story:
Super Quick Lowdown

Don’t have the time to read through the whole thing? That’s Cool – here is the gist of it all...

Flux Vertical Theatre has finally found a home. We just signed a lease on a 4,000 sq ft building in Berkeley California and we are proud to announce that we will be opening up our very first alternative dance studio and performance space.

We have a lot of work ahead of us since we are building our perfect studio with a stage from scratch. We have a solid foundation and now all we need is a little help from our friends. Every donation will go towards creating the most beautiful space to dance in and entertain you. 

We are dedicated to bringing you world class pole and dance instruction and are excited to feature incredible talent and skills from all genres of pole. Our focus is cultivating dancers who want to reach the spotlight and we are committed to instituting a supportive, safe and diverse community where we are all free to express ourselves. 

In order for Flux Vertical Theatre to open its doors, there are some things we need your help with right now: keep reading for more info, pick a perk and contribute, then spread the word. We are so excited about this space. It has been a long journey already and we can’t wait to one day sit back and kick our stilettos up and look at all the glorious community around us!

We would be honored to feel your love and support in this dream of ours. 

Thanks for being a supporter of the Bay Area pole and dance community!

Our WHO

For those of you who don't know us, Flux Vertical Theatre is a Bay Area dance company specializing in the art of pole, founded by Kirsten (aka Mz. K) and Leah Marie. For the past 6 years we have been dancing our way through the Bay Area and beyond with high quality performances and incredible talent. Our company member's and performers come from unique backgrounds ranging from classical and contemporary styles of dance, gymnastics, theater and circus arts. Our mission is to inspire and entertain you through our collaborative work, united by our love of Pole. 

We have been dreaming of one day having a studio of our own to rehearse in and that day has finally come. Our new Flux Vertical Theatre Academy will allow us to train our future pole stars and will also provide a gorgeous stage for us all to perform on. 

Without our dancers and our fans, Flux Vertical Theatre would be nothing.

We count on all our supporters to show up constantly and we demand a lot of our artists as well. We are so lucky to have this incredible community and we are excited to give back!

 

Our WHAT

Our goal is to create an all encompassing, amazing and diverse community under one roof. So what does that look like? Well, it looks like this:

ONE PART Academy: Our academy students will learn from top notch dancers and choreographers and will be rewarded with stage time. That’s right, if your dream is to be in the spotlight then this is the program for you!

ONE PART Alternative Dance Studio: Want to just come and pick up a new skill or work on toning those muscles in a creative and exciting way without the pressure of being on stage? We got that too. But make sure you come out and cheer all your new friends when it’s showtime!

ONE PART Theatre: We will now be able to host our own showcases, performances and cabaret shows! We will also be able to open our doors to others that are in need of a gorgeous theatre space and stage for their dream shows!

ONE PART Dance Company: Flux Vertical Theatre will finally have it’s own stage and rehearsal space so that we can continue to bring you pole and dance shows with no limitations!

Our WHY

The most common question we consistently get asked from our show goers is “Where can I learn to do this?” or “Where can I take a Flux Vertical Theatre class?” And we have never been able to fully answer this question... until now! 

With the art and sport of pole growing everyday and becoming more popular, having a safe space for all genres of the pole community to be together in is a huge deal. Pole is a place where so many people find their freedom of movement, body acceptance, inner beauty, strength, confidence and most of all life long friends. Pole can be athletic, artistic or sensual. Pole is for any age and ANY BODY and we want to share it with the world in our new space!

The Money

We are looking to raise $50,000 to get us started. This will help cover the beginning stages of the build out. We will first need to add a fresh coat of paint while the trussing and poles are being installed. Then we start laying down our sprung wood floor so we can protect our dancers' joints and muscles. The stage is next! 

Here is an estimated breakdown of those costs: 

Trussing - $18,700   Poles - $8,700   Floors - $17,100   Stage - $5,000   Paint - $500

As you can see it will take much more to complete this project and to realize our ultimate vision but it will get the ball rolling. Building a studio is an intense labor of love and is not going to be cheap. If we raise money beyond our goal we will be able to get super tall mirrors for our walls, gorgeous velvet stage curtains, lighting and sound equipment for the stage and also add some amenities like a second bathroom for your tushy’s!

We are just two girls with big dreams and at the end of the day it’s just about making dreams come true!

The Perks

We are so grateful that there is really no limit to what we are willing to give back. But for now this is what we have come up with to give to you for giving to us. 

Check out the full list --> --> --> --> -->

Other Ways You Can Help

For those of you who are interested in a tax deductible way to donate directly to us, follow the link below to our Dancers Group page for a guilt free way to give us money! We are honored to be the only pole dance company sponsored by this esteemed organization.

https://www.flipcause.com/secure/cause_pdetails...

 

If you are not able to financially contribute, that’s totally fine. There are other ways you can support that will make a huge difference that don’t cost a thing! 

1- Please share this video far and wide! Share to your friends and family and on social media. In the age of technology social media is the best way to spread the word for pretty much anything! 

2- Tell your neighbor, tell your dog, tell your bartender, you never know who is going to show up to help us succeed. 

That being said please follow us on IG @FluxVerticalTheatre and on Facebook here: https://www.facebook.com/fluxverticaltheatre

You can also check us out on YouTube by following us at this link: https://www.youtube.com/fluxverticaltheatre

 

We are also accepting help regarding all aspects of the process, physical labor, advice, a shoulder to cry on and even some Titos.

https://www.flipcause.com/secure/cause_pdetails...

That being said please follow us on IG @FluxVerticalTheatre and on Facebook here: https://www.facebook.com/fluxverticaltheatre

story:
About "Jesus Hopped the 'A' Train"

Written by Stephen Adly Guirgis, Jesus Hopped The "A" Train  tells the story of several inmates of Rikers Prison who are awaiting charges for murder. Angel Cruz is a young Puerto Rican man incarcerated for shooting a cult leader after said person “stole” his best friend. When the cult leader dies during surgery, Angel suddenly finds himself facing murder charges. Added to the mix are Lucius Jenkins, a serial killer turned born-again Christian, and Valdez, a sadistic corrections officer. 

Jesus Hopped the 'A' Train is a project we've been wanting to do for over a year now.  Although COVID presented many challenges, we've still managed to come together.

Our team is working hard to get this play ready for a November production, and we need your help!

Our Team

Director: Rahul Gandhi

Rahul Gandhi is an actor, director, creator, and producer born, raised, and located in Tiohtià:ke / Montreal. Though his heart lies on stage, he wears a variety of hats in and around theatre, film, television, and Arts Service.

His company, Tantalus, where he is co-artistic director has produced four productions, and is now working on the currently postponed What Rough Beast by Alice Abracen presented as part The Brave New Looks series at Centaur Theatre.

Notable credits-- direction: Amuse Me by Laurent Pitre, assistant direction on Stendhal X's God of Carnage, film/TV:  The Bold Type, Best Sellers, Theatre: Romeo in HPC’s Romeo and Juliet, alumni of the Black Theatre Workshop AMP ensemble. He holds a Bachelor of Fine Arts (with honors) in Acting, and a Graduates Diploma in Communication studies, both from Concordia University.

Stage Manager: Kennedy Huffman-Baillargeon

Kennedy Huffman-Baillargeon is a bilingual artist based in Montreal. Since moving to the city in 2016, she has been involved in numerous collaborative theatre projects including a performance at the Bayerische Theatertage Festival in Fürth, Germany in 2018. After graduating with a BFA in Acting for the Theatre from Concordia University, Kennedy has tried to diversify her abilities in the world of theatre and is glad to be taking on a role other than that of an actor as the stage manager of this production of "Jesus Hopped the 'A' Train"

Producer/Actor: Joshua Bilbao, "Angel Cruz" 

Joshua Bilbao is a Canadian Mexican actor currently based in Montreal. Having studied theatre in New York, Los Angeles & Vienna, Joshua continues to discover new passions through his love for acting such as directing, writing and producing.  One of his many goals is to continue to work on stories such as "Jesus Hopped the 'A' Train". 

Producer/Actor: Vanessa Lynn Rancourt, "Mary Jane"

Vanessa Lynn Rancourt is a franco-anglo actress located in Montreal. She has appeared in numerous theatre productions in Los Angeles and in both TV and film in Montreal such as District 31 and Deep Web. In 2021 she directed her first short film, Her Face Her Body, which lead to her first nomination as best new director for the Vancouver Independent Film Festival. Vanessa is a strongly trained actress with over 8 years of working with the industry’s elite. Along with her acting career, she started House of Actors in 2016 and has grown it to be one of Montreal’s most coveted hot spots for young artists.

Actor: Jean Bernard, "Lucius Jenkins"

Jean Bernard is Montreal born and raised. He acts, writes, and directs, in whichever order pays the bills, and if there’s no dough flow, it’s acting all the way. He’s in video games, cartoons, movies, indies, improv shows, webseries, and the lead singer for the heavy metal band Steve Jones & The Rubber Chickens. Like all independent contractors in the gig economy, he’s on the open road. Hopefully on his way to success, or at least a metric ton of fun.

Actor: Scott Kettles, "D'Amico"

Scott stumbled into acting at the ripe old age of 25 while briefly living and working in England. He was appropriately "snared for life" after portraying the doomed Garcin in Jean-Paul Sartre's No Exit. The intervening years have seen him engaged in the search for writers that need to be heard. "There is nothing more satisfying than giving voice to a playwright's invention. It is a collaboration that can span decades or centuries. Shakespeare, Pinter, Joanna Glass, David Sherman, David Fennario, Stephen Adly Guirgis, are some of the partners who have shown me a tapestry of 'human being' which I could never have dreamt in my personal philosophy. All aboard!"

Actor: Evan Pavlou, "Valdez"

Evangelos Pavlou is an actor based in Montreal. After pursuing alternate careers, he finally
decided to follow his dream and enroll in the Acting for the Theatre program at Concordia
University. Within his three years in the program, he played such roles as Stephano in
William Shakespear’s The Tempest, and as Kulygin in Anton Chekhov’s The Three Sisters. He
is an ACTRA apprentice and shortly after graduation, Evangelos landed the role of Sal in
Stephen Adly Guirgis’ Den of Thieves. His dream, of course, is to be a prominent figure in
the voice acting world and has spent the better part of the pandemic working on this
aspect of his craft. Evangelos looks forward to all future endeavours with all the challenges
they might bring.

Your donation

We're thrilled to be bringing this play to audiences, live and in person. The $3000 we raise will go toward compensating our artists, renting our space, performance rights, and funding set, sound, costumes, props, and lights. 

Other Ways You Can Help

Even if you're not able to donate, we'd appreciate your support in spreading the word about our campaign (feel free to share our Indiegogo page!) and our play!

Credit to Vanessa Burns for the poster. Thank you!
story_txt: About "Jesus Hopped the 'A' Train"Written by Stephen Adly Guirgis, Jesus Hopped The "A" Train  tells the story of several inmates of Rikers Prison who are awaiting charges for murder. Angel Cruz is a young Puerto Rican man incarcerated for shooting a cult leader after said person “stole” his best friend. When the cult leader dies during surgery, Angel suddenly finds himself facing murder charges. Added to the mix are Lucius Jenkins, a serial killer turned born-again Christian, and Valdez, a sadistic corrections officer. Jesus Hopped the 'A' Train is a project we've been wanting to do for over a year now.  Although COVID presented many challenges, we've still managed to come together.Our team is working hard to get this play ready for a November production, and we need your help!Our TeamDirector: Rahul GandhiRahul Gandhi is an actor, director, creator, and producer born, raised, and located in Tiohtià:ke / Montreal. Though his heart lies on stage, he wears a variety of hats in and around theatre, film, television, and Arts Service.His company, Tantalus, where he is co-artistic director has produced four productions, and is now working on the currently postponed What Rough Beast by Alice Abracen presented as part The Brave New Looks series at Centaur Theatre.Notable credits-- direction: Amuse Me by Laurent Pitre, assistant direction on Stendhal X's God of Carnage, film/TV:  The Bold Type, Best Sellers, Theatre: Romeo in HPC’s Romeo and Juliet, alumni of the Black Theatre Workshop AMP ensemble. He holds a Bachelor of Fine Arts (with honors) in Acting, and a Graduates Diploma in Communication studies, both from Concordia University.Stage Manager: Kennedy Huffman-BaillargeonKennedy Huffman-Baillargeon is a bilingual artist based in Montreal. Since moving to the city in 2016, she has been involved in numerous collaborative theatre projects including a performance at the Bayerische Theatertage Festival in Fürth, Germany in 2018. After graduating with a BFA in Acting for the Theatre from Concordia University, Kennedy has tried to diversify her abilities in the world of theatre and is glad to be taking on a role other than that of an actor as the stage manager of this production of "Jesus Hopped the 'A' Train"Producer/Actor: Joshua Bilbao, "Angel Cruz" Joshua Bilbao is a Canadian Mexican actor currently based in Montreal. Having studied theatre in New York, Los Angeles & Vienna, Joshua continues to discover new passions through his love for acting such as directing, writing and producing.  One of his many goals is to continue to work on stories such as "Jesus Hopped the 'A' Train". Producer/Actor: Vanessa Lynn Rancourt, "Mary Jane"Vanessa Lynn Rancourt is a franco-anglo actress located in Montreal. She has appeared in numerous theatre productions in Los Angeles and in both TV and film in Montreal such as District 31 and Deep Web. In 2021 she directed her first short film, Her Face Her Body, which lead to her first nomination as best new director for the Vancouver Independent Film Festival. Vanessa is a strongly trained actress with over 8 years of working with the industry’s elite. Along with her acting career, she started House of Actors in 2016 and has grown it to be one of Montreal’s most coveted hot spots for young artists.Actor: Jean Bernard, "Lucius Jenkins"Jean Bernard is Montreal born and raised. He acts, writes, and directs, in whichever order pays the bills, and if there’s no dough flow, it’s acting all the way. He’s in video games, cartoons, movies, indies, improv shows, webseries, and the lead singer for the heavy metal band Steve Jones & The Rubber Chickens. Like all independent contractors in the gig economy, he’s on the open road. Hopefully on his way to success, or at least a metric ton of fun.Actor: Scott Kettles, "D'Amico"Scott stumbled into acting at the ripe old age of 25 while briefly living and working in England. He was appropriately "snared for life" after portraying the doomed Garcin in Jean-Paul Sartre's No Exit. The intervening years have seen him engaged in the search for writers that need to be heard. "There is nothing more satisfying than giving voice to a playwright's invention. It is a collaboration that can span decades or centuries. Shakespeare, Pinter, Joanna Glass, David Sherman, David Fennario, Stephen Adly Guirgis, are some of the partners who have shown me a tapestry of 'human being' which I could never have dreamt in my personal philosophy. All aboard!"Actor: Evan Pavlou, "Valdez"Evangelos Pavlou is an actor based in Montreal. After pursuing alternate careers, he finallydecided to follow his dream and enroll in the Acting for the Theatre program at ConcordiaUniversity. Within his three years in the program, he played such roles as Stephano inWilliam Shakespear’s The Tempest, and as Kulygin in Anton Chekhov’s The Three Sisters. Heis an ACTRA apprentice and shortly after graduation, Evangelos landed the role of Sal inStephen Adly Guirgis’ Den of Thieves. His dream, of course, is to be a prominent figure inthe voice acting world and has spent the better part of the pandemic working on thisaspect of his craft. Evangelos looks forward to all future endeavours with all the challengesthey might bring.Your donationWe're thrilled to be bringing this play to audiences, live and in person. The $3000 we raise will go toward compensating our artists, renting our space, performance rights, and funding set, sound, costumes, props, and lights. Other Ways You Can HelpEven if you're not able to donate, we'd appreciate your support in spreading the word about our campaign (feel free to share our Indiegogo page!) and our play!Credit to Vanessa Burns for the poster. Thank you!

story:
Who are we?

We are dancers and musicians of Southeast Michigan, bringing the joy of dance with live music across Metro Detroit. We share our love of dance and music through performance and education. 

What We Need & What You Get

  • Ticket sales only cover a portion of what's needed to pay dancers, musicians, costume designers, costume costs and venue rental fees. We need supporters like you to help us continue to create work for immensely talented, hardworking performers of Michigan.
  • Donors can receive show tickets, swag and listings on all marketing materials.
  • We strive to keep events affordable and accessible for all to attend.

The Impact

  • The arts give us immeasurable personal and social benefits.
  • Since 2008, we have been providing opportunities and outreach to aspiring dancers, dance educators and working professional dancers and musicians.
  • With your support, we can continue to create, perform, educate and engage our community.

Risks & Challenges

  • Producing cultural events is always a challenge, especially with the tumult of the last year and a half and the uncertainty of what's ahead, but without arts and culture we are less connected. 
  • As the adage goes, the show must go on, but to be successful we need your help!

Other Ways You Can Help

  • Spread the word! 

All amounts are met with huge gratitude.

All amounts are met with huge gratitude.

story:
What is... Come Back to IMPACT?


The story: Seventeen years ago, visionary and founder of MT Space (Multicultural Theatre Space), Majdi Bou-Matar, created a dynamic week filled with eclectic, contemporary and physical theatre and a platform for artists from all backgrounds to showcase their work. He saw a cross-pollination of artistic practices that can transform differences into innovation and spark dialogue. So much beauty, creativity, innovation, sorrow, grief, and passion has brought us to where we are today. Now, through a global pandemic, we are still bringing you #IMPACT21Festival. We are asking that you Come Back to IMPACT!

No one could have predicted that shortly after #IMPACT19Festival marked its 10th Anniversary appearance in the Waterloo Region, that things would change so drastically in such a short period of time. We were all forced to close our doors to keep each other safe and healthy as we tried our best to make sense of how we move forward and how we continue to create, all while watching the world change around us like nothing we’d ever seen before.

However, nothing will truly ever stop the arts. We learned how to adjust, how to pay artists to create in this time, how to make art happen together under restriction, how to shift the arts online, and through this we made art more accessible, more visible, more personal, more political, and more easily shared across the world.

Following a year and a half of this pandemic that brought to the mainstream underlying social and political injustices worldwide, IMPACT 21 brings us to a place of necessary healing while moving forward.

The festival this year dives into the issues that were brought to light over the past year from the lived and ancestral experiences of Indigenous, Black, and racialized artists, while also holding space for conversation and relationship.

In a time when we hope to dismantle systems and reshape society, we ask ourselves, “How do we begin again?”

As we demonstrate our resilience by carefully re-opening our doors and carving out spaces for artists to tell their stories, we invite you to Come Back to IMPACT. Come take a stand with us as we use theatre as a means to challenge and instigate societal change.

This year, IMPACT 21 will spread over two weeks, from September 28th to October 9th, as we present powerful productions from, Tunisia, Chile, India, Australia, and more.

Making a donation to this campaign will help us to pay artists, to reconnect with our national and international networks, and to bring communities together to create a community of difference. Help us make IMPACT!




MT Space (founded 2004, Kitchener) is a multicultural theatre company that creates, presents and tours challenging work locally, nationally and internationally. Find out more at mtspace.ca or follow us on Facebook.



How can we Come Back to IMPACT together?

Come Back to IMPACT is the 5th Indiegogo Crowdfunding Campaign held by MT Space. This year, your contributions will help us:

  ⋅  Keep our ticket prices low!

  ⋅  Pay our artists, relieve their transportation and accommodation costs 

  ⋅  Help us continue to be resilient as we collectively face COVID-19

Together, we can enrich our community with space for all voices.
Together, we can create the conditions for innovation and connection.
Together, we can Come Back to IMPACT!

 


 

We understand that these have been hard times for everyone while we are asking for your donations and your support. With this in mind we have created tiers with options as low as $5, and we truly thank you for anything you provide. We are grateful for your generosity and passion for the arts, and we acknowledge every donation received!

Help us spread the word and Come Back to IMPACT. We can't wait!

 

 

Donating to this campaign comes with many perks - see the list on the sidebar! You can also choose to donate without claiming a perk! MT Space is a registered charitable organization and is able to provide you with a tax receipt for donations $20 or higher.

Thanks for reading, and we hope to see you at this year's IMPACT 21 Festival!

story:
The Tarot Reading

Called "fresh and daring" (DCTS), The Tarot Reading is a variety show with an arcane twist—each act inspired by a Tarot Card, and each act is interactive, performed for and with one adventurous and consenting audience member. What happens next is "a wholly new framework for experiencing live theatre...a captivating catharsis not to be missed" (DCMTA). 

Tarot VI  will arrive March 25-April 10, 2022 at Theatre on the Run, just outside Shirlington Village in Arlington. Tickets won't go on sale until Fall 2021, but you can guarantee yourself one of only a handful of interactive tickets (called "Seeker" tickets, our name for adventurous participants) now! What's more, you can pick up some super sweet merch too!

Merch Details

Tickets | When you order a ticket, we'll contact you via email to choose a performance date before they go on sale to the general public in the fall. When we do, you can get either a Seeker (interactive) or Witness (non-interactive) ticket, and you can book for any performance. Tarot VI runs Fri-Sun, March 25-April 10, 2022.

Pins and Tees | When you back the campaign and reward yourself with merch like Pentacle Pins and Tarot Tees. When you do, we will hold your merch for you and you'll receive it when you see the show in March, 2022. If you just can't wait to get your hands on some merch (and who could blame you?), there are add-on perks to cover shipping. There's one add-on for Pins, and separate add-on for Tees, since they're coming from different suppliers.  If you add-on merch shipping, it will arrive no later than Halloween, 2021. 

Shipping covers only one of each item type, so if you buy multiples you must add on shipping for each item.

The World, by Rachel Menyuk (Tarot V)

The Wizard, by Jon Jon Johnson (Tarot IV)

The Devil, by Toni Rae Salmi (Tarot V)

The World, by Justin J. Bell (Tarot IV)

The Beast, by Nyla Rose (Tarot IV)

Tarot V production design by Niomi Collard. Tarot IV production design by Mary Keegan. All production photos by R. Maxwell Photography.

story:
Short Summary

My name is Sophie Holmes (She/Her) and I am a performance artist working with body somatics, presence and space to create new artwork. As part of a Fellowship with the LEIMAY Ensemble, called the Incubator Program, I am working on a devised performance piece called FRAGMENT.  The LEIMAY Ensemble is a performance and dance collective based in Williamsburg, Brooklyn. This is a 2 night performance taking place in Brooklyn, NY on October 28th & 29th 2021 at Cloud City in Williamsburg.  A solo performance that includes the presences of many, the piece is a play on “first thought best thought” and a collaboration with ensemble near and far.  Admission will be sliding scale $5-$20, no one will be turned away for lack of funds, follow link to purchase your ticket(s) here!

 https://withfriends.co/event/12666261/fragment

A snippet from the piece…

The workerchef, the animal clay body, the newspaper femme doctor join in conversation to untangle the threads, the elements that create unison and a fourth happening.  Heat, water, clay, newspaper and rocks and the red light square. Come get fed!

What We Need & What You Get

I am looking to raise $3,500 for this project.  Some of that money is going to me, the artist, the rest will be put toward paying for materials (clay, clothing, objects), transportation, videographer (Camera rental, editing), rehearsal fees, sound equipment, lighting, advertising and a project assistant/manager.

I’m hoping to raise a majority of the money though the ‘’selling’’ of some of my sculptures.  The rest I am asking for in generous donations, $1-$1000 please!  You may choose one of my sculptures to buy as a “perk,” partly because you like it :), and partly as a thank you for your generosity in supporting art makers. All the sculptures I have made in the last year are inspired by chance and space awareness.  Some of them have ways of standing or sitting and others may want to be hung, worn or even pinned (hot glue needed).  I will leave that up to you, so please let me know if I can include a piece of red thread, yellow thread (or both) or a brooch pin.  If you choose to make the piece a brooch I will be happy to provide the pin but ask that you do the gluing as a small part in making it your own.  Please note that while the sculptures may appear large, they are actually quite small.  1-3 inches for most of the metal ones and 4-10 inches for those that incorporate wood.  Small is beautiful. 

I may be adding more perks as time goes on, so please keep a look out!

And another thing…Please come! That would mean the most to me!  Money helps the process though :).  I also plan on making photo prints from the performance to mail to everyone who donates after as an additional thank you.  If you chose a sculpted friend then I already have your address and if you didn’t then I’ll contact you to find a way to send you one.  Amazing, thank you.

The Impact

The most immediate impact will be in the sharing of this work with a collective witness and co-creator in space, aka you all. As an art person I always seek community, both intimate and collective, and performance brings people into community and can act as a living part of that community.  In a different sense, as a personal process, the real impact is unknown and ongoing.

Risks & Challenges

Covid-19, health and safety pose a risk and challenge to art makers and in asking people to gather (45-50 viewers max) it is something that I am taking seriously.  While NYC is relatively well vaccinated and cases are stable, the delta variant and country wide low vaccinations rates still present an active health risk.  Proof of full vaccination will be mandatory, masks will also be required for entry. Social distancing will not be able to be maintained as it is an intimate space but with masks and vaccination we are doing the best we can to keep everyone safe.  If you feel sick, have tested positive for Covid within two weeks prior to the performance or have been exposed to Covid-19 we ask that stay home or in exposure cases, get a negative test result before coming. Please get vaccinated if you haven’t already so that you can come see art. Thank you!

Other Ways You Can Help

I understand that asking for money is not a small thing and anyway people can contribute financially will be so meaningful to this process.  I also understand that it’s not easy or possible to always give in that way.  I can only ask that if giving money is not available to you but you want to contribute in some way to please share this event with anyone you think would be interested. Or, even better, if not able to donate please come to the performance!!  Again, no one will be turned away at the door for financial reasons, come see art. Thank you for your kindness, your generosity, thank you for your heart!

story:
MS Magic team has another new invention, here we present you - Rocket, the ultimate handheld card fountain

MS Magic always focus on practical and creative magic tools. Today we have a brand new original professional magic device to share with you all.

Rocket is a joint project by FISM Asia Champion Xin Yafei and MS Magic.

Our concept is very simple, a strong and compact card fountain device, which you can palm with your hand or place anywhere you like. The end product is way better than we think and different from all other similar products in the market, here is our card fountain first debut - Rocket!

 

Since we want to apply Rocket to most of our performance situation, we have made it can be controlled by 2 method.

1. Direct control

A button on the side of the device, you can press with your thumb to activate. Due to this controlling method, it has right hand version and left hand version. If you are planning to use it with you right hand then get the right hand version, vice versa.

2. Remote control

Every Rocket can be controlled by our remote control, you can use it offhand like placing it in your table or hidden somewhere in the stage. The max control distance is 20 meters (without influence). 

 

Rocket provide different way to mount it, we will teach all of these way in the tutorial, so you can use Rocket in all situation.

1. Bare hand

2. Card box

3. Card fan

4. Glove

5. Top hat

6. Table

The new compact design make the Rocket probably the most versatile card shooting device.

You can use Rocket for many situation:

1. Card manipulation magic

2. Sword Card stab

3. Opening effect for shows

4. Substitution of pyro effect

5. Theatre special effects

 

 

To ensure Rocket has a decent height, we chose a high power motor and 12V battery.

Card height of Rocket can reach 3 meters.

This height is perfect for most of the situation, parlor, stage and sometimes even close up too. 

 

During our champaign we always want to provide the best discount possible for our supporter. Here you will be getting Rocket in the lowest price possible, and only during this champaign you will enjoy more than 50% off, and never again.

The est. retail price for Rocket will be USD$220 - $250, but now on Indiegogo you can get it for USD$148, now that's a good deal!

 

We provide 1 year free of charge warranty for all of our Rocket (shipping not included).

The whole set consist of the following:

Rocket main device - 1

Charger (100 - 240V) - 1

Remote - 1

Back up wheel - 1

 

Hello, we are MS Magic, it is our pleasure to launch our project once again on Indiegogo. Indiegogo is really helpful for our product development, during this difficult time, and we are grateful for all the help you guys are giving us.

Please do support us here on Indiegogo while we offer special discount to you all for helping this project possible.

Thank you very much for your continues support and let’s get the magic started!

Feel free to contact us directly if you have any questions.

Facebook: www.facebook.com/magiclismstore

- MS Magic Team

story:
An Unusual Mission for an Unusual Time

"Something’s not quite right in the arthropod world, and Science needs your help to find out why. As courageous volunteers in cutting edge research, you and your fellow humans are invited to super secret Nomtanso Laboratories, where the state-of-the-art Shrinker Machine will send you on a bug-sized recon adventure to find out what is going on with those little critters at the bottom of the food chain. However, what, or rather, who awaits may surprise you. How will your research play out? Will you find Thea?" 

 

This is an uplifting interactive tale about the myriad of ways we experience grief, and the opportunities we have to help each other through it. Hosted online, on Gather-town, audiences of 20 will come together from across the world and set out to uncover the mystery of Thea L’Anna in a branching narrative adventure story filled with light escape room-like puzzling elements, surprising characters, and poetic dialogue. Part show, part game; it's something like a mix between Honey I Shrunk the Kids and Pokémon Red if it were written by T.S. Elliot.

Here's everyone who is directly involved in bringing Thea L'Anna to light and life:

  • Kimberly Ridgeway - actor and ensemble writer
  • Alix Josefski - actor and ensemble writer
  • Alicia MP Nelson - actor and ensemble writer
  • KC Hyland - actor and ensemble writer, scientific consultant
  • Darica Louie - actor and ensemble writer, web development associate
  • AnJu Hyppolite - actor and ensemble writer, associate director
  • Elaine Blank PhD - Grief consultant and dramaturg
  • G.V. Hartman - Graphic designer and campaign community manager
  • Kellie Lu - Associate map designer
  • Hailey Qu - Associate map designer
  • Magnetic Mapworks - Gather.town consultation and environment design
  • Dragon Productions Theatre Company* - Co-producer and non-profit fiscal sponsor
  • Spencer Williams - Co-producer and lead writer
  • Nathanael Card - Co-producer and director

*Dragon Productions is: Max Koknar (Chief Visionary Officer), Alika Spencer-Koknar (Chief Talent Officer), Justine Bechler (Chief Operating Officer), Rachel Nin (Production Stage Manager), Lydia Feuerhelm (Communications Manager)

Our Process

It is essential that this story arise from authenticity. The director and writer are working with the actors to craft characters and performances which capture the quirks (and often, contradictions) of real, lived experiences. To build on that authenticity, we're offering the chance for you to participate in a "beta" run - and early-access preview of the first act of the show - and share your reactions and ideas to help influence the continued development of Thea L'Anna. The live beta will run July 9 - 25, the final preview coinciding with the conclusion of this campaign. There will be an additional 6 weeks of development before Thea L'Anna goes live to the world. 

What We Need & What You Get

Our initial goal of $5500 covers the basics of the production: paying artist stipends, purchasing and shipping props and costumes, custom graphic arts and other digital media, design and implementation of the virtual world of the show on Gather.town, marketing, and printing.

We have tentative stretch goals of $8000 and $10,000 which will allow for increased artist stipends, pay for a Discord community manager, additional media for marketing, improvements to production assets, and cool programming magic to further enrich the immersive experience of the virtual world of Thea L'Anna. 

It's our great pleasure to provide some exciting perks for your contribution to this goal: custom art created for the show by the incredible Genevieve Hartman, contributor-only early access and the opportunity to impact the story and it's content and be included in it, a stress relief activity book, an invitation to our Discord community where we'll be sharing sneak peaks and other exclusive content,  VIP "founders" care packages, eternal recognition as an early supporter of Thea L'Anna in our digital program...and of course, our sincere and enthusiastic thanks! 

The Impact

Now for the most important part: the difference you'll make by supporting this campaign! Thea L'Anna is as much about individual journeys as it is about the social nature of grief support. This is a community and we are connecting through compassion - you can help it to flourish and thrive by joining us! As we move forward in the wake of a devastating pandemic and ongoing climate change, it's more critical than ever that we make time and space for collective healing. 

Not to mention a portion of your campaign contribution is tax deductible, helping Dragon Productions - a Bay Area non-profit - continue to make impactful art in their mission to serve as a theatrical hub that fosters an inclusive artistic community for the creation of experiences that are innovative, intimate, empathetic, accessible and bold.

Risks & Challenges

Here's some great news: there's no risk involved. Thanks to seed funding from Dragon Productions and Magnetic Mapworks, Thea L'Anna has enough of a financial foundation to guarantee that this production gets off the ground. Your contribution helps us build on that momentum and soar. 

Other Ways You Can Help

Here's some more good news: you don't have to spend any money to help out if you're not able or ready to! Word of mouth is just as valuable of a contribution as any dollar amount. By sharing this campaign with your friends and family (direct messages make the biggest impact!) and on your favorite social media platform, this campaign can blossom into the flourishing community it's envisioned to be. 

So, today, right now, we are inviting you to join us in crafting this soul-stirring experience, as we collectively kintsugi our fractured selves in the healing cocoon of theatre. If you’re ready, don’t miss this opportunity to make something beautiful with us. We’ve shared so much grief together, it’s worth sharing the recovery too. 

On behalf of the entire Thea L'Anna team, 

Nathanael Card, Producing Director

story:
OUTDOORS THIS SUMMER! Before Bway re-opens:

DUTCH KINGS

by Kristen I. Spencer 

Directed by Christopher D. Betts

~WORLD PREMIERE~

6 LIVE in-person performances 

OPENING Sunday August 15 at 3pm. 

The story of the play:

Today is the Annual Block Shop Double Dutch Competition and the Dutch Kings title is up for whichever team has the BADDEST, lyrical jumpers on the block. What starts off as a fun competition becomes an unraveling of self-identity in a quickly changing neighborhood. What are Black boys to do when once holy ground is suddenly unsafe and uptownies have come to take over their block?

Please help raise $10,000 to make this production a reality!

Check out the discounted tickets and perks. Be sure to click on each perk to learn more!

Dutch Kings has a $30,000 budget. Only $10,000 will come from ticket sales in order to keep prices low for the RED HOOK community. 

BNW REP began developing this play for Brave New Works 2021: Zoom in January 2021. 

Preview date: August 15th at 11am. Opening: August 15 at 3pm. Additional dates: August 21 and August 28 at 11am and 3pm.

Can't SEE IT LIVE in Brooklyn in August?

All donors to this Campaign automatically receive a Zoom link to our online July 31 benefit

performance with some new faces...

August seating will be limited and we anticipate a large turnout:

  • $300 guarantees you 2 front and center seats for opening performance.  
  • $200: 2 Premium Seats for opening performance (Goes UP to $300 after July 25.) 
  • $100: 2 premium seats at any other performance  (Goes UP to $200 after July 25.) 
  • $25: 2 regular seats (50% 0ff).

Other perks include:

  • an autographed copy of the DUTCH KINGS script 
  • Cocktails with the playwright and BNW artistic director at at MangoSeed, a Black owned bar and restaurant at 755 Flatbush Ave.  Must redeem by Sept 1.

BNW Rep believes that Dutch Kings "has legs" and deserves to be seen all over the country.

This important play humanizes young Black Lives with humor and compassion, physical power, poetry and grace.

Kristen I. Spencer has created a world at once familiar and deeply intimate and specific to her characters. It's not to be missed, and you can be a part of its seminal history.

Like To Kill a Mockingbird, Street Scene and Shakespeare on Stratford, Brave New World Rep will shut down a Brooklyn street for theater Red Hook will not soon forget. We hope you will be a part of it and tell your friends and neighbors!

And if you cannot join us in August, we hope to see you over Zoom on July 31!

story:
A Chilling Reality...

Since 2016, Las Vegas's Majestic Repertory Theatre has been home to a very diverse group of theatre artists: actors, writers, directors,  and designers. Our work - particularly in immersive and experiential productions - has been featured in national and global media, including The New York Times, USA Today, CNN, Good Morning America, and more.

However, like many arts organizations around the world, we were severely impacted by the COVID pandemic. Our doors closed in March 2020, and although we have been experimenting with distanced performances, we will not be able to return to full indoor productions until Fall 2021.

To mark that very special occasion, we will be producing the American premiere of The Sandman - a new musical by the writers of the Tony-winning Broadway musical Bandstand, Richard Oberacker and Robert Taylor.

 

A Terrifying Tale...

Drawn from the more nightmarish fantasy of E.T.A. Hoffmann, author of The Nutcracker, comes a new and darkly comic musical tale – THE SANDMAN. When the family of an ingenious German clockmaker engages a new nanny to care for the children, a series of bizarre and unnatural events begin to unfold. As the Strauss family is thrust ever deeper into chaos, the sinister forces at play are revealed – forces from which only the children may be able to save them.

Original artwork by Stephanie Delazeri

 

Why Your Support Matters

Producing THE SANDMAN is an opportunity for our award-winning theatre company to make an impactful return to live production in our 99-seat storefront in the heart of the Las Vegas Arts District.

The writers selected Majestic Repertory Theater for their American premiere because of our reputation for tackling daring, new works. Originally slated for Fall 2020, we're excited to finally bring this Little Nightmare Musical to gleefully ghoulish light.

However, diving into any project of this size after a year-long shutdown is like cranking a Chevy that's been parked for months: we need a jumpstart.

Unlike many non-profit organizations, charitable donations only make up a small amount of our operating budget. We rely primarily on single ticket sales - but having been closed for the past year, we haven't had those sales. So, this Indiegogo campaign is like you giving us those jumper cables.

With the money raised from this campaign:

  • We will be able to hire the finest theatrical designers to bring this nightmare vision to life.

  • We will be able to hire an amazing cast, all of whom have been out of work for the past year.

  • We will be able to pay royalties to the writers of this thrilling work. 
     

About the Writers

Conductor, composer, lyricist and librettist Richard Oberacker is the musical director for Cirque du Soleil’s “KA” in Las Vegas. Prior engagements include conductor, arranger and contributing composer for Cirque’s world tour of DRALION and conductor of the national tours of Disney’s THE LION KING. As a composer and lyricist, Mr. Oberacker’s original musicals include A LITTLE THEATER (Aurelia Theater), IN THAT VALLEY (National Alliance for Musical Theater Festival of New Works), DRACULA (CCM Corbett Theater), and THE GOSPEL ACCORDING TO FISHMAN (Signature Theatre). With co-lyricist and co-author Robert Taylor, Mr. Oberacker has collaborated on several new musicals including ACE, (National Alliance for Musical Theater New Works Festival, The Repertory Theatre of St. Louis, Cincinnati Playhouse in the Park, The Old Globe, Signature Theatre), JOURNEY TO THE WEST (New York Musical Theater Festival), THE PARENTING PROJECT (Cincinnati Fringe Festival, Ensemble Theatre of Cincinnati), and THE SANDMAN (NAMT Festival of New Works, Fredericia Theatre in Denmark). Their TONY Award-winning musical BANDSTAND opened at The Paper Mill Playhouse and premiered on Broadway at the Bernard B. Jacobs Theatre, was filmed for Fathom Events release in cinemas nationwide, and is now on a National Tour. Mr. Oberacker recently composed the score for a new musical adaptation of THE GREAT GATSBY which premiered in Tokyo, Japan before a Japanese national tour. Their newest musical, BRUCE, premieres in a co-production with The Seattle Repertory Theatre and Paper Mill Playhouse in the upcoming theater season.

ROBERT TAYLOR began writing poetry and lyrics around the same time he picked up the violin at age eight. His love of music, languages, literature, and nature has led him to a lifetime of study and travel. A graduate of Holland’s Royal Conservatory, Union College, the University of Bonn, and Princeton University, he has taught foreign languages and ornithology in New York, English and music in China, served as music critic to the Albany Times Union, worked as a freelance musician and writer in Manhattan, a translator in Europe and Asia, and has lectured extensively on opera, literature, and art history. Mr. Taylor is the co-lyricist/librettist with Richard Oberacker of several new musicals, including ACE, (National Alliance for Musical Theater New Works Festival, The Repertory Theatre of St. Louis, Cincinnati Playhouse in the Park, The Old Globe, Signature Theatre), JOURNEY TO THE WEST (New York Musical Theater Festival), THE PARENTING PROJECT (Cincinnati Fringe Festival, Ensemble Theatre of Cincinnati), THE SANDMAN (NAMT Festival of New Works, Fredericia Theatre in Denmark), and their TONY Award winning musical BANDSTAND. Their newest musical, BRUCE, will premiere in a co-production with The Seattle Repertory Theatre and The Paper Mill Playhouse in the upcoming theatre season. A principal player with the New York Chamber Soloists Ensemble and the Mozart Orchestra of New York, Mr. Taylor is a member of the Dramatist's Guild, and leads Birding & Nature Tours around the world for the Audubon Society.

His love of music, languages, literature, and nature has led him to a lifetime of study and travel. A graduate of Holland’s Royal Conservatory, Union College, the University of Bonn, and Princeton University, he has taught foreign languages and ornithology in New York, English and music in China, served as music critic to the Albany Times Union, worked as a freelance musician and writer in Manhattan, a translator in Europe and Asia, and has lectured extensively on opera, literature, and art history. Mr. Taylor is the co-lyricist/librettist with Richard Oberacker of several new musicals, including ACE, (National Alliance for Musical Theater New Works Festival, The Repertory Theatre of St. Louis, Cincinnati Playhouse in the Park, The Old Globe, Signature Theatre), JOURNEY TO THE WEST (New York Musical Theater Festival), THE PARENTING PROJECT (Cincinnati Fringe Festival, Ensemble Theatre of Cincinnati), THE SANDMAN (NAMT Festival of New Works, Fredericia Theatre in Denmark), and their TONY Award winning musical BANDSTAND. Their newest musical, BRUCE, will premiere in a co-production with The Seattle Repertory Theatre and The Paper Mill Playhouse in the upcoming theatre season. A principal player with the New York Chamber Soloists Ensemble and the Mozart Orchestra of New York, Mr. Taylor is a member of the Dramatist's Guild, and leads Birding & Nature Tours around the world for the Audubon Society.

story:
We are SMC (Shakespeare's Motley Crew), a not for profit Chicago theatre company that has been telling Shakespeare stories since 1992.  Since 2013, we’ve been performing Midsummer Mayhem - Shakespeare shorts - in Winnemac Park in Ravenswood.   We are family friendly and free to the public. 

This year we are back with a story for 2021:  Sins of the Father.  Sins is not about fathers.  Sins is about what came before, about what we did, about another generation taking up our story, our sins.  Sins of the Father is also - literally - the classical canon.

Here is the plan:

  • 45 minutes of Shakespeare.
  • 5 summer (-ish) weekends:  August 21 - September 19. 
  • Winnemac Park in Chicago:  trees, stars, sins.
  • 10 actors, 1 director, 1 costumer, 1 sound designer and 1 fight director.
  • FREE FREE FREE

 

Here is where the money goes:

  • $1000 for actors
  • $800 for insurance
  • $200 for props / sound
  • $500 for rehearsal space (and trying to help St. Matthias...)

 

Here is our website and some of the things we have done since 1992:

www.smcplays.org

Here are some other things:

  • Come to the show!
  • Tell people about us!
  • Visit us as smcplays.org
  • Like us on FB (smc plays)
  • Follow us on Twitter (smc plays)

 

Please help with our annual campaign and help keep Midsummer Mayhem (Sins and all) free in the parks!

story:
Help Us Bring This Relevant, Compelling Play

to the Virtual Stage!

During the pandemic, we’ve found a greater need for art that helps us see the reality of life—in an entertaining way that can be easily digested.  That’s our aim with the play Nickel and Dimed.

We are the newly formed ARRT Productions Collective, a group of five long-time theater and entertainment professionals excited and moved to bring to life our first virtual production on July 24th and 25th.  No surprise.  Everyone was affected by the pandemic last year.  Just about everyone’s job was affected.  Or maybe you were one of the millions who lost your job or business.

San Francisco-based playwright Joan Holden adapted Nickel and Dimed from Barbara Ehrenreich’s 2001 bestselling book of the same name. Ehrenreich went undercover to report on what it’s like to live on minimum wage. Her story drives home how difficult it can be depending on your race, age, gender, and education, among other factors, to make ends meet.

 

What We Need & What You Get

In our effort to put on this play, we feel our purpose and calling is to give back to our community beyond our production.  We’ll give a portion of all donations to a nonprofit that supports increasing the minimum wage as well as to tickets for those who are unable to afford them.  We want to help change our current, painful economic reality from one of suffering to one of thriving.

We ask you, our community, to help us raise $3000 to support our production.  The more we raise, the more we’ll be able to help our cause.

When you give, on top of the satisfaction of knowing you are helping to put on a meaningful production, we’re excited to share the following offers!

  • Get listed as a Founding Supporter in our online program when you contribute $10 or more!
  • Get a free ticket to a future ARRT production when you contribute $20 or more!
  • Get a raffle ticket toward an autographed copy of the play when you contribute $25 or more!
  • Attend a post-show digital happy hour with the cast and crew when you contribute $30 or more!
  • Get a pre-show virtual tour of all of the cities from Nickel and Dimed when you contribute $40 or more!
  • Get a copy of the play autographed by Joan Holden when you contribute $50 or more!

Let us know what you want your contribution to help cover:

$52 licensing fee

$200 royalties

$500 actors and crew pay

$264 host and streaming fees

$300 platform fees

Unknown extras, etc.

Thank you in advance for what you can contribute.

 

Risks & Challenges

There is more to know about putting on a virtual production during the pandemic.  Many of our production team, cast, and crew have greatly limited or put on hold their work as theatres shuttered during the pandemic.  Many lost all or some of not only their livelihoods but also their usual creative outlet.  Suppose we are unable to raise the appropriate funds for the production...In that case, there is a chance we won’t be able to put it on without significant financial hardship.  There are many costs to cover:  the play license, required actors’ union costs, associated streaming costs, etc.

But we are a determined bunch, and we’ve been volunteering countless hours to make this production a reality.

 

Help Us Spread the Word!

Please share information about our production so we can touch as many lives as possible from our play and our charitable contributions.  Share what qualifies you to overcome these hurdles.

And please remember to share on social media and use the Indiegogo share tools!

 

Other Fun Facts About Our Production

San Francisco’s award-winning playwright Joan Holden had the privilege of adapting this book into a stage play in 2002, bringing Ehrenreich’s characters and experiences alive for audiences.  ARRT Productions Collective is thrilled to be working directly with Joan on a staged reading of this play.  This reading will include her newly written, never-seen embellishments, updates, and voiceovers.

Our 6-member cast of local union and non-union talent, playing 32 characters, includes actors Amy Turningbrook—our lead, Scott Ragle, Elizabeth Aaron, Pamela Drummer Williams, Tessa Koning-Martinez, and Lexi Barry.  And the new voiceovers will be performed by Cal Shakes own Catherine Castellanos.  Our producer/director is William Diedrick Razo.

story:
Dear parents, family, friends, and sponsors,

This has been an especially difficult year for our young people given the recent pandemic. Missed school events, sports, proms, and other activities that make growing up an enriching experience have practically been on hold for the last year. So challenging, I hear many heart-breaking stories from the young people we work with every day. They and their families seem so grateful and appreciative to be involved in our Summer Arts Performing Arts Program. Along with our partner, "America's Job Centers of California (AJCC)" we currently employ 74 youth workers ages 14-24 who are gaining work readiness skills and experience as they assist in facilitating these important performing arts (musical theater) and technology (filmed in Virtual Reality) projects. Additionally, we are facilitating over 244 learners (2nd to 8th grade) in performing arts education.

Please help us create some positive memories as these participants work their way back to “normal” while engaging in this life-changing summer arts experience. Help us raise funding to cover the show playbill, sets, props, lighting, sound, costumes and make-up (due to covid safety protocol, learners are not permitted to share make-up, some props, or costume items).

Visit one of the following crowdfunding sites to donate and/or become a sponsor today.

All donations are tax deductible through our “Showcase” nonprofit partner “Wisdom to Go Alliance”

 
Visit our crowd funding sites to make donations
 
https://buymeacoffee.com/ceedtv.vr
 
https://www.indiegogo.com/project/preview/f0a9de94
 

Looking Forward,

Dr. Derrick Spiva

Artistic Director

Short Summary

This summer arts program will address the need to provide youth with general career/job training. This collaborative program promotes social and emotional growth and is project-based learning culminating in a festival of public performances. This program utilizes the performing arts as a motivational tool; young people will gain work readiness skills, career planning, and higher education preparation. We will create an experience, leading students into the world of VR and expose them to the world of theater through VR.

What We Need & What You Get

We need to rise about $10,000 to fund the Virtual Reality Filming of this production. Donars will recieve free tickets to the performance as well as recieve credit in our playbill.

The Impact

We will create an experience, leading students into the world of VR and expose them to the world of theater through VR. This training will cover a wide range of Virtual Environments to give students some exposure to the future of this medium and its relationship to theater. By the end of this training participants will:

  • Have a broad understanding of VR (Virtual Reality) and AR (Augmented Reality.
  • A deeper understanding of the different types of Virtual Environments.
  • Students will experience some practical applications for VR/AR and carry on a conversation about the medium.
  • Explore the variety of ways in which VR is affecting theater and the entertainment industry as a whole.
  • Introduction to Animation
  • Work on producing a VR/AR experience for distribution.

Check out our production team at: https://www.theshowcasevenue.com/meet-the-team

Other Ways You Can Help

Help us get the word out!

Like us on facebook!

story:
The year? 1849. The place? A Dingle workhouse! It’s the Irish Potato Famine! There are disguises! Star-crossed lovers! Betrayals! Songs! The Great Hunger takes us on an anachronistic, genre-bending journey through the past and into the present, exploring the different ways we define pain, suffering, and connection.

THE GREAT HUNGER by Kallan Dana. Coming to New York September 2021. 

Help us bring the latest in a series of joyous collaborations between playwright/director duo Kallan Dana and Erica Zippel Schnitzer to in-person audiences this fall. We are elated to finally be able to safely bring this play to the stage, and provide opportunities for many young artists who have been unable to work in live theatre for over a year. 

Like so many emerging artists in our industry - our lives and careers were put on pause during the pandemic. We have missed the joys of being in an artistic community with one another in a shared space. We cannot wait to get back to the breathless first-day of school excitement of the first rehearsal, the deep camaraderie of the late nights of tech, and the singular elation of the moment the crowd starts to hush as the show begins on opening night - but we need your help to get there. 

We're already well on our way - with a successful fundraiser as a part of the Tank's June Pridefest lineup where we were able to share a sneak preview of the show!  

Every dollar raised from this campaign will go directly into the pockets of the ALL-STAR team of collaborators we are assembling to work on this project. 

Including: 

  • A cast of five actors 
  • A Stage Manager 
  • An Intimacy Coordinator
  • A Composer
  • A Musician (did we mention there is live original music?? How cool !)  
  • A Production Designer
  • A Dramaturg
  • A Music Director

We believe in the fair and equitable compensation of all artists - no matter their experience or age.  Too often emerging artists in our field are asked to work for very little payment and we refuse to see and accept this as a "rite of passage." In donating to our campaign you will let our team know that their work and time are valuable, and will be treated as such.

You will also be helping to fuel an ecosystem of young freelancers in the new work development field--a vital branch of the American theatre industry that was hit hard by the inability to produce work without the resources afforded to larger organizations and institutions. 

We LOVE this play and would be so grateful if you played a part in helping us share it with the world. 

A Little Bit More About Who We Are... 

Kallan Dana (Playwright/Producer) (she/her) is a writer and performer originally from Portland, Oregon and now living in Brooklyn. She has worked with Dixon Place, The Tank, The Jam at New Georges, and Permafrost Theatre Collective, and she is a member of the Citadel of Playwrights. Her play, Playdate, was directed in a commissioned workshop production at Dixon Place in September 2019. Her plays can be found on New Play Exchange and her writing has been featured on Culturebot, Broadway Beat, and Fleas on the Dog. In September 2021, she will be a first-year student in the MFA in Writing for the Screen and Stage at Northwestern University.

Erica Zippel Schnitzer (Director/Producer) (she/her) is a Brooklyn-based Director and Theater Maker. Select credits include Open Call (The Shed), A Dozen Dreams (EnGarde Arts) My Teenage Wet Dream by Kallan Dana (The Tank) Playdate by Kallan Dana (Dixon Place), Plastic Bag Store by Robin Frohardt (Pomegranate Arts), What The Constitution Means to Me by Heidi Schreck (NYTW), The Recipe (The Momentary), Black Light by Daniel Alexander Jones (Greenwich House Theater), and Mile Long Opera (The Office Arts). In addition, Erica has worked with a variety of theater companies, production companies, and other major institutions including, New York Theatre Workshop, HERE Arts Center, Two Headed Rep, BRIC Arts Media, New York Musical Festival, Theater For a New City, The New Museum, and the 14th St. YMCA Theater. Erica is a founding member of 3DaysPrior Productions and Four Person Phantom. For upcoming projects and additional credits go to ericaschnitzer.com.

Ruiran Xun (Composer) (she/her) is a Pittsburgh-based collaborative pianist and music director. She is a rising senior at Carnegie Mellon University studying chemistry and computer science, and outside of academics she is actively involved in theatre and other musical endeavors. Ruiran has previously worked with the Pittsburgh Festival Opera (resident artist pianist, assistant music director) and the CMU School of Music (voice lesson and rehearsal pianist). She's currently the assistant conductor for the CMU All-University Orchestra, and continues to serve in various music direction-adjacent roles on productions by Scotch'n'Soda Theatre, CMU's student-led theatre organization. It was actually through a S'n'S production that Ruiran got her first taste of composition, and she's thrilled to continue exploring this arena by working with the creative team of The Great Hunger to bring the show's music to life!

Liv Wilson (Dramaturg) (she/they) is a dramaturg, playwright, librettist, and theatremaker based out of Washington, D.C. Their work has been seen at The Eugene O'Neill Theatre Center, Boise State University, The University of Texas at El Paso, The College of William & Mary and at The Premiere Theatre Playwriting Competition. Liv is the recipient of the Howard Scammon Prize for Drama and the Martin Jurow Theatre Arts Award for artistic excellence. Liv has worked as the dramaturg for Ford's Theatre in Washington, D.C. and for Cadence Theatre Company's Sitelines BLM series as well as freelancing and tackling devised site-specific projects at the historical Wren Building in Williamsburg, VA. Liv received their Bachelor's degree in History from The College of William and Mary in 2021 and is a recent National Theatre Institute alum.

Rebecca Rovezzi (Producer)(she/her)  is an East Coast based Theatre Artist. She graduated from Skidmore College with a Bachelor of Science with Honors in Directing,  and has trained with The SITI Company as a participant in their 2017 Summer Intensive. She has worked on new play development  at Portland Stage, The Portland Fringe Festival, Rorschach Theatre Theatre's  Klecksography, The Manhattan Repertory Theater, and Ruthless Nightingale Theatre Company. Rebecca has also been a reader for The Playwrights Realm,  The Magic in Rough Spaces New Play Lab, and The Clauder Competition. She has spent the last two years at Woolly Mammoth Theatre Company serving most recently as their New Work Associate. rebeccarovezzi.com

Shea Leavis (Associate Director) (they/them) is a Brooklyn-based performer and director. Most recently they have performed with Royal Osiris Karaoke Ensemble in The Art of Luv Part 6: Awesome Grotto! (Abrons Arts Center), in Annie Dorsen’s The Slow Room (Performance Space New York), and in Dylan Guerra’s  Let’s Have A Seance (HERE Arts). Shea worked as Movement Director for the premiere of Playdate by Kallan Dana (Dixon Place). Assistant directing credits include Joe Diebes’s original opera Oyster (dir. Phil Soltanoff), and Who Will Carry the Word by Charlotte Delbo (dir. Rebecca Marzalek-Kelly). They have also worked on productions at Drop Forge & Tool, The Tank, The Flea, The PIT, Mass Live Arts, The Bushwick Starr, and Roulette Intermedium. Shea trained at the Moscow Art Theatre School through the National Theater Institute, and holds a B.S. in Theater from Skidmore College.

All the Ways You Can Help! 

  • Make a contribution! Any amount helps.
  • Share the campaign on your social media platforms and/or via email. Tell people why you’re just as excited about THE GREAT HUNGER as we are. 
  • Follow our journey on Instagram @thegreathungernyc 
  • Join our email list here, to stay in the loop.

Liv has worked as the dramaturg for Ford's Theatre in Washington, D.C. and for Cadence Theatre Company's Sitelines BLM series as well as freelancing and tackling devised site-specific projects at the historical Wren Building in Williamsburg, VA. Liv received their Bachelor's degree in History from The College of William and Mary in 2021 and is a recent National Theatre Institute alum.
Rebecca Rovezzi (Producer)(she/her)  is an East Coast based Theatre Artist. She graduated from Skidmore College with a Bachelor of Science with Honors in Directing,  and has trained with The SITI Company as a participant in their 2017 Summer Intensive. She has worked on new play development  at Portland Stage, The Portland Fringe Festival, Rorschach Theatre Theatre's  Klecksography, The Manhattan Repertory Theater, and Ruthless Nightingale Theatre Company. Rebecca has also been a reader for The Playwrights Realm,  The Magic in Rough Spaces New Play Lab, and The Clauder Competition. She has spent the last two years at Woolly Mammoth Theatre Company serving most recently as their New Work Associate. rebeccarovezzi.com
Shea Leavis (Associate Director) (they/them) is a Brooklyn-based performer and director. Most recently they have performed with Royal Osiris Karaoke Ensemble in The Art of Luv Part 6: Awesome Grotto! (Abrons Arts Center), in Annie Dorsen’s The Slow Room (Performance Space New York), and in Dylan Guerra’s  Let’s Have A Seance (HERE Arts). Shea worked as Movement Director for the premiere of Playdate by Kallan Dana (Dixon Place). Assistant directing credits include Joe Diebes’s original opera Oyster (dir. Phil Soltanoff), and Who Will Carry the Word by Charlotte Delbo (dir. Rebecca Marzalek-Kelly). They have also worked on productions at Drop Forge & Tool, The Tank, The Flea, The PIT, Mass Live Arts, The Bushwick Starr, and Roulette Intermedium. Shea trained at the Moscow Art Theatre School through the National Theater Institute, and holds a B.S. in Theater from Skidmore College.

All the Ways You Can Help! 

Make a contribution! Any amount helps.
Share the campaign on your social media platforms and/or via email. Tell people why you’re just as excited about THE GREAT HUNGER as we are. 
Follow our journey on Instagram @thegreathungernyc 
Join our email list here, to stay in the loop.

story:
Short Summary

Welcome, Home is an original one-act play written and directed by Parker Forest Olson. Welcome, Home explores a family over the course of a decade as they begin, fall apart, and reassemble, all while the spirit of Home enters and exits their lives, acting as a grandmotherly figure driving and nourishing their growth.

What We Need

We are proud to announce that this show will be curated by the 2021 Elgin Fringe Festival. This is a community event that produces minimalist performances, so what we're looking to raise is very small to cover the price of:

  • The Elgin Fringe Festival production fee
  • A small, compactable dining room set
  • The necessary lumber to build eight wooden theater boxes
  • A handful of small props
  • Any costume pieces that the actors don't already have
  • Press material (posters and postcards)

Why This Project Matters to Us

Welcome Home is about the family as a unit, observing the symbols that carry special meaning for many families, whether it's the mismatched linens in the closet or the floral-design plates in the cupboard. Beyond that, this piece ventures to ensure audiences that families are adaptable and have the ability to rebuild and come together through anything life can throw our way.

Other Ways You Can Help

If you don't have the means to help financially, we would highly appreciate a share on any social media source. Getting the campaign publicized is the easiest way for us to reach our goal.

story:
A Short Summary

The Off West End theatre scene is the proving ground of the UK's theatrical talent and in 2020 the ravages of the Covid-19 pandemic led to the decision to close the theatre indefinitely. However, in the spring of 2021 the management of The Bridge House pub and Luke Adamson agreed to work to reopen the theatre as a producing house as well as a home for visiting companies.

This is obviously a huge undertaking that will involve a lot of practical adjustments. From buying lights and chairs to being able to support the artistic community with an affordable space to work and be a part of.

What We Need & What You Get

So here's some of things we're going to be spending the initial investment on

  • A professional website. A well presented digital face of the venue that represents the quality of the work we're doing.
  • A sound and lighting rig. A proper theatre needs proper equipment, this will involve mounting weight bearing bars that can support a range of lights and speakers for the space. This could also involve running new electrical wires and cables.
  • Chairs! Quite simply, the audience need somewhere to sit!

In return for your donations you will be offered: 

  • Thanks
  • Discounted or complimentary tickets to a range of shows and opportunities to meet the creative team.
  • Access to exclusive events as part of our launch season that will feature a range of shows from all different aspects of the industry. Traditional theatre, comedy, cabaret, poetry & spoken word, family shows, dance and more!
  • Your name (or someone else's) on the wall of fame. If you'd like to make a donation in honour of someone who loves the arts then you can have a name feature on the walls or chairs of the theatre. 

The Impact

In 2019 arts and culture contributed £10.47 billion to the UK economy, with an estimated 226,000 jobs in the arts industry in 2019. Now more than ever, with the combined pressure of budget cuts and an industry closed due to the pandemic, small companies like ourselves need all the support we can get to help keep the arts alive and local communities engaged with the cultural and economical significance of its work. 

As a small scale fringe venue we hope to be able to actively engage with the local area whilst also being a welcoming home to companies from further afield that want to bring their work to us.

Every penny you're able to contribute will help to bring this idea to life!

Risks & Challenges

Obviously the arts and entertainment industries are volatile ones, and like with any new business there will be risks. There may be unforeseen technical difficulties, there might be another global pandemic or the audience might just not be interested!

However, as a team; Artistic Director, Luke Adamson and Associate Director, Joseph Lindoe, have worked together for many years and have a combined experience spanning multiple decades in the industry. The success of their previous shows as JLA Productions shows their commitment to a sustainable business model. We know when we're biting off more than we can chew and how to grow a programme bit by bit, ensuring there is always the time and resources available to give whatever the current project is as much attention as it deserves.

We know what it's like to produce theatre and visit a venue as well, one of our aims is to offer a space that is as risk free as possible to incoming companies, with smaller guarantees on box office splits and lower hire fees, as well as a holistic approach to the marketing and creative support. The last thing you want is someone who just takes your money and says "here's your space".

Other Ways You Can Help

Money is tight right now, we know but that doesn't mean you can't still help out:

  • Tell your friends! Know someone who loves theatre, or who would like to see more, then shout about it.
    • You can find us on Twitter, Facebook & Instagram @PengeTheatre
    • If you have any questions or just want to say hello you can email us admin@thebridgehousetheatre.co.uk
  • Do you know someone in the local area who might be able to help out?
    Electricians, Printers/Publishers for posters and programmes, Marketing professionals. If they could offer their services at a reduced rate or in-kind, in return for adverts online and in programmes. Are you a business based in SE20 or nearby that would like to support in other ways? Then email sponsorship@thebridgehousetheatre.co.uk
  • Don't forget you can also share this Indiegogo campaign on your own social feeds!
