story:
(the text in English - below)

Apie projektą

Esame trijų žmonių komanda: Arnas Stučinskas, Evelina Brėdikytė, Sigita Pikturnaitė. Iki ateinančio rudens norime įrengti naują kamerinį teatrą (kūrybinę studiją) Vilniaus miesto centre, kuriame kiekvieną dieną vyktų spektakliai, koncertai, teatriniai užsiėmimai vaikams, studentams, šeimoms. Radome tinkamas patalpas nuomai, su interjeristu sukūrėme patalpų multifunkcinės erdvės koncepciją (vizualizacijos aprašymo apačioje), turime tam tikrą dalį įrangos, veiklos planą visiems ateinantiems metams ir verslo planą.

Projekto įdėją plėtojame metus, esame investavę daug savo laiko ir jėgų. Tikime tuo, ką darome. Esame ištyrę rinką ir žinome, kad tai reikalinga Vilniaus miestui, nes 1) turime žymiai daugiau aktorių ir trupių nei vietų jiems save parodyti, 2) realizuosime trūkstamus veiklos modelius šioje industrijoje, 3) įkursime kultūrinio bendradarbiavimo, mentorystės ir filantropijos programas, padėsiančias jauniems kūrėjams realizuoti savo idėjas ir kt.


Finansinė dalis

Savo jėgomis surinksime lėšas ir investuosime į patalpų įrengimą (10241 eurą) ir kitas projekto pradžiai būtinas išlaidas. Tačiau tokio pobūdžio veiklai rasti lėšų yra itin sunku, nes, pavyzdžiui, bankai ir kredito unijos neskolina dėl rizikos, privatūs investuotojai domisi tik globaliais interneriniais projektais. Dėl šios priežasties nusprendėme ieškoti žmonių pagalbos vienai projekto sudedamajai daliai – šviesų ir garso įrangos įsigijimui. Ši sritis pasirinkda dėl to, kad tai įsigyti galime paskiausiai, todėl turime laiko lėšų rinkimui. 5078 eurų suma pasirinkta remiantis pasiūlymais, gautais iš įmonių ir yra lygiai tiek, kiek reikia būtinos įrangos pasirodymams įsigyti.

Jeigu šioje platformoje mums nepavyks surinkti pilnos sumos įrangos įsigyjimui, tuomet trūkstamai daliai rasti per kitus šaltinius turėsime dar mėnesį su puse - iki mūsų pirmųjų pasirodymų.

Mokėjimą galima atlikti ir banko kortele (per PayPal, bet neprisijungus į pačią PayPal sistemą).

Finansavimo intrukcija: http://www.houseofpuglu.com/#instruction


Ką gaunate Jūs?

1. Jums bus skirta vieta mūsų tinklalapio houseofpuglu.com garbės puslapyje :)

2. Iki gruodžio mėnesio pabaigos padarysime mažiausiai penkių pasirodymų vaizdo įrašus ir patalpinsime juos internete. Visiems prisidėjusiems prie mūsų projekto bent 10 eurų išsiųsime unikalius kodus, su kuriais galėsite žiūrėti mūsų įrašus.

3. Tiems, kurie prisidės 15 ar daugiau eurų - padovanosim kvietimą į spektaklį arba koncertą. Asmeniškai suderinsim tinkamą laiką.

4. Jeigu paremsite 99 ar daugiau eurų - užrašysime Jūsų vardą ant vienos iš teatro kėdžių!

Iššūkiai, stiprybės

Turime profesionalios, ilgametės patirties renginių organizavime, vaidyboje, režisūroje, kultūros vadyboje, viešinime. Esame dirbe teatro trupėse, renginių organizavimo įmonėse, kūrybinėse / web studijose. Evelina yra baigusi vaidybos studijas ir turi magistro laipsnį, kartu su Arnu įkūrė projektą mimai.lt, Sigutė – baigusi menotyros ir vaidybos studijas, turi du magistro laipsnius.

Šio projekto realizavimui turime daug reikalingų kompetencijų, tačiau susiduriame ir su tokiomis problemomis, kurias vieniems įveikti būtų sunku. Esame labai dėkingi savo draugams, kurie mums stipriai padeda teisiniais klausimais, darant rinkodaros ir strategijos sprendimus ir kt. Turime daug palaikymo ir daug būsimų patrnerių tolimesnėje projekto eigoje.

Taip pat turime daug patirties informacinių technologijų srityje. Arnas sėkmingai kuria reprezentacines svetaines ir sudėtingesnes internetines sistemas. Tai didelis koziris projekto viešinime ir įvaizdžio kūrime, padedantis ne tik sutaupyti, bet ir rasti šaltinių papildomoms pajamoms projektui įgyvendinti.


Kiti būdai prisidėti

Jeigu norite, bet negalite finansiškai prisidėti prie mūsų projekto, tuomet mums labai pagelbėtų, jeigu pasidalintimėt apie tai su savo pažįstamais - socialiniuose tinkluose, elektroniniu paštu etc.


-----------------------------------------------


About the project

Our team consists of three people: Arnas Stučinskas, Evelina Brėdikytė, Sigita Pikturnaitė. By next autumn we want to open a new chamber theatre (artistic studio) in the center of Vilnius, in which every day would be held performances, concerts, theatrical activities for children, students and families. We have found suitable premises for rent, with an interior decorator have created a concept of multifunctional space (description of visualization is below), we have certain part of equipment, an activity plan for the whole coming year, and a business plan.

Project idea is developed by us through the year, we have invested much our time and energy. We believe in what we do. We researched the market and we know that it is necessary for the city of Vilnius, because 1) we have much more actors and troupes than places for them to show themselves, 2) we realize the missing activity models in the industry, 3) we will establish cultural cooperation, mentoring and philanthropic programs, which will help young developers to realize their ideas, and etc.


Financial part

With our own strength we will collect funds and invest in the installation of premises (10241 EUR) and other expenses necessary for the beginning of the project. However, to find the funds for this type of activity is particularly difficult, because, for example, banks and credit unions do not lend money because of risk; private investors are only interested in global internet projects. For this reason, we decided look for a help of people for one component of the project – acquisition of lighting and audio equipment. This component has been chosen due to the fact that it will be purchased last, so we have time to collect money. The sum of 5078 EUR was chosen on basis of the proposals received from companies and it is exactly to the extent necessary to acquire the equipment required for performances.

If in this platform we will fail to collect a full amount for purchase of the equipment, then to find the missing part through other sources we will have a month and a half – until our first performances.

For the people who contributed we will try to pay back with our services, such as tickets to events.


What you get?

1. We will create a page "Board of honor" in our website houseofpuglu.com to thank all who contributed. You will be there, too :)

2. We will make at least five videos of appearances (mime, dance performances etc.) and will put them online until end of December. For all who will support us with at least 10 euros we will send unique access codes to watch our videos.

3. For all who will support us with at least 99 euros we will print their names on the chairs in the theatre to thank for your generous contribution.

4. For all who will support us with at least 15 we will send a ticket to the performance or a concert. We will personally coordinate the time that would be right for You. 


Challenges, strengths

We have a professional, long-lived experience in organization of events, acting, directing, cultural management, publicity. We worked in theatre troupes, event organization in companies, creative/web studios. Evelina graduated acting studies and has a master’s degree, together with Arnas established a project mimai.lt, Sigutė graduated studies of art and acting, has two master’s degrees.

For realization of this project we have many required competencies, but we face with such problems, which will be hardly overcome by us alone. We are very grateful to our friends who assist us greatly in legal issues, marketing and strategy making decisions, and etc. We have much support and many future partners in further course of the project.

We also have much experience in the field of information technology. Arnas successfully creates representative websites and complex internet systems. This is a great trump for the project’s publicity and image creation, which helps not only to save, but also to find sources for additional income for the project’s implementation.


Other ways to contribute

If you want, but you cannot contribute financially to our project, then we would be greatly aided if you share about it with the people you know from social networks, by e-mail, carrier pigeons, and etc.

story: Tengo la oportunidad de viajar a los Estados Unidos para realizar mi  primer proyecto de Danza. Estaré allí desde el 16 de abril, hasta el 23 de junio. El proyecto se trata de poder crear una recopilación de videos, en donde la Danza, recorra las calles de distintas cuidades. Necesito de tu ayuda para los gastos del viaje y para el hospedaje. En esos dos meses podré conocer distintas ciudades para filmar mi danza, y compartir mi arte. Muchas gracias de corazón a los que puedan colaborar con este sueño.

El proyecto se trata de poder crear una recopilación de videos, en donde la Danza, recorra las calles de distintas cuidades. Necesito de tu ayuda para los gastos del viaje y para el hospedaje. story:
Thanks to Black Cat Harriet for her original song accompanying our trailer.

Check out our gallery to view our first promotional video, featuring a quote from Ariana Reines in her essay on Francesca Woodman, as well as an informational video on AS220. 

Who We Are 

She Is A Problem began over a year ago as an investigation into why, as a society, we are more comfortable with dead female artists than living female artists? 

Six fellow female artists came together with the intent of creating an original work focusing on the lives, bodies of work, and suicides of Francesca Woodman, Sylvia Plath, Anne Sexton, Diane Arbus, and Kay Sage. What resulted was She Is A Problem, an immersive art gallery and performance piece that illuminates both the beauty in their art and the darkness surrounding their deaths. It also asks who are these women when liberated from an idealized Western suicidal facade? The show ran at Vox Populi in Philadelphia, PA during the Fringe/Fringe festival August 28-30. 

Another result was an overwhelming response from the community in terms of their presence at our piece, artistic contribution to our digital Zine and set, and the pursuing dialogue that continued after closing. We now also have an Interview Series with female artists in the community and only plan for the project to continue growing. Huge thanks to everyone who donated to our first campaign! Without you, this would have never taken flight. 

We have now been asked to perform this piece at AS220 in Providence, Rhode Island from June 2-4. The opportunity to share this piece with more of the country is both humbling and thrilling. We would love to take this show on the road, but we need your help! 

How You Can Help 

We are requesting funding for:

  • Props
  • Costumes
  • Set pieces 
  • Transportation of show to and from Providence
  • Accomodations in Providence
  • Advertising Materials & Web Marketing

Performance Dates:

06/02: Opening Night at 7pm

06/03: Performance at 7pm

06/04: Performances at 7pm & 10pm

Find Us On:

Website: sheisaproblem.com

Facebook: Sheisaproblem

Other Ways You Can Help 

Can't spare some change? We can always use more art! If you're interested in contributing to our Zine or donating a portrait of one of artists to the gallery, shoot us an e-mail at  sheisaproblemproject@gmail.com

The She Is A Problem Collective

Emily Alexander || aspires to be more problematic in the future; this piece is just the beginning of her journey to finding her voice. She makes theater because when you move others, you create waves. She wants to create theatrical experiences that push boundaries—of what we think bodies can do, of what we think narrative can do, of what we think theater can do. She is so grateful for working with this amazing ensemble of women and can’t wait to see where life takes her next.

Nia Benjamin || is an emerging Philadelphia theatre artist currently pursuing her BFA Acting degree from the University of the Arts. She devotes her spare time to things that make her happy, especially crushing the patriarchy. She is honored to be among this innovative group of lady theatre warriors. 

Kahla Brown || is an artist struggling with the place and value of art in a world torn up by ignorance and oppression. She believes the greatest hope for women lies in the formation of communities and disinterest in competition. She believes the greatest way to solve problems is to ask questions. She hopes you arrive at She Is A Problem with a lot of questions, and leave with even more.

Rebecca Buckley || is a movement based performer, a writer, and an artist in search of change. She devises to shed light not only on tragedies, but victories as well. In 2014, Rebecca graduated from University of the Arts with a BFA in Acting. She is a Problem is Rebecca’s fourth devised show she has had the special privilege to be part of creating.

Gracie Martin || is an actor, singer, writer and explorative artist. Devised theatre came into her life in a big way when trying to wrap her mind around the fraught and frustrating progression of human rights in Russia. Gracie believes not only in revolt against forces that harm women, but in positive, creative endeavors that celebrate what feminists throughout history have fought for, while also asking audiences explore and discover their own path to a more equal society.

Amy Harper || is a designer, writer, illustrator, and educator. She is a compulsive creator and believes in spreading ideas like dandelion seeds in the hopes that if a hundred and one are thrown at least a few will bloom. Amy believes in seeking out and recording both the whimsical magic of our world along with its dysfunctional cruelty. 

All artist portraits by Amy Harper 

See our full bios and more of our mission at Sheisaproblem.com
story_txt:
Thanks to Black Cat Harriet for her original song accompanying our trailer.
Check out our gallery to view our first promotional video, featuring a quote from Ariana Reines in her essay on Francesca Woodman, as well as an informational video on AS220. 





Who We Are  She Is A Problem began over a year ago as an investigation into why, as a society, we are more comfortable with dead female artists than living female artists? 
Six fellow female artists came together with the intent of creating an original work focusing on the lives, bodies of work, and suicides of Francesca Woodman, Sylvia Plath, Anne Sexton, Diane Arbus, and Kay Sage. What resulted was She Is A Problem, an immersive art gallery and performance piece that illuminates both the beauty in their art and the darkness surrounding their deaths. It also asks who are these women when liberated from an idealized Western suicidal facade? The show ran at Vox Populi in Philadelphia, PA during the Fringe/Fringe festival August 28-30. 
Another result was an overwhelming response from the community in terms of their presence at our piece, artistic contribution to our digital Zine and set, and the pursuing dialogue that continued after closing. We now also have an Interview Series with female artists in the community and only plan for the project to continue growing. Huge thanks to everyone who donated to our first campaign! Without you, this would have never taken flight. 
We have now been asked to perform this piece at AS220 in Providence, Rhode Island from June 2-4. The opportunity to share this piece with more of the country is both humbling and thrilling. We would love to take this show on the road, but we need your help!    How You Can Help  We are requesting funding for:  Props
Costumes Set pieces 
Transportation of show to and from Providence
Accomodations in Providence
Advertising Materials & Web Marketing


Performance Dates:
06/02: Opening Night at 7pm
06/03: Performance at 7pm
06/04: Performances at 7pm & 10pm

story:
Our passion and enthusiasm for the art of BALLET is our driving force!

Our inspiration comes from our love for CHILDREN!

Athens Children’s Ballet is a non-profit organization founded in 2013, amid the difficulties of the Greek economy.  We were willing to take the risk, however, as we believe that Art has a healing power and is the noblest reaction in times of crisis.

We aspire to motivate our youngsters and encourage them to set higher goals, to be creative, to enrich their artistic expression. To form the group we audition young dancers (10-22 years old), from all over Greece, and those selected are rigorously trained and prepared by highly skilled professionals to participate in a classic repertoire ballet performance.

“Snow white” (2013) and “Cinderella” (2014) are our two productions up to now, attended by more than 3.000 spectators, who are eagerly awaiting  our next production, “Beauty and the Beast” , to be staged in Athens on November 28th and 29th, 2015.

Why we need your support

Athens Children’s Ballet is an initiative taken by dancers and teachers of classical ballet with years of experience and profound knowledge of the subject. It is an independent operator not financed by any public or private organization. Ticket sales are its only source of revenue. Your support will enable us to continue our mission as well as our social work.

It should be noted that our scope is not limited to the ballet productions. We are concerned with the further development and career opportunities for our children. Thus, every year, our most talented dancers are rewarded with scholarships to attend courses at professional dance schools in Europe. Moreover a significant number of complimentary tickets for our performances are offered to people in need –especially children, who enjoy it tremendously. We also visit various institutions, e.g. orphanages, to give small performances for free.

Our yearly productions are choreographed by professional choreographers, who join us from abroad.  Teaching, training, rehearsals take countless hours of hard work. Costumes, fittings, stage sets are of the finest quality. To keep these high standards expenses are always exceeding revenue.

Consequently your contribution will help us:

To offer two scholarships to our best students

To cover the expenses of the production (costumes, scenery, etc)

To pay the fees and temporary accommodation of the choreographer

If financial support is not an option please share with friends and ask them to promote our vision and efforts.

Thanking you in advance

The Athens Children’s Ballet Team 


Το πάθος και ο ενθουσιασμός μας για το μπαλέτο αποτελούν την κινητήρια δύναμή μας! Η αγάπη μας για τα παιδιά, μάς χαρίζει έμπνευση!

Το Athens Children’s Ballet είναι μια μη κερδοσκοπική νεανική ομάδα μπαλέτου. Δημιουργήθηκε στην Ελλάδα το 2013, σε μια δύσκολη για τον τόπο μας περίοδο, με την πεποίθηση ότι η Τέχνη έχει δύναμη και αποτελεί την πιο ευγενική απάντηση στους καιρούς της κρίσης. Στόχος μας είναι, οι μικροί χορευτές να καλλιεργούν υψηλούς στόχους, τη δημιουργικότητα και την καλλιτεχνική τους έκφραση.

Παρουσιάζουμε γνωστά έργα κλασικού ρεπερτορίου σε δύο πράξεις, δίνοντας  την ευκαιρία σε νεαρούς χορευτές (10 – 22 ετών) από όλη την Ελλάδα, που επιλέγονται με audition, να αποκτούν εμπειρία και γνώση μέσα από την προετοιμασία μιας παράστασης με επαγγελματικές προδιαγραφές και απαιτήσεις.

Μέχρι σήμερα, το Athens Children’s Ballet έχει παρουσιάσει τα έργα Η Χιονάτη και οι 7 Νάνοι (2013) και Η Σταχτοπούτα (2014), που έχουν παρακολουθήσει περισσότεροι από 3.000 θεατές.

Έχοντας ήδη δημιουργήσει ένα θεσμό με το έργο μας και με πολύ καλή αποδοχή από το ελληνικό κοινό, ετοιμάζουμε φέτος τη νέα μας παραγωγή, το μπαλέτο η «Πεντάμορφη & το Τέρας», που θα παρουσιαστεί στην Αθήνα στις 28 και 29 Νοεμβρίου 2015.

Γιατί να μας στηρίξετε

Το Athens Children’s Ballet έχει ξεκινήσει από ιδιωτική πρωτοβουλία, από ανθρώπους που έχουν μακρόχρονη γνώση και εμπειρία ως χορευτές και δάσκαλοι κλασικού χορού. Είναι ανεξάρτητος φορέας και δεν χρηματοδοτείται από κανένα δημόσιο ή άλλο ιδιωτικό φορέα. Τα έσοδά του προέρχονται αποκλειστικά και μόνο από τις πωλήσεις των εισιτηρίων του. Η ενίσχυσή σας μας βοηθά να συνεχίσουμε την προσπάθειά μας, αλλά και το κοινωνικό μας έργο.

Γιατί το έργο του Athens Children’s Ballet δεν περιορίζεται μόνο στις παραστάσεις. Κάθε χρόνο επιβραβεύει τους πιο ταλαντούχους νεαρούς χορευτές προσφέροντας τους υποτροφίες για φοίτηση σε επαγγελματικές σχολές χορού της Ευρώπης.

Διαθέτει δωρεάν ένα μεγάλο μέρος των εισιτηρίων του σε ασθενέστερες οικονομικά ομάδες και κυρίως παιδιά, για να παρακολουθούν τις παραστάσεις του.

Επισκέπτεται κοινωνικά ιδρύματα δωρεάν δίνοντας μικρές παραστάσεις.

Οι παραγωγές που οργανώνει κάθε χρόνο, χορογραφούνται από προσκεκλημένους ξένους χορογράφους και εκτελούνται με υψηλή ποιότητα τόσο στα κοστούμια και τα σκηνικά, όσο και σε επίπεδο χοροδιδασκαλίας. Για να κρατήσουμε αυτή την ποιότητα στο έργο μας, κάθε χρόνο τα έξοδά μας υπερβαίνουν τα έσοδά μας.

Η δική σας συνεισφορά, θα μας βοηθήσει:

·  να στηρίξουμε με υποτροφίες δύο από τους πιο ταλαντούχους χορευτές μας

·  να πληρώσουμε τα έξοδα της παραγωγής (σκηνικά, κοστούμια, κλπ)

·  να καλύψουμε την αμοιβή και τη διαμονή της προσκεκλημένης χορογράφου

 Aν πάλι δεν μπορείτε να μας ενισχύσετε οικονομικά, μοιραστείτε με τους φίλους σας την προσπάθειά μας.

Σας ευχαριστούμε εκ των προτέρων!

Η ομάδα του Athens Children's Ballet

story:
Join the ¡FLACC! familia as we grow! 

Festival of Latin American Contemporary Choreographers 

welcomes you. 

(Ver final de la pagina para leer en Español)

FACT: 

¡FLACC! is the ONLY annual festival on the West Coast celebrating the artistry of Chican@/Latin@ Contemporary Dance Choreographers! 

Whaaaat? 

¡Sí, es verdad! 

And it's here in the San Francisco Bay Area! 


El Festival Latinoamericano de coreógrafos contemporáneos les da la bienvenida.


Your donation is bringing visibility, accessibility and inclusion to underserved Latin@ choreographers and communities.


Imagine September 25, 26 & 27, 2015 at the Mission Cultural Center Theater packed to capacity with 150 people each night and an inspired audience buzzing with excitement to see 7 outstanding local Chican@/Latin@ choreographers making high level dance theater production. 

It is our 2nd year and we are quickly growing. Our goal is to triple our audience size from last year within a larger venue and include our fantastic teaching series this year.  We just need you!  ¡Te necesitamos!  

Our artists, dance teachers, administrators and presenters are committed to making contemporary dance performance and practice accessible to under-represented Latin@ communities and beyond. 

Your donation will directly support this vision and help us reach our goal this September 2015 event.


 


With the Partnerships of the Piñata Dance Collective, Mission Cultural Center for Latino Arts and the Center for Art and Social Justice at CIIS, 


We are producing: 

1) 3 Evenings of cutting-edge dance featuring 7 local Bay Area choreographers Sept. 25-27 @MCCLA (Pre-sale tickets $17 before Sept. 1)

2) Low-cost* ¡FLACC! FRIDAYS Teaching Series. Every Friday, twice a day in September @ MCCLA with Bay Area dance educators. *Scholarships are available. See teachers and class descriptions here!  

3) FREE ¡FLACC! Panel Discussion at California Institute of Integral Studies. Sept 19, @6pm. Join event page here

www.flaccdanza.org

¡FLACC! Mission Statement

¡FLACC! supports emerging and established Dance Artists of the Latin@ Diaspora who are choosing to make dances of the non-traditional, border-crossing, rule-breaking, cutting-edge, queer, avant-garde, contemporary, curious, experimental, abstract, sensitive, hybridized, neo-classical, or revolutionary varieties.  For our purposes, choreographers with “Latin American” cultural heritage or ancestry are defined by all countries that speak Spanish, Portuguese, or Indigenous languages in the Americas- from the Borderlands of the US to the tip of South America, including the Caribbean Islands.  Indigenous contemporary choreographers of North America and all US-born Chican@s and Latin@s are also invited to apply to this Festival.

¡FLACC! celebrates our heritage, our inclusive identities and our artistic innovations through multi-media contemporary dance performance.  We are committed to making contemporary dance practice and performance accessible to underserved Latin@ communities and to creating a platform of connection in the dance community locally and internationally.   See www.flaccdanza.org

Photo: Marisa Aragona/David Herrera Performance Company

Your support brings social change

Inclusión: We aim to create a welcoming space for audiences and artists to deeply engage with unique Latin@ perspectives crossing barriers related to race, place, class, ability, gender and sexual identity. ¡FLACC! is also committed to giving our greater community of Latino@s more access and exposure to contemporary modern and experimental dance forms by offering low-cost dance classes, a free panel discussion with the artists and placing our work on a stage that specifically houses Latin@ artists.

Voces Internacionales:  Director, Liz Duran Boubion, is currently working to foster a bridge with contemporary dance artists in Mexico and seeks to invite choreographers from other countries and states as we grow.  ¡FLACC!  allows us to share our experience and innovation globally with each other as immigrants, locals, mixed-race Latin@'s and international artists within the dance community. 

La Raza/Meeting each other: Our sustainability depends on our collaborations with each other and we are rapidly creating a recognizable platform for Latin@ choreographers to meet one another under one roof.  Our cultural identities can often become insignificant within the contemporary dance world. ¡FLACC! puts cultural perspective at the center by supporting Latin@ choreographers.  To date, the emotional response of ¡FLACC! audiences and the power of our connection to each other is immense.  ¡FLACC! allows us to share ideas and experiences with one another, claim our diverse identities and find out who's out there. 

photo: Melissa Aldape/ Juan Manuel Aldape

Who we are: 

* 7 Coreógrafos en Movimiento:

Davalos Dance Company, Rogelio Lopez and Dancers, Zari Le'On Dance Theater, Juan Aldape, David Herrera Performance Company, Detour Dance, Piñata Dance Collective.

* 7 ¡FLACC! Friday Teachers:

Arturo Fernandez, Emmeline Gonzalez-Beban, Diana Lara, CatherineMarie Davalos, Zari Le'On, Liz Duran Boubion, Rogelio Lopez

* ¡FLACC! Organizers:

  1. Artistic/Managing Director,  Executive Director, Fundraiser, Administrator, Website maker, grant writer, web designer, publicity, you get the picture...el pulpo, Liz Duran Boubion 
  2. Social Media Manager: Zari Le'On
  3. Production Manager: Yanina Rivera
  4. Stage Manager/Technical director: Maximilian Urruzmendi
  5. Panel Facilitator: Juan Manuel Aldape
  6. MC/Hostess: Rebeca Sanchez

* Mission Cultural Center organizers 

  1. Event Coordinator: Andreina Maldonado
  2. Media Design: Adrian Arias
  3. Executive Director: Jenni Rodriguez
  4. Lighting/Sound Tech: TBA

*Sponsors: MCCLA, ABD Productions, Zellerbach Family Foundation


The Breakdown:


As a project of The Piñata Dance Collective, ¡FLACC! has been blessed with the generous help and sponsorship of our co-presenters at the Mission Cultural Center for Latino Arts.   They are providing the MCCLA Theater space, tech staff, box office, house manager, PR, MCCLA administrators and more.  However, we still need to raise $8,000 to cover ¡FLACC! artist fees and operating expenses for the festival. 

TOTAL ¡FLACC! EXPENSES: $13,000 

TOTAL ¡FLACC INCOME: $5,000

GRANTS RECEIVED: $2,000 provided by the Zellerbach Family Foundation

¡FLACC! ANTICIPATES 50%  of TICKET SALES: $2,550-$3,800 

¡FLACC! ANTICIPATES Merchandise sales, business ads: $500

WE NEED YOUR SUPPORT to raise $8,000 for artist fees and operating expenses: 

  • Our 7 choreographers (we pay our artists!) ($3500)
  • Our 6 organizers ($4000)
  • 8 ¡FLACC! Friday Dance Teachers ($600)
  • Videographer/editing($450)
  • Photographer ($200)
  • Publicity($300)
  • Promotional materials, printing, mailing and PR design ($350)
  • T-shirts, Piñatas and Posters ($400)
  • Post production costs ($500)
  • Sustaining Organizational development for ¡FLACC! and Piñata Dance Collective / technical equipment, software, artistic development, web development, strategic planning, administration, marketing, community outreach, grant writer ($2000)
  • $700 to 3rd party processing fees.
We are confident that we will raise the funds necessary to make this important work available to our communities and in tripling our audience from last year.
We can do it! ¡Podemos Hacerlo! With your support. Con su apoyo.

 ¡Únete a la familia ¡FLACC!  a medida que crecemos!

 ¡El Festival Latinoamericano de coreógrafos contemporáneos les da la bienvenida!


EL HECHO:

Es el único Festival  de coreógrafos de danza contemporánea  anual de la Costa Oeste celebrando el arte Chican@/Latin@.


Whaaaat?


Yes,  It is truth!

Y es aquí, en la Bahia de San Francisco 


Su donación genera cambios, brindando visibilidad, acceso e  inclusión a los coreógra@s latin@s y a la comunidad que no reciben suficiente valor.


Imagínese 25, 26 y 27 de Septiembre de 2015 en la Misión Cultural Center Theater, un teatro con capacidad para 150 personas lleno todas las noches, con una audiencia zumbando de emoción al ver a  siete excepcionales  coreógrafos chicano - latinos con producciones de danza teatro del más alto nivel.


Este es el 2do año de ¡FLACC! 

¡Estamos creciendo!!! Nuestro objetivo es triplicar nuestra audiencia, por eso este año contamos con un espacio más grande.

¡Sólo te necesitamos para llevarlo a cabo! We just need you!

Nuestros artistas, maestros, administradores y presentadores están comprometidos con el quehacer de danza contemporánea, para que su práctica y espectáculos puedan ser disfrutados por la marginada comunidad latina.


Su donación apoya nuestra misión y nos ayudará a alcanzar nuestra meta en este Septiembre de 2015.



Evento producido con el  apoyo de Piñata Dance Collective, Mission Cultural Center for Latino Arts y el Center for Art and Social Justice at CIIS.


Estamos Produciendo/EVENTOS:

1)  Tres noches de danza de vanguardia con siete coreógrafos del Área  de la Bahía. Sept. 25-27MCCLA (preventa de boletas $ 17 antes del 1 de septiembre)
2)  Económicos ó a bajos costos* ¡FLACC! FRIDAYS Series de aprendizaje ó  Clases. Todos los viernes de Septiembre dos veces al día. @ MCCLA con  Profesores de danza de Bay Area *NOTA.

¡Vea los profesores y la descripción de las clases aqui! 

3)  GRATIS ¡FLACC! Mesa redonda en California Institute of Integral Studies. Sept 19 @ 6pm.


¡Únete a la página del evento aqui


Misión - ¡FLACC!

¡FLACC! apoya artistas – bailarines emergentes y establecidos de la diáspora Latina: Sur y Centro Americana, que  han optado por hacer danza no tradicional, cruzando las fronteras, rompiendo las reglas, siendo vanguardistas, raros ó extraños, contemporáneos, curiosos, experimentales, abstractos, sensibles , híbridos, Neoclásico,  revolucionarios. Para nuestro propósito, los coreógrafos “Latino American@s” que hacen parte del patrimonio cultural se definen por  los países que hablan español, portugués o lenguas indígenas en las Américas: desde las tierras fronterizas de los EE.UU. a la punta de América del Sur, incluyendo las islas del Caribe. Invitamos también a los coreógrafos contemporáneos Indígenas de América del Norte y todos los nacidos en Estados Unidos Chican@s latin@s a participar del Festival.

¡FLACC! celebra nuestro patrimonio cultural,  nuestras identidades inclusivas y nuestras innovaciones artísticas con espectáculos multi-media de  danza contemporánea. Estamos comprometidos a hacer que la danza contemporánea y sus performances estén al alcance de las comunidades Latinas marginadas y a crear una plataforma de conexiones en la comunidad de la danza a nivel nacional e internacional. Ver  www.flaccdanza.org

Foto: Marisa Aragona/David Herrera Performance Company

Su apoyo trae cambio social

Inclusión: Nuestro objetivo es crear un espacio de participación  seguro para el público y los artistas con perspectiva latina eliminando las barreras de raza, lugar, clase social, capacidades, género e inclinación sexual. ¡FLACC! también se ha comprometido a brindarle mayor acceso a nuestra comunidad Latina a las formas de danza moderna y experimental contemporánea, ofreciendo clases de baile a bajo costo, un panel de discusión gratuito con artistas  y a realizar una puesta en escena exclusivamente para artistas latin@s.

Voces Internacionales: Directora, Liz Duran Boubion. Está trabajando para fomentar un puente con artistas de danza contemporánea en México y busca invitar a coreógrafos de otros países y estados en la  medida en que crece el festival. ¡FLACC! nos permite compartir nuestra experiencia y la innovación a nivel mundial entre sí como inmigrantes, locales, mestizos Lati@s  y artistas internacionales dentro de la comunidad de la danza.

La Raza / Reuniéndonos entre sí: Nuestro sostenibilidad depende de la  colaboración de los unos con los otros y estamos creando rápidamente una plataforma reconocible para coreógrafos Latin@s,  para cubrirnos mutuamente bajo el mismo techo. Nuestras identidades culturales a menudo pueden llegar a ser insignificante en el mundo de la danza contemporánea. ¡FLACC! pone perspectiva cultural en el centro apoyando a los coreógraf@s latin@s. A la fecha, la respuesta del público hacia  ¡FLACC! y el poder de nuestra conexión con los demás es gigantesca. ¡FLACC! nos permite compartir ideas y experiencias con otros, reclamar por nuestras diversas identidades y encontrar a quien está ahí afuera.

foto: Melissa Aldape/ Juan Manuel Aldape

Quiénes somos:

* 7 Coreógrafos en Movimiento:

Davalos Dance Company, Rogelio Lopez and Dancers, Zari Le'On Dance Theater, Juan Aldape, David Herrera Performance Company, Detour Dance, Piñata Dance Collective.

* 7 ¡FLACC! Profesores de los viernes:

Arturo Fernandez, Emmeline Gonzalez-Beban, Diana Lara, CatherineMarie Davalos, Zari Le'On, Liz Duran Boubion, Rogelio Lopez.

* ¡FLACC! Organizadores:

  1. Director Artistica/Manager,  Directora Ejecutiva, Recaudadora de Fondos, Administradora, diseñador del web, escritora de proyectos ó subvenciones, Tienes la pintura del pulpo???,  Liz Duran Boubion
  2. Social Media Manager: Zari Le'On
  3. Production Manager: Yanina Rivera
  4. Stage Manager/Technical director: Maximilian Urruzmendi
  5. Panel Facilitator: Juan Manuel Aldape
  6. MC/Hostess: Rebeca Sanchez

* Organizadores Mission Cultural Center

1. Event Coordinator: Andreina Maldonado

2. Media Design: Adrian Arias

3. Executive Director: Jenni Rodriguez

4. Lighting/Sound Tech: TBA

*Sponsors: MCCLA, ABD Productions, Zellerbach Family Foundation

El Desglose:

Como proyecto de La Piñata danza colectiva, ¡FLACC! ha sido bendecido con el apoyo de nuestros anfitriones, Misión Centro Cultural, con algunos de los principales costos del teatro. Sin embargo, todavía tenemos que recaudar $ 8,000 para cubrir  gastos artísticos y de operación.

PRESUPUESTO TOAL DE ¡FLACC: $13,000 

Ingresos total de ¡FLACC!: $5,000

APOYO RECIVIDO: $2,000 de Zellerbach Family Foundation

¡FLACC!ANTICIPA UNA VENTA DE BOLETAS POR VALOR DE: $2,550 -$3,800

¡FLACC! ANTICIPA VENTA DE  MERCHANDISE, Y FINANCIACIÓN DE EMPRESAS POR VALOR DE: $500

NECESITAMOS TU APOYO para recaudar $ 8,000 para los honorarios del artista y gastos de operación: ver abajo

  • 7 choreogr@s (¡pagamos nuestros artistas!) ($3500)
  • 6 organizadores ($4000)
  • Los 8 Profesores de danza ¡FLACC! para los Viernes ($600)
  • Video & edición($450)
  • Fotógrafo ($200)
  • Publicista ($300)
  • Material publicitario, impresos, correo y  diseño PR  ($350)
  • Camisetas, Piñatas y Posters ($400)
  • Costos de post-producción ($500)
  • Sostener el desarrollo artístico y organizacional de ¡FLACC! y Piñata Danza Colectivo:  web, planeación de estrategias, administración, comercializacion, extensión a la comunidad, escritura de subvención y/o proyectos ($ 2000)
  • 3er tarifas de procesamiento del partido

Estamos seguros de que vamos a recaudar los fondos necesarios para realizar este importante trabajo y de que triplicaremos nuestro público.

¡Podemos hacerlo! We can do it! Con su apoyo.

¡El colectivo de Danza Piñata está creando camisetas nuevas para ¡FLACC! Este año, también vamos a vender las camisetas y unas fotos increíbles de nuestros coreógrafos durante el evento de septiembre 25-27. También vamos a regalar fotos e camisetas para los que donen dinero a ¡FLACC!
story_txt:
Join the ¡FLACC! familia as we grow! 

Festival of Latin American Contemporary Choreographers 


welcomes you. 

(Ver final de la pagina para leer en Español)


FACT: 


¡FLACC! is the ONLY annual festival on the West Coast celebrating the artistry of Chican@/Latin@ Contemporary Dance Choreographers! 

Whaaaat? 
¡Sí, es verdad! 

And it's here in the San Francisco Bay Area! 




El Festival Latinoamericano de coreógrafos contemporáneos les da la bienvenida.



Your donation is bringing visibility, accessibility and inclusion to underserved Latin@ choreographers and communities.


Imagine September 25, 26 & 27, 2015 at the Mission Cultural Center Theater packed to capacity with 150 people each night and an inspired audience buzzing with excitement to see 7 outstanding local Chican@/Latin@ choreographers making high level dance theater production. 


It is our 2nd year and we are quickly growing. Our goal is to triple our audience size from last year within a larger venue and include our fantastic teaching series this year.  We just need you!  ¡Te necesitamos!  
Our artists, dance teachers, administrators and presenters are committed to making contemporary dance performance and practice accessible to under-represented Latin@ communities and beyond. 
Your donation will directly support this vision and help us reach our goal this September 2015 event.






 


With the Partnerships of the Piñata Dance Collective, Mission Cultural Center for Latino Arts and the Center for Art and Social Justice at CIIS, 


We are producing: 

1) 3 Evenings of cutting-edge dance featuring 7 local Bay Area choreographers Sept. 25-27 @MCCLA (Pre-sale tickets $17 before Sept. 1)


2) Low-cost* ¡FLACC! FRIDAYS Teaching Series. Every Friday, twice a day in September @ MCCLA with Bay Area dance educators. *Scholarships are available. See teachers and class descriptions here!  


3) FREE ¡FLACC! Panel Discussion at California Institute of Integral Studies. Sept 19, @6pm. Join event page here


www.flaccdanza.org






¡FLACC! Mission Statement
¡FLACC! supports emerging and established Dance Artists of the Latin@ Diaspora who are choosing to make dances of the non-traditional, border-crossing, rule-breaking, cutting-edge, queer, avant-garde, contemporary, curious, experimental, abstract, sensitive, hybridized, neo-classical, or revolutionary varieties.  For our purposes, choreographers with “Latin American” cultural heritage or ancestry are defined by all countries that speak Spanish, Portuguese, or Indigenous languages in the Americas- from the Borderlands of the US to the tip of South America, including the Caribbean Islands.  Indigenous contemporary choreographers of North America and all US-born Chican@s and Latin@s are also invited to apply to this Festival.¡FLACC! celebrates our heritage, our inclusive identities and our artistic innovations through multi-media contemporary dance performance.  We are committed to making contemporary dance practice and performance accessible to underserved Latin@ communities and to creating a platform of connection in the dance community locally and internationally.   See www.flaccdanza.org

Photo: Marisa Aragona/David Herrera Performance Company

Your support brings social change
Inclusión: We aim to create a welcoming space for audiences and artists to deeply engage with unique Latin@ perspectives crossing barriers related to race, place, class, ability, gender and sexual identity. ¡FLACC! is also committed to giving our greater community of Latino@s more access and exposure to contemporary modern and experimental dance forms by offering low-cost dance classes, a free panel discussion with the artists and placing our work on a stage that specifically houses Latin@ artists.
Voces Internacionales:  Director, Liz Duran Boubion, is currently working to foster a bridge with contemporary dance artists in Mexico and seeks to invite choreographers from other countries and states as we grow.  ¡FLACC!  allows us to share our experience and innovation globally with each other as immigrants, locals, mixed-race Latin@'s and international artists within the dance community. 
La Raza/Meeting each other: Our sustainability depends on our collaborations with each other and we are rapidly creating a recognizable platform for Latin@ choreographers to meet one another under one roof.  Our cultural identities can often become insignificant within the contemporary dance world. ¡FLACC! puts cultural perspective at the center by supporting Latin@ choreographers.  To date, the emotional response of ¡FLACC! audiences and the power of our connection to each other is immense.  ¡FLACC! allows us to share ideas and experiences with one another, claim our diverse identities and find out who's out there. 





photo: Melissa Aldape/ Juan Manuel Aldape




Who we are: 

* 7 Coreógrafos en Movimiento:
Davalos Dance Company, Rogelio Lopez and Dancers, Zari Le'On Dance Theater, Juan Aldape, David Herrera Performance Company, Detour Dance, Piñata Dance Collective.
* 7 ¡FLACC! Friday Teachers:
Arturo Fernandez, Emmeline Gonzalez-Beban, Diana Lara, CatherineMarie Davalos, Zari Le'On, Liz Duran Boubion, Rogelio Lopez
* ¡FLACC! Organizers:


Artistic/Managing Director,  Executive Director, Fundraiser, Administrator, Website maker, grant writer, web designer, publicity, you get the picture...el pulpo, Liz Duran Boubion 
Social Media Manager: Zari Le'On
Production Manager: Yanina Rivera
Stage Manager/Technical director: Maximilian Urruzmendi
Panel Facilitator: Juan Manuel Aldape
MC/Hostess: Rebeca Sanchez


* Mission Cultural Center organizers 


Event Coordinator: Andreina Maldonado
Media Design: Adrian Arias
Executive Director: Jenni Rodriguez
Lighting/Sound Tech: TBA

*Sponsors: MCCLA, ABD Productions, Zellerbach Family Foundation

The Breakdown:
As a project of The Piñata Dance Collective, ¡FLACC! has been blessed with the generous help and sponsorship of our co-presenters at the Mission Cultural Center for Latino Arts.   They are providing the MCCLA Theater space, tech staff, box office, house manager, PR, MCCLA administrators and more.  However, we still need to raise $8,000 to cover ¡FLACC! artist fees and operating expenses for the festival. 
TOTAL ¡FLACC! EXPENSES: $13,000 
TOTAL ¡FLACC INCOME: $5,000
GRANTS RECEIVED: $2,000 provided by the Zellerbach Family Foundation

¡FLACC! ANTICIPATES 50%  of TICKET SALES: $2,550-$3,800 
¡FLACC! ANTICIPATES Merchandise sales, business ads: $500
WE NEED YOUR SUPPORT to raise $8,000 for artist fees and operating expenses: 


Our 7 choreographers (we pay our artists!) ($3500)
Our 6 organizers ($4000)
8 ¡FLACC! Friday Dance Teachers ($600)
Videographer/editing($450)
Photographer ($200)
Publicity($300)
Promotional materials, printing, mailing and PR design ($350)
T-shirts, Piñatas and Posters ($400)
Post production costs ($500)
Sustaining Organizational development for ¡FLACC! and Piñata Dance Collective / technical equipment, software, artistic development, web development, strategic planning, administration, marketing, community outreach, grant writer ($2000)
$700 to 3rd party processing fees.

We are confident that we will raise the funds necessary to make this important work available to our communities and in tripling our audience from last year.We can do it! ¡Podemos Hacerlo! With your support. Con su apoyo.

La Raza /
Reuniéndonos entre sí: Nuestro sostenibilidad depende de
la  colaboración de los unos con los
otros y estamos creando rápidamente una plataforma reconocible para coreógrafos
Latin@s,  para cubrirnos mutuamente bajo el
mismo techo. Nuestras identidades culturales a menudo pueden llegar a ser
insignificante en el mundo de la danza contemporánea. ¡FLACC! pone perspectiva
cultural en el centro apoyando a los coreógraf@s latin@s. A la fecha, la
respuesta del público hacia  ¡FLACC! y el
poder de nuestra conexión con los demás es gigantesca. ¡FLACC! nos permite
compartir ideas y experiencias con otros, reclamar por nuestras diversas
identidades y encontrar a quien está ahí afuera.

foto: Melissa Aldape/ Juan Manuel Aldape

somos:

story:
Kinection Dance Project

Fueled by their passion to provoke human connection – choreographers/dancers Cesar Garfiaz and Bianca Blanco have combined their eclectic styles to create an exciting yet thought provoking evening of dance that will have you both dancing in your seats and reflecting on the nuances of your own kinections. Partial proceeds of ticket sales will go to The Coalition for Engaged Education. 


To buy tickets click this link! Eventbrite Link


Who are we?


Cesar Garfiaz was born and raised in Los Angeles, CA. Growing up in a Mexican family full of women that loved to dance, he became the go to partner for all genres that played at parties whether it was Mexican banda music, salsa, merengue or cumbia. He began dancing Salsa at the age of seven, going on Sundays to Steven’s Steakhouse (a famous Salsa spot in Los Angeles). In high he joined a theater class where along with his natural dancing affinity he found a passion that would continue to help him into college. After studying in years of performing arts courses he gained a love for the stage. In 2004 Cesar joined UCLA’s Department of World Arts & Cultures. As a part of UCLA’s Repertory Tour Ensemble, Cesar performed and inspired young people in high schools all over Los Angeles. Through his work with Rep Tour, he became passionate about youth arts education. He studied various styles including modern, hip hop, house, tai chi, Ghanaian, Mexican Folklorico & Afro-Cuban solidifying him as a versatile dancer. During his time at UCLA Cesar began working and collaborating with Ana Maria Alvarez and was a cast member of her original thesis concert “contra-tiempo.” This turned into the Urban Latin Dance Theater Company CONTRA-TIEMPO, a company rooted in Salsa and Afro-Cuban and draws from Hip-Hop, urban and contemporary dance-theater. They created an invigorating blend of physically intense and socially astute performance that pushed the boundaries of Latin dance as an expressive cultural and contemporary form. As a founding company member he invested 10 years in the company collaborating in the creation process, performing, touring world wide, and teaching as the lead teacher on behalf of the company.In 2014 he co-founded Kinection Dance Project which explores the many different human relationships and the different ways we relate to the world using duets and multiple genres as a means of expression. Using partnering as a foundation Cesar hopes to give a new perspective to partnering movement. As a passionate dance educator, Cesar has taught extensively from the studio level to all grade levels in schools to University level both nationally and internationally. As an artist he is passionate about continuing to explore movement in site-specific works in Los Angeles and bringing the idea of dance as an integral part of everyday society out in the streets.

Bianca Blanco is a dancer/choreographer and actress. She is a Venezuelan American, born and raised in Kalamazoo, Michigan. Her fate was decided the moment she stepped in her first ballet class at 10 years old and fell in love with dance. She studied since then focusing on ballet and modern, even going on to pursue a BA in Dance at Western Michigan University after receiving a full scholarship. She studied with many wonderful teachers including Kathleen Hermsdorf, Donald McKayle, and Derrick Evans. During this time she was selected to be in many wonderful works such as Paul Taylor’s Three Epitaphs and was also chosen to be part of an ensemble that performed locally and even internationally in Prague.  In 2002 she moved to Los Angeles where she spent the first many years focusing on studying Latin forms including salsa, cha cha, and pachanga. She performed salsa both on stage and on television/film for many years as well as winning many competitions including Baila mi Baile on Univision’s “Sabado Gigante.”During these years she became an acclaimed salsa dancer and teacher. She has been seen dancing in commercials such as Taco Bell and Coors, Television Show’s such as Luis and Dexter, and movies such as Along Came Polly and Mini’s First time. In 2010 feeling the need to connect back to the classical beginning but not lose the Latin roots, Blanco was selected to be a part of CONTRA-TIEMPO Urban Latin Dance Company. The fusion of modern dance, many Latin forms, many urban forms, and theatre was a perfect fit. Here Blanco toured extensively nationally and internationally as part of a small cast of talented dancers. She was also a teaching artist for CONTRA-TIEMPO and active in the creation process of the works. As a highlight – In 2014, she was part of the cast who toured to South America for a month long tour for Dance Motion as cultural ambassadors for the United States. Currently – Blanco co-founded Kinection Dance Project with partner/co-founder Cesar Garfiaz. Born out of their love and strength for performing and teaching partnering work – Kinection Dance Project explores the human connection both physically and metaphorically. Its concentration is on duets, each showcasing and exploring a different aspect of ever complicated and beautiful relationships. As a movement educator Blanco has created curriculum and taught extensively partnering technique, performance technique, salsa, and modern dance. She has taught in school residencies, choreographed special projects, and taught workshops in schools across the country as well as internationally. She also has a great love for the culinary world and is certified in plant-based nutrition. She teaches cooking classes and gives lectures on the subject of “food be thy medicine.” During her many dance tours the cooking classes and lectures have often been a wonderful holistic addition allowing further connection to the community and body.

What We Need & What You Get

Here's the scoop:

With our grand idea yet modest means, we are looking to our community to help bring this work to life. All donations will go directly to the cost of production including dancer stipends, lighting design, rehearsal space, set/costume design and all the little things in between.

  • $25 contribution gets you a shout out on social media and our deepest gratitude
  • $50 contribution gets you a special thank you in our program, a shout out on social media, and our deepest gratitude
  • $100 contribution gets you a hand written letter from Cesar and Bianca, a special thank you in our program, a shout out on social media, and our deepest gratitude
  • $250 contribution gets you a special Kinection Dance Project tote bag, a hand written letter from Cesar and Bianca, a special thank you in our program, a shout out on social media, and our deepest gratitude
  • $500 contribution gets you 2 comp tickets to the show (LA area only), a private salsa dance lesson (LA area only), a special Kinection Dance Project tote bag, a hand written letter from Cesar and Bianca, a special thank you in our program, a shout out on social media, and our deepest gratitude ($160 value!)
  • $1000 contribution gets you 4 comp tickets to the show (LA area only), 4 private salsa dance lessons (LA area only), a special Kinection Dance Project tote bag, a hand written letter from Cesar and Bianca, a special thank you in our program, a shout out on social media, and our deepest gratitude ($500 value!!)
  • By donating - you are at the forefront of a movement in dance. This show is just the beginning of looking at dance in a new way. 

The Impact

This show is a labor of love and personally means the world to us. We want Los Angeles to continue to experience exciting and thought provoking concert dance. We intend to continue to perform this work both on stage as well as pop up performances in the community to really kinect! Bringing art to the street in an engaging way is just one way we hope to provoke human connection.

We have been doing this type of work for many years but now through our own vision hope to create a specific and meaningful experience for all who witness…including the performers. 

Risks & Challenges

As excited as we are, we are also terrified! It is an exercise in vulnerability putting our ideas on stage - but we are ready to meet that challenge head on. 

  • We are seasoned dancers/choreographers/creators. We have overcome much more and know that this is an awesome place for possibilities and growth. 
  • We are also enlisting the help of fellow artists to give us creative inspiration and support along the way! 

Other Ways You Can Help

Kinect us to your circles!

  • Indiegogo makes it super easy to share our campaign so hit all those buttons and share!
  • Talk about it to your friends!
  • Buy tickets!
  • Send us positive vibes! :)

story:
The Oregon Shakespeare Festival (OSF) and The One-Minute Play Festival (#1MPF) are teaming up to co-produce Every 28 Hours, a national partnership focused on the widely shared and contested statistic that a black person is killed by the police every 28 hours in the United States. The Every 28 Hours plays will consist of 60-plus one-minute plays inspired by the Black Lives Matter movement, with participation by playwrights and across the nation. These funds will supplement some artists housing, travel,and food costs in St. Louis. 

We are still accepting donation by check to "Oregon Shakespeare Festival" and in subject line "Every 28 Hours" mail to OSF, 15 South Pioneer St, Ashland OR, 97520


https://www.facebook.com/Every28HoursPlays/

WHAT?

Created under the leadership of Claudia Alick (OSF’s associate producer, community) and Dominic D’Andrea (producing artistic director, The One-Minute Play Festival), in association with local St. Louis theater maker and producer Jacqueline Thompson (assistant professor of acting and directing, University of Missouri-St. Louis), the first phase of the project includes community meetings, collaborative writing sessions and readings of the plays in St. Louis County, October 20-24, 2015. Readings will be produced Oct. 24 at two locations: the Dellwood Recreation Center in Ferguson, Missouri at 2:00 p.m., and the Kranzberg Arts Center in St. Louis at 8:00 p.m.

WHY?

“The Every 28 Hours Playsis an exciting and necessary project to be doing at this place and time,” D’Andrea said. “The deep injustices that marginalized populations face in this country are staggering—and no place better represents this tension than in Ferguson. As artists we felt it was our responsibility to create an artistic space to respond to questions of race, injustice, and civic responsibility on a local and national platform.”

"Ferguson is the heartbeat of the movement,” Thompson said. “This project is a brilliant creative conduit to share its pulse with the world.”

“We are in a time of change for the U.S.,” Alick said, “and the reflection on this current Civil Rights Movement is exciting because of the power and number of talented voices collaborating. Our project is informed by thoughtful leaders in activism, performance, civic leadership and communications. The work is hard and inspiring and necessary.”

HOW?

Partnering theaters and institutions will send artists and cover their expenses for a week to allow for the writing and rehearsing of the staged readings, though additional funding for the project is being raised through an Indiegogo campaign. The second phase of The Every 28 Hours Plays will include the national partner theaters engaging with these plays in their own communities in October of 2016.

Collaborators include: David Henry Hwang, Lynn Nottage, Luis Alfaro, Robert Schenkkan, Richard Montoya, Ralph Remington, Kristoffer Diaz, Dominique Morisseau, Liza Jesse Peterson, Stew, Rickerby Hinds, Aurin Squire, Idris Goodwin, Jim McManus, Shishir Kurup, Robert Alexander, Zakiyyah Alexander, Larissa FastHorse, Tavia Nyongo, Jacqueline E. Lawton, Gamal Chasten, Josh Wilder, Aaron Jafferis, Jonathan Norton, Lisa Loomer, Migdalia Cruz, Paris Crayton III, Nancy Bell, Mario Farwell, Joan Lipkin, Kelley Webber, Grant Harris, Robert Maesaka, Em Piro, Adam Flores, Carl Overly, Andrea Purnell, Marty Casey, Kathryn Bentley, Trinity Rep, The TEAM, Salvage Vanguard Theatre, Working Theater, Steppenwolf Theatre Company, Voices United, Sojourn Theater, Looking Glass Theater, Urban Theater Movement, Fishtank Performance Studio, Cleveland Public Theater, Guthrie Theater, ACT, The National Black Theater, Cleveland Playhouse, Wooly Mammoth Theater, The Forum Theater, The Flea Theater, Ping Chong Company, Berkeley Repertory Theatre, The Hansberry Project and American Theater Company, Dyalekt (Brian Kushner), The Black Rep, That Uppity Theatre Company, St. Louis Rep Theater, St. Louis Shakespeare Festival, Salt House Collective, Mustard Seed Theatre, the Regional Arts Commission and more. 

Please leave a comment and share even if you cannot give to spread the word about the project. Message us through our Facebook page if you would like participate in our blog or on the theater piece.

and American Theater Company, Dyalekt (Brian Kushner), The Black Rep,
That Uppity Theatre Company, St. Louis Rep Theater, St. Louis Shakespeare
Festival, Salt House Collective, Mustard Seed Theatre, the Regional Arts
Commission and more. 
Please leave a comment and share even if you cannot give to spread the word about the project. Message us through our Facebook page if you would like participate in our blog or on the theater piece.

story:
About the show

"A child suicide bomber in Pakistan, 

a Canadian soldier in Kandahar, an Afghan immigrant in Toronto. Three worlds collide

 in this play about love and loss in the time of war."
 

The Road to Paradise was created in Pakistan, Afghanistan and Canada and features actors from each country. Based on interviews conducted with families of the Canadian Armed Forces, the Pakistan Army, the Afghan National Army,  and the Taliban, The Road to Paradise examines the impact of war on women and children. 

 
This show will also mark the Canadian debut of actress Parwin Mushtael. After years of death threats due to her work as an actress in Afghanistan, she fled to Canada with her family after her husband was murdered at their home in Kabul. The Road to Paradise includes her true story, told by her, in all its rawness.

A Human Cargo production presented by Crow's Theatre in association with  Buddies in Bad Times Theatre, The Road to Paradise is presented in English and Dari with a cast of Canadian, Afghan and Pakistani actors. Surtitles will translate all Dari dialogue into English.
Following the world premiere at Buddies in Bad Times Theatre, the production will be touring to:

Agha Khan Museum – Dec 2, 2015 at 8pm

And to Canadian Forces Base Petawawa on December 5th, 2015 for a special performance for military families.
 


Who are we?

Human Cargo is dedicated to the creation of theatre that explores the extremes of the human condition. It’s our goal to bring new voices to the world stage, offer diverse perspectives of the human condition and celebrate our evolving Canadian identity.

We collaborate with theatre artists and companies in Canada, and around the world, to create our work. We develop our plays over long periods of time, in the countries and communities where the play is set. We then present these multi-lingual productions, with international casts, both in Canada and the plays' countries of origin.

We strive to create innovative, theatrical experiences that will inspire audiences to re-evaluate their personal and global perspectives of the human condition. We provide a safe environment for audiences to engage in a thorough and thought-provoking discussion of ideas. We implement a touring/presentation model that reaches out to a new generation of viewing public and embraces the diverse make-up of our ever-changing society.

The Creative Team

   Christopher Morris - Director & co-playwright

Christopher is a director, actor and playwright residing in Toronto. As Artistic Director of Human Cargo he has collaborated with theatre artists from Nunavut, Iceland, the Republic of Georgia, Israel, Pakistan, Afghanistan and China to create unique, theatrical works. Christopher is the recipient of the prestigious Canada Council for the Arts' 2012 John Hirsch Prize for directing and the 2005 KM Hunter Award for Theatre.


   Jonathan Garfinkel - Co-playwright

 

   Gillian Gallow - Set & Costume Design


   Michelle Ramsay - Lighting Design


  Richard Feren - Composer/Sound Designer


 

Starring

Beau Dixon, Christine Horne, Andrew Lawrie, Cheri Maracle, Samiya Mumtaz, Parwin Mushtael, and Sanjay Talwar
 

           

        


 

Why Contribute?


                              

No debate or public discourse has ever occurred in the House of Commons before, during, or after the "official" end of the war in Afghanistan. The conflict continues, and Canadian Special Forces remain there to this day. In light of the fact that more Canadian veterans of the Afghan war have died by suicide than were killed in combat, there is an appetite growing in Canada to acknowledge the long-term effect this war is having on Canadian soldiers and their families. The majority of the Taliban who fight Canadians in Afghanistan come from Pakistan. The accelerated resettlement of Afghans to Canada - with little resources provided to address the trauma of living through decades of war - can create a toxic blend of isolation and mental illness that foils the hopes of all involved. The Road to Paradise is a triptych of stories that examines the long-reaching consequences of a single act of violence, and exposes the lethal thread that snakes its way through the fabric of households, continents apart. 

Your contribution will help us tell these stories. The funds raised will go towards venue rental, set, costume, props, and the employment of 15 theatre artists from Canada, Pakistan, and Afghanistan. This campaign will also help us bring the show to Canadian Forces Base Petawawa, for a special performance for military families.

Creating The Road to Paradise has been an immense, life-altering experience for all of us. As a creative team, we're striving to make a piece of theatre that is worthy of the profundity that surrounds this play. An ambitious group of theatre artists have been assembled to create a bold and powerful piece of theatre. This is the story of our generation, and it is with dignity, humbleness, and a fierce sense of purpose, that we stage the world premiere of The Road to Paradise.

story:
The Peasants Club is proud to present “You & Me & The Devil Makes Three”.

An exploration of what it is to be a young person in London today. Dealing with mental health, young parenting, sexuality, domestic abuse, and the housing crisis in London.  

The Peasants Club's newest play received outstanding reviews from its London premiere at The Tea House Theatre in August 2014. It has since been redeveloped and reworked into a bold and powerful piece that keeps you on the edge as four friends strain to maintain their relationships while the emotional stakes grow higher and higher until reaching a climax that no one could have predicted.  




This Autumn , The Peasants Club is pushing theatre forward!

Performing for a week at The Bread & Roses Theatre, Clapham, from the 24th-28th November!!

LEWISHAM FRINGE FESTIVAL 21st November- for a 1 night performance.

Our aim is to invite Londons theatre industry to see what we do best at The Peasants Club! Show them how our approach differs to other theatre in the industry today. With aspirations to produce this fantastic play in a larger theatre, thus introducing it to a bigger, wider audience and get non-theatre going folk to see affordable and relatable stories!

We wish to gain experience and develop into a sustainable theatre company that pays it’s actors, directors and technical production team for their hard work and talent!   

London’s West End is full of shows that will put you on a high for an hour or two. You wake up the following morning, though, and you find the theatrical experience hasn’t really changed anything in your life. We set this company up because we wanted to align ourselves with the companies that tell transformative stories.



What We Need & What You Get

•  Rehearsal space. We all know London rent is expensive, but rehersal spaces are extortionate! Being from a Meisner trained background the

rehearsal period is important  part of the prosses. Its the time for actors to play, find those high stakes and push the actors into undiscovered places, so that when showtime comes, they can deliver something powerful.

•  Marketing the play, advertising and print distribution. We need the funds to pay for poster and flyer printing.

  • Transportation.

•  Paying our artists/creative and crew - which we feel is very important!



We are proud to say that we built this company from scratch throwing ourselves into every project, with great results and responses from audiences; however, we just need that extra hand in raising the funds to take this company to the next step!   

Other Ways You Can Help

•  Share! 

•  Like and share this project on Facebook

•  Follow us on Twitter 

•  Stop people in the street and express to them the brilliance of this project!

story:
In April I joined The Power of One, a program designed to lead a team of artists on their journeys to produce and present a cluster of one person shows in NYC in December.  

My last crowdfunding campaign had amazing success!  Since then I've been writing and collaborating with the support of the other Ones, and we've been making some pretty powerful magic happen.  There's no turning back now, friends!

 The next step is a retreat happening in 10 days to start building the framework for our shows. We will finally all meet face to face in NYC and see the theater space where everything will come together.  From there we will be setting up shop for a few days with a few coaches to really bring life to what we've been doing on our own and a documentation team to capture all the excitement.  

From here we start creating something dynamic!

So, here's what you'll be funding.

  - One on one and team coaching with a group of amazing artists by one of the most powerfully dynamic people I know.

- A documentation team to capture each step of the way.

  - Specialized coaching from stage directors,  storytellers, and other professionals to aid in crafting my show.

  - Food and lodging for a workshop retreat and our time in NYC. 

  - A beautiful venue in NYC in a theater already excited about our program.

  - Any additional production costs.

Due to the nature of a program developed by someone with experience and ability to have plans for all foreseeable issues that may arise, there is very little risk as long as the funds can be raised for my participation.  This is where I need your help. 

This next step is to fund my spot in the retreat.  Thank you for helping me make this happen!

story:
Short Summary

I am born and raised in Florida and have always known of it as an insane state.  A few years ago, i decided to write short plays based on true stories from Florida.  This is what happened. 

The history of the show began as a test run at UCB in August 2014, where the notes were incredibly positive, they just wanted it to officially be a play (and not a sketch show as it would've been at UCB).  We took those notes and had a full production with those notes at Manhattan Repertory Theatre in July 2015 and we sold pretty well and the audience ate the show up.  Kind of like we fed them bath salts....we didn't....or did we?

We just got accepted into the 2016 FRIGID FESTIVAL in NYC and we need to raise funds for this huge opportunity for the show.  This show will see a whole audience that we couldn't get just from promoting a small off-off broadway play by myself but a bigger audience from the festival.  Every dollar donated will be used for the production and we will deeply be grateful for the support.

What We Need & What You Get

We need atleast $1400.  This will cover:

$1000 for festival fees

$350 for extra rehearsals (the show has been fully staged before just gotta tune it up, we also have a place that will give us a deal)

$50 any extra props, or extra rehearsal space

Risks & Challenges

There are over 90 real "Florida Man" stories/headlines in this play and that means there have been countless hours of research going into this play.  Plus 23 years growing up in Florida.  This play is the play that Florida needs and deserves.  We make fun with Florida and respect it while realizing many citizens are insane.

We understand that most people won't be able to give a lot of money or anything.  I've been in that boat many times.  I am an actor.  But, even as little as $5 goes a long way.  

Other Ways You Can Help

There are way's you can support just by getting our name out there.  When you see a Florida man headline use the #AllisFine and share it out.  And share it with your friends.  Also, share our link with your friends.

story:
What's it all about?

My name is David and I am an actor, director and soon to be stand up musical comedian at the Edinburgh Fringe. 

In 2012, together with my flatmate and partner in crime Will Perrins, I wrote a love song for Sally Gunnell, the athlete who won the gold for the 400m hurdles at the Barcelona Olympics in 1992.

Four years later, the flame lives on and I am off to the Edinburgh Fringe with an entire show's worth of songs, poetry, and letters written for the unlikeliest of celebrity crushes.

NOW I NEED SOME HELP! This year I am reducing the costs of performing in Edinburgh by performing in a free venue but I still need to cover the costs of registering the show, marketing the show, paying for accommodation, as well as raising some money for PBH's Free Fringe, which is an awesome organisation.

Sponsoring me!

The main costs for the show are for Fringe registration which costs £393.60, marketing and print costs for posters and flyers for which I am setting aside £250, and the rest will go towards living costs for the month in Edinburgh and a donation to PBH's Free Fringe.

In return for financial contributions to make this show happen, I am offering something that money ordinarily can't buy...

Personalised (and deeply heartful) love songs to backers who contribute £25 or more.

How you are helping.

Your support will make a huge difference to the success of the show. This year I am carefully budgeting and reducing costs by performing in a free venue, but there are still costs involved for which I need help. At last year's Edinburgh Fringe I spent over £2000 of my own money to take up my show 'The Star Rover,' an adaptation of a Jack London novel which I wrote, directed and played music in. This left me a little bit broke, but with a show that was received really well:

'Utterly incomparable to all I have seen before, this performance is one of emotional intensity, and at moments could certainly be described as nothing less than first-rate art. ★★★★★

(Edfringereview.com)

My aim this year is to create a funny, silly and poignant one show, all while avoiding destitution

story:
Le jour où l'on se sent enfin soi-même, qui doit-on remercier : le temps qui a passé ou ses amis ? Peut-être les deux...

C'est ce  que raconte "31", sur vingt ans et en chansons. 
Les spectateurs de notre première lecture, par leurs rires et leur émotion, nous ont prouvé que cette histoire et ces personnages leur étaient allés droit au coeur. Tous nous ont dit leur impatience de voir cette pièce mise en scène. 
Le projet est déjà en route avec une amorce de production, mais nous avons besoin de votre générosité pour concrétiser le montage de la pièce au prochain Festival d'Avignon. Joignez-vous à cette belle aventure en participant financièrement.
Le spectacle a un besoin vital de ces 8000€.
Chaque don est important !

"31", comédie musicale

Stéphane, Victoire, Anthony et Ruben, quatre amis de toujours, fêtent le 31 décembre 1999, comme ils en ont fêté tant d’autres ensemble. C’est un réveillon habituel, une photo de plus de ce qu’ils sont devenus au bout d’un an écoulé… Jusqu’à l’annonce d’Anthony. Mais avant que quiconque ait pu réagir, nous allons remonter le temps avec eux, de réveillon en réveillon, jusqu’en 1979. On les a connus adultes, on les découvrira à chaque âge de leur vie, jusqu’à l’enfance…
Avec émotion et humour, Gaétan Borg (Mamma Mia) et Stéphane Laporte (Le Roi Lion) nous guident dans ce jeu de piste à travers les années. 
C’est l’élégante musique de Stéphane Corbin (L’Hôtel des Roches Noires) qui tourne chaque page d’un nouveau 31, avec les chansons des Funambules.

Sous la houlette de Jean-Luc Revol (Le Cabaret des Hommes perdus), quatre talents reconnus du théâtre musical :

Stéphane : Rachel Pignot (Un Violon sur le Toit)
Victoire : Valérie Zaccomer (Frankenstein Junior)
Anthony : Alexandre Faitrouni (La Belle et la Bête)
Ruben : Fabian Richard (Cabaret)

Une comédie musicale sur l’amitié, le temps qui passe, Nadine de Rotschild et les mouflons.

story:
CTP is a new theatre company with a mission to offer high quality theatrical productions; community outreach and educational programs; and to support local artists and enhance the lives of the members of our community through the arts.

Services We Will Offer

  • Provide a collaborative base to enhance and increase awareness of the arts in the Rogue Valley.
  • A professional environment, dedicated to educational programs and workshops.
  • Provide full theatrical productions to the community on topics of relevance.
  • Training programs for the developing theatrical artist (performance and technical).
  • Community-building events (productions in the parks).

CTP is registered as a non profit LLC in the State of Oregon. We filed for 501 (c) (3) non-profit status in November 2016 and are awaiting approval.


As theatre artists, we have a passion to bring you only the best theatrical productions. But we understand that theatre is also a business that must raise money in order to produce the art. There is a lot that goes into putting up a production:
  • Theatre/space rental (whether we are using a temporary space or buying it, there is rent and mortgage to consider)
  • Cost of acquiring rights to plays/musicals (plays usually cost between $75-120 per performance that means that a show with 9 performances can cost between $600-1,000... and that's just for the rights to put on a play)
  • Paying actors,  sound and light designers, Stage Managers, and everyone else who works behind the scenes (as much as we want to believe that everyone wants to work for free in the arts because they have a passion for it, in reality, we all want to be paid just like everyone who works passionately in their chosen field... theatre is not a hobby)
  • Marketing (promotional material, cost of running a website, printing costs, etc)
  • Supplies (all basic office supplies needed to run the business aspect of a theatre company)
  • Fees (crowd funding, bank fees, legal fees, etc)
  • Insurance (any business needs to have insurance for the safety of the business and their customers)
  • Costumes
  • Set pieces
  • Lighting equipment (including software to run it)
  • Sound equipment (including software to run it)
These are just some of the costs that will be incurred to start up CTP in 2016. To that end, we are excited to launch our inaugural fundraiser:

The Benefits

Your donation to Collaborative Theatre Project will help fund our Inaugural Season in 2016. Additionally, we plan to implement classes and workshops to the community as soon as possible, which will require CTP to rent a space for the duration of the class/workshop several times through the 2016 season.

All this requires funding and your donation will make that happen for CTP in 2016!

You can also be a part of our first theatrical endeavor: The 24 Hour Plays(R) Play in a Day Event! Please look over our perks for donating to CTP. 

For more information about our 24 Hour Plays (R) event, please visit ctporegon.org.


Other Ways You Can Help

If you have access to:
  • Theatre equipment
  • Printing services
  • Printers, ink, paper
  • Concessions (candy, drinks, popcorn --all in bulk)
  • Costumes
  • Set pieces
  • Time to volunteer
We need you! Whether donated, borrowed, or deeply discounted, any of the above will help us be successful in 2016! Contact us and we will be happy to work with you.

Services We Will Offer

Provide a collaborative base to enhance and increase awareness of the arts in the Rogue Valley.
A professional environment, dedicated to educational programs and workshops.
Provide full theatrical productions to the community on topics of relevance.
Training programs for the developing theatrical artist (performance and technical).
Community-building events (productions in the parks).
