story:
This piece of black queer ritual-theatre—equal parts interrogating and fiercely loving the black radical tradition, has the unique opportunity intervene in the conversation about homophobia in the black community through the fragmented story of one deeply troubled masculine-of-center child of two Panthers. It will premiere at BRIC House (Brooklyn), a multidisciplinary arts organization which has made its reputation known supporting both aesthetic excellence and justice-oriented cultural programming, reaching hundreds of thousands of people a year. 
The Messiah Complex has received years of development (including a residency at San Francisco’s The Garage and a staged reading at the National Black Theatre) and been recognized at several venues—a CASH Grant from Theatre Bay Area, an NAACP nomination for an excerpted production in L.A., and the Audience Award at New York’s esteemed Downtown Urban Theatre Festival.) Finally, with the support of the Astraea Lesbian Foundation for Justice in collaboration with BRIC House, the play will receive its world premiere.

In collaboration with a team of two fiercely talented artists—Charlotte Brathwaite (director) and Ni’Ja Whitson (choreographer), I am thrilled at the opportunity to premiere this work which amplifies the voices of black queer folks who so often get the short end of the representational stick. Sadly, it is still a rare opportunity, in the current theatre world where black queer work is so severely underrepresented, for a play like mine, which stars three gender non-conforming actors of color (and 10 additional performers of color), to be funded at all. Yet in this cultural climate of hate (more trans-people of color were murdered this year than in any year preceding) it is more important than ever for me to tell this story.  
Stories save lives—not just because they reflect us to ourselves, but because they refract us to others struggling to see us as whole, healthy, and beautiful. It is urgent for us all to see—and be seen--in the art being put out by the cultural institutions that surround us. I am humbled that this story has the chance to do some of this work, and I hope you decide to walk down that road with us. 
Your contribution will be what gives this play the opportunity to have a life beyond the page.  

Please spread the word, and welcome to the "Messiah" family!!!

Written by Nia Witherspoon, directed by Charlotte Brathwaite, choreography by Ni’Ja Whitson, dramaturgy by Cherrie Moraga, and original music by Justin Hicks.

Performed by Mikel Banks, Marcus Brandon, Joel Daniels, Kirsten Flores-Davis, Anyanwu Glanville, Tiffany Salmon, Linda La Montanez, Shelley Nicole, Nabowire Stokes, Kirya Traber, Tanisha Thompson and Ni’Ja Whitson.

About the creative and design team:
Nia Ostrow Witherspoon (Playwright)
Nia Ostrow Witherspoon is a multidisciplinary Brooklyn/Phoenix based artist investigating the social and spiritual realities of blackness, gender/sexuality, and intergenerational trauma. Working primarily in the mediums of theatre/performance, vocal and sound composition, and creative scholarship, Witherspoon’s work has traveled both nationally and internationally to venues ranging from theatres and universities to activist organizations and non-profits. Described as “especially fascinating” by Backstage Magazine, Witherspoon has been the recipient of multiple awards, including: Astraea Foundation’s Lesbian Writer Award and Global Arts Fund Grant, Downtown Theatre Festival’s “Audience Award,” a three-month long Wurlitzer Foundation residency, Lambda Literary’s Emerging Playwriting Fellowship, a CASH Grant from Theatre Bay Area, and a Mellon Dissertation Fellowship. Her work for the stage has been featured at HERE, the National Black Theatre, BAAD, and the Painted Bride (Philadelphia), among various venues in the Bay Area, including The Lab, The Garage, La Peña, and Eastside Arts Alliance. As a performer, Witherspoon is co-founder of ceremonial music collective SoliRose, a world-premiere cast member (and in the touring company) of Sharon Bridgforth’s River See, which opened at Chicago’s Links Hall, and has been a featured vocalist in the work of Cherríe Moraga in La Semilla Caminante/The Traveling Seed (Intersection for the Arts). Witherspoon’s writing is published in the Yellow Medicine Review, and forthcoming inWomen and Collective Creation (Palgrave), The Journal of Popular Culture, and Imagined Theatres (Routledge). Her next play, You Mine, commissioned by the Obie-award winning Fire This Time Festival, will premiere in January 2016. Witherspoon holds a BA in American Studies from Smith College and a PhD in Theatre and Performance Studies from Stanford University.

Cherríe Moraga (Dramaturg)

Cherríe Moraga is a co-editor of This Bridge Called My Back: Writings by Radical Women of Color, republished in a new edition by SUNY Press in 2015. As a political and literary essayist, she has published several collections of writings, including, most recently, A Xicana Codex of Changing Consciousness; Writings 2000-2010. As a playwright, her latest work, New Fire: To Put Things Right Again, which she also directed, premiered at Brava Theater in San Francisco in 2012. A collaboration with visual artist, Celia Herrera Rodríguez, over three-thousand people witnessed the work. Moraga is the recipient of the United States Artist Rockefeller Fellowship for Literature, the American Studies Association Lifetime Achievement Award, and the Lambda Foundation’s “Pioneer” award, among many other honors. In 2015, she was awarded the MAP Fund/Creative Capital grant for her new play, “Mathematics of Love” to premiere in 2017 in San Francisco. For nearly twenty years she has served as an Artist in Residence at Stanford University in the Department of Theater and Performance Studies and (since 2008) in Comparative Studies in Race and Ethnicity Program. She is also a founding member of La Red Xicana Indígena, an advocacy group working in the areas of education, culture, and international and local indigenous women’s rights. She is presently completing a memoir entitled The Native Country of My Heart.


Charlotte Brathwaite (Director)
Princess Grace award-winning stage director Charlotte Brathwaite is known for staging classical and unconventional texts, dance, visual art, multi-media, site-specific installation and music events which have been seen in the Americas, Europe, the Caribbean and Asia. Recently she directed Prophetika: an oratorio at La MaMa Theater in NYC which was celebrated as, “conceptual yet viscerally powerful,” by the Wall Street Journal. She is also the recipient of the Julian Milton Kaufman Prize and a Rockefeller Residency. BA, Amsterdam School for the Arts (the Netherlands); MFA, Yale School of Drama (USA). She was a Visiting Professor at Amherst College, a Visiting artist at Williams College and is currently assistant professor of Theater Arts at Massachusetts Institute of Technology (MIT).

Ni'Ja Whitson (Choreographer)

Ni’Ja Whitson is an interdisciplinary artist and writer whose work engages a nexus of postmodern and African diasporic performance practices. She is the recipient of a 2013 Movement Research Artist in Residency Award, commissioned to create a new interdisciplinary performance work, and a member of the Hemispheric Institute’s Working Group in Dance. She has served as assistant choreographer to Dianne McIntyre for the Goodman Theater’s production of Crowns, directed and written by Regina Taylor, and recently completed an international tour of her interdisciplinary solo work root shock including invitations in New York, Canada, and Chicago. She is noted as an innovating practitioner of the Theatrical Jazz Aesthetic and has also co-facilitated training internationally as well as in collaboration with Sharon Bridgforth hosted by Links Hall and the Theatre School at DePaul University. Whitson has worked with a range of artists including Guillermo Gomez Peña / La Pocha Nostra, April Berry, Allison Knowles, Darrell Jones, Dee Alexander, and Douglas Ewart.  As a percussionist and dance soloist of Inventions/Nyabinghi Choir, directed by Douglas Ewart, Whitson has performed in multiple venues with award-winning artists including recording a live album at the legendary Velvet Lounge. Whitson’s writing includes critical essays, poetry, experimental non-fiction, and performance/writing in the performance/novel and Theatrical Jazz Aesthetic tradition. Her work has been published in print and online journals including, Stories: A Room of Her Own; Area 21; and have been performed widely.


Justin Hicks (Sound Designer/DJ/Composer)

Using music, text, and sound Hicks explores various themes, including identity, economics, marriage, and religion, through compositions and performances that range from singer/songwriter-style presentations, and recordings, to interdisciplinary and collaborative performance works involving movement and set design. His work has been featured at Lincoln Center for the Performing Arts, Baryshnikov Arts Center, PS 122, The Julliard School,The Knitting Factory, Jack, Arlene’s Grocery, Pianos and Bowery Poetry Club. He was a member of Kara Walker's 6-8 Months Space and in 2014 completed a Lower Manhattan Cultural Council process space residency with Kaneza Schaal as a performer and sound designer for Schaal's Go Forth, which premiered during PS 122's COIL Festival in 2016.  Justin was also a performer and sound designer for both The Geneva Project by Jennifer Harrison Newman and Charlotte Brathwaite (Jack 2015), as well as the Obie Award winning (Abigail Deville design) production of Prophetika: An Oratorio by Charlotte Brathwaite (LaMama 2015).  His work The Odetta Project:  Waterboy and the Mighty World, was shown at Bowery Arts and Science in 2014 and was featured during the Freedom Songs Festival:  Which Side Are You On, Friend? at Jack in 2015.   He served as music director for Steffani Jemison's Promise Machine (MoMA 2015), and is currently working with Jemison onMikrokosmos, a performance vocabulary that uses musical literacy as subject and form.Inspired by diverse approaches to music pedagogy and musical language, the work connects visual signs, musical symbols, and real world referents.  Mikrokosmos is commissioned by Steirischer Herbst; it will be deployed in a site-specific performance for the Neuemuseum Graz, Austria, in October 2016.


Tuce Yasak (Lighting/Set Designer)

Tuce Yasak graduated from the Department of Industrial Design at Middle East Technical University in Turkey in 2004. She worked for XXI Architecture and Design Magazine for five years as the Editor of Industrial Design. Following the magic of light, she moved from Istanbul to New York in November 2009. She designs for dance, theater and concerts. She is interested in site-specific performances and light installations. She has been to NOLA Fringe Festival with Enthusiast Theater Company’s site-specific piece ‘the Decay of the Cities” in November 2013. She has been involved with Lumensentient Projections since 2011 and has performed in “LAMP”, the urban light festival in New Haven in October 2013 and at MassBliss Festival in July, 2015.  Also, she was a contributing participant in Gutai Card Box exhibited at the Solomon R Guggenheim Museum, NYC as a part of Gutai: Playground retrospective exhibition in February/March 2013. In August 2013, she was a resident at MANA Contemporary Art Center, NJ with choreographer Nikki Holck. She worked as a contributor writer ofPLSN Magazine and made interviews with lighting designers. She has been collaborating with choreographer Korhan Basaran since 2011 in both  NYC and Istanbul (Gatherings, Untitled, RAU, DRT, RAU2, Unfold, Unsettled). She has also collaborated with Vicky Araico, actress and playwright from Mexico City, on her solo show “Juana in a Million” including the performance at the Yerba Buena Arts Center in San Francisco as a part of MEX I AM festival, in July 2014. The same year in August, she was a resident at the Bates Dance Festival with Korhan Basaran,where she got the opportunity to light “Unsettled”, a collaborative work by Korhan Basaran Dance Company and the David Dorfman Dance that was commissioned and produced by DanceMotionUS and BAM performed at Brooklyn Academy of Music, NYC in August, 2014. She has been a creative collaborator to choreographer Raja Feather Kelly of the Feather Theory in his recent works including Color Me Warhol in April,2015 and “37 Other Reasons to Cry” in October, 2015. She has been dancing tango since 2000 and she loves listening to jazz.

story:
By donating and supporting our campaign you are helping

Hues Productions create a dance performance that will explore grief in two parts, providing more opportunites for professionals. 

The Piece:

In  Act One,  the production will begin with those honoured in the sculpture called “The Dark Elegy” by Suse Lowenstein, (http://www.darkelegy103.com/.)

  She is the mother of one of the passengers, a Student returning from Study abroad program through Syracuse University, killed in the skies over Lockerbie, Scotland, (Pan Am flight 103) in 1988.  The audience will be introduced to a tragedy that hasn’t been mentioned in years, and it will be a reminder of the loss that accompanies the terrorism that seems so common in today’s world.  While ‘Holding On’ will use Lowenstein’s sculpture as its foundation artistic vision, it will not be limited to this.  We will build on her work with the range of emotions experienced by those affected in the wake of this tragic occurrence.  We will transform her static sculptural expression of grief and animate it through dynamic movement and music.

In Act two, we take a look into how we try to 'hold on' when life unexpectedly gets out of control. From loss of a family member, to loss of a relationship, to even loss of what could have been, we continue on and struggle  to get by day by day. With this piece we are taking everyday realities and exploring the journey we take to live and love,even when our whole world crashes down around us.

We will interview people who have journeyed through grief to gain insight to physical aspects, senses and movement associated with the pain caused. 

The Team:

Hues productions/Rory Hughes:  Creator/Director/Producer

    Rory Hughes has had this concept mulling in his mind over the last 15 years and is very excited to have it brought to life.  His is very excited to work with the people involved and has a connection to the first piece by attending the Syracuse University Musical Theater Program.  

Hues Productions mission is to bring ‘Broadway to Ireland’ and also create new opportunities for performers to have work in Ireland.  

David Doyle: Lighting and Sound Design

Neil O’Brien: Choreographer;  https://www.facebook.com/neilobriendance?fref=ts

Nina Pongratz: Choreographer; https://ninapongratz.wordpress.com/

Contribution:

What is happening in the world today is why we are passionate about doing this now and your support means a lot to bring this to life at the Axis Theatre in Ballymun. 

Our performance will be October 26 and 27th at the Axis Theatre Ballymun, Ireland 7:30pm curtain

In order to make this show, we need to raise the necessary funds and cannot make all of this happen without your help.  

By Donating Here your contribution will help us pay for the Theatre, Studio hire, the dancers, designers, stage management, design, promotional materials, marketing, Insurance & for the Choreographers.  

Here is an Expense chart so you can see what your donation is helping us with.
story_txt: By donating and supporting our campaign you are helpingHues Productions create a dance performance that will explore grief in two parts, providing more opportunites for professionals. The Piece:In  Act One,  the production will begin with those honoured in the sculpture called “The Dark Elegy” by Suse Lowenstein, (http://www.darkelegy103.com/.)  She is the mother of one of the passengers, a Student returning from Study abroad program through Syracuse University, killed in the skies over Lockerbie, Scotland, (Pan Am flight 103) in 1988.  The audience will be introduced to a tragedy that hasn’t been mentioned in years, and it will be a reminder of the loss that accompanies the terrorism that seems so common in today’s world.  While ‘Holding On’ will use Lowenstein’s sculpture as its foundation artistic vision, it will not be limited to this.  We will build on her work with the range of emotions experienced by those affected in the wake of this tragic occurrence.  We will transform her static sculptural expression of grief and animate it through dynamic movement and music.In Act two, we take a look into how we try to 'hold on' when life unexpectedly gets out of control. From loss of a family member, to loss of a relationship, to even loss of what could have been, we continue on and struggle  to get by day by day. With this piece we are taking everyday realities and exploring the journey we take to live and love,even when our whole world crashes down around us.We will interview people who have journeyed through grief to gain insight to physical aspects, senses and movement associated with the pain caused. The Team:Hues productions/Rory Hughes:  Creator/Director/Producer    Rory Hughes has had this concept mulling in his mind over the last 15 years and is very excited to have it brought to life.  His is very excited to work with the people involved and has a connection to the first piece by attending the Syracuse University Musical Theater Program.  Hues Productions mission is to bring ‘Broadway to Ireland’ and also create new opportunities for performers to have work in Ireland.  David Doyle: Lighting and Sound DesignNeil O’Brien: Choreographer;  https://www.facebook.com/neilobriendance?fref=tsNina Pongratz: Choreographer; https://ninapongratz.wordpress.com/Contribution:What is happening in the world today is why we are passionate about doing this now and your support means a lot to bring this to life at the Axis Theatre in Ballymun. Our performance will be October 26 and 27th at the Axis Theatre Ballymun, Ireland 7:30pm curtainIn order to make this show, we need to raise the necessary funds and cannot make all of this happen without your help.  By Donating Here your contribution will help us pay for the Theatre, Studio hire, the dancers, designers, stage management, design, promotional materials, marketing, Insurance & for the Choreographers.  Here is an Expense chart so you can see what your donation is helping us with.

story:
Dear Friends! 

Please consider helping Los Angeles Women's Shakespeare Company (non-profit 501c3) raise $15,000 to present Two Hot Projects in NYC!

We have Gifts with Witch to Tempt you  - Journeys through the Underlands, Soul Portraits dreamed up for this project by my friend, the genius metaphysical painter, Chuck Rounds!

If you can make a tax-deductible contribution of any size to bring some sizzling, gender-bent Shakespeare to New York City, we would deeply appreciate your generosity! We will keep Ticket prices at $18, but herein we reach for the Goblets, the Throne, and the Crown! We need your Support, for We would have Our Place (HERE - but, HERE, at the Dorothy B. Williams theater)! And your Action will be reflected back to you with a Sharp Pin, a Dagger, or a Portrait of your Soul...

"It if were done, when 'til done, then 'twere well it were done Quickly!..."

Here are a few quick details about our amazing theatrical/artistic co-creations to come! Please Help Us! Do It! Donate Now!

Lisa Wolpe, Producing Artistic Director, LAWSC

Spread Like Fire! We Thank You!

                  

 

MACBETH3

Starring Nick Salamone, Mary Hodges, and Lisa Wolpe

Co-Directed by Natsuko Ohama and Lisa Wolpe

Costumes Kelly Horrigan - Sets Mia Torres - Lights Sue Brandt

I’m playing Macbeth in a 3-person gender-bent adaptation I’m co-directing with my brilliant friend and long-time collaborator Natsuko Ohama. Nick Salamone, an extremely accomplished, highly trained, wonderful actor that I adore, is playing The Lady and Satan. Mary Hodges, a powerful actress who played Cassio beautifully in the all-female Othello I directed in Harlem for Take Wing and Soar, will play Banquo, Porter, Duncan, Witch and Macduff. My dear friend Mia Torres, long-time TD and set designer for LAWSC, is coming out to create our World, Kelly Horrigan is creating original leather designs for the Costumes, Sue Brandt comes to our aid, bringing Light in NYC after designing a number of successful LAWSC on the West Coast... Ellie Handel from NYU is our fabulous young Stage Manager... This will be Powerful! Join us! Please spread the word! Order tix ($18), donate a bit to help us on our maniacal way!

Fresh off an international tour, I bring my dynamic solo show to New York City. Shakespeare and the Alchemy of Gender is a very profound and personal piece, in which I play bits of Hamlet, Richard III, Shylock, and engage the audience in a profound discussion about suicide, empathy, family, forgiveness, and the transformational powers of Imagination, Memory, and Love. I’ve been touring it from Vancouver to London and throughout the USA to 5-star reviews – deceptively simple, a lifetime of work packed into an hour. 

“Wolpe brilliantly owns the stage.” – The New Current, U.K * * * * *

“Lisa Wolpe’s mesmerizing performance celebrates Shakespeare’s language and shows the humanity of his writing.” – UK Theatre Network

GET Tix NOW!

************************************

OUR GOAL: We’ve raised $10,000, and YES, we need to raise $15,000 more!

Can you Give $50,  $100, $1000? (YES, but What? You may say! $1,000!)

YES! ... and you will receive something AMAZING AND BEAUTIFUL in return! 

A Sharp Pin, a Dagger! or Here’s a way to Give and Receive Back a Tremendous Perk: Here are just three of hundreds of paintings of a journey with me that Chuck Rounds has created as an incentive to raise funds for these productions:

CHUCK ROUNDS

"I am a shaman. I am a process-based artist.I am an abstract expressionist. I believe that art is relational, a conversation. My art is meant to invoke questions and to tell stories. It is meant to be a meditation portal to liminal space. I am a visionary painter and believe art asks the big questions..."


My dear friend, the brilliant painter Chuck Rounds, will donate his artworks to YOU to support this theater festival!  Browse through Chuck's portfolio http://www.chuckrounds.com/portfolio.htm  Experience his beautiful, metaphysical work on his website - as well as the shamanic portraits he has done of me especially for this project. 

"Just coming up for air from a week of shamanic journey. It was a wild ride. I used five of your images and rendered a trove of treasure. I am very excited about both the alchemical and aesthetic aspects of these landscapes. I trust that some may be visionary portals for you... Thank you for your sharing your spirit Lisa…you have touched my heart and challenge me to the best of my abilities. Thank you for this time together on the path. You are a muse and a light. xoxo Chuck"

  • Donate $500 or more and receive one framed giclee print of your choice, sent with our thanks!   
  • Donate $1000 and receive any three giclee prints of your choosing, framed and delivered with our deepest gratitude!
 I am deeply touched and blessed and excited to have Chuck's partnership on this endeavor. He is a phenomenal metaphysical painter, a courageous shaman, a beloved friend, a generous man, a philanthropist, and a happy co-creator. We are soulmates!

Please CONTACT US ABOUT PRINTS YOU'D LIKE TO COLLECT! 
CHOOSE YOUR FAVORITES! GIVE ART TO A FRIEND! 

THANK YOU FOR HELPING US!

"My art is spiritual map-making. and I hope perceived as liminal space, a place for a conversation. a meditative portal, an invitation to play…" - Chuck Rounds

And that's all there is to it. 
Accept My Thanks, Accept My Thanks, Accept My Thanks! 
Lisa Wolpe

Producing Artistic Director

Los Angeles Women's Shakespeare Company

FED ID 501c3 95-4434376

http://www.lawsc.net

lisawolpe@gmail.com

(310) 453-5069

  •

Natsuko Ohama (Co-Director, MACBETH3) Natsuko Ohama is the head of the Voice Path in the MFA Acting program and a Professor of Theatre Practice at the USC School of Dramatic Arts. She is one of the premier voice teachers in the country, trained under legendary master Kristin Linklater at the Working Theatre. Ohama is a founding member and permanent faculty of Shakespeare & Company Lenox, Mass., as well as a senior artist at Pan Asian Rep New York, a certified Joy of Phonetics teacher trained by Louis Colaianni and was the Director of Training at the National Arts Center of Canada. She has taught at numerous institutions all over the country, including the NYU Experimental Theater Wing, CalArts, Columbia University, the Sundance Institute, New Actors Workshop and the Stratford Festival. Recently, she taught in Stromboli, Italy, in Istanbul and at the Wooster Group Summer Institute in New York. She also has an extensive workshop and private teaching practice.

In Los Angeles, she has coached numerous productions at the Kirk Douglas Theatre, Mark Taper Forum and also at the new Wallis Annenberg Theatre in Beverly Hills. A Drama Desk-nominated actress, she has portrayed roles ranging from Juliet to Lady Macbeth from Hamlet to Prospero (Los Angeles Women’s Shakespeare Company) from the action film Speed to the cult series Forever Knight and American Playhouse on PBS. She has been seen on screen in Pirates of the Caribbean 2, and on stage at the Kirk Douglas Theatre in Dogeaters as Imelda Marcos and last season appeared as Polonius in the LAWSC production of Hamlet at the Odyssey Theatre. Ohama’s play Geisha of the Gilded Age-Miyuki Morgan, was staged at the Ventford Theater in Massachusetts last year. As a director, her credits include the Press and FACE for Visions and Voices at USC. Learn more at www.natsukoohama.com.

Nick Salamone (Lady Macbeth, Satan) has appeared in scores of plays Off and Off Off Broadway in NYC, in Los Angeles and around the English-speaking world. He has been nominated for Britain’s Stage Award as Best Actor at the Edinburgh International Fringe Festival as well as the LA Weekly Award and four times for the BSW Garland Award. He is an associate artist with New York Classical Theatre where he has performed Off Broadway in 14 productions including THE TEMPEST (Antonio), THE SEAGULL (Dorn), PLAYING MOLIERE (Moliere) and SCHOOL FOR HUSBANDS (Sganarelle), Other recent stage appearances include HILLARY AGONISTES at the Bleecker Street Theatre in NYC, Ricky Roma in GLENGARRY GLEN ROSS at the Egyptian Arena Theater, Jon Lawrence Rivera’s production of DOGEATERS at the Kirk Douglas Theatre, the title role in Classical Theatre Lab’s production of ARTURO UI as well as their CORIOLANUS (Aufidius) and THE LIBERTINE, Edwin Sanchez’ BAREFOOT BOY WITH SHOES ON at the Underground, Craig Lucas’ THE DYING GAUL, THE REFUGEE HOTEL for the Taper’s New Works Festival also at the Kirk Douglas Theatre, MEDEA at the Theatre @ Boston Court, and THE TEMPEST (Caliban) at the Taper Amphitheatre. Work in the UK includes MACBETH (Banquo), SHERLOCK HOLMES (Holmes) and his own RED HAT AND TALES, RIFFS & CREDOS and WHALE WATCHERS. Regional work includes FIND YOUR WAY HOME and THE MAIDS and Romulus Linney’s 2. A selection of some of his earlier New York work includes roles in the East Coast premiere of LORCA-A SHADOW OF CYPRESS, The 25th anniversary revival of Joseph Heller’s WE BOMBED IN NEW HAVEN, the world premieres of NIGHTSHIFT and A.R. Gurney’s THE OPEN MEETING and productions of Coward’s DESIGN FOR LIVING (Otto) and Chekhov’s THE SEAGULL (Treplev). Recent film credits include the Indie mystery PORNOGRAPHY, A THRILLER and the recently released Indie feature NINE LIVES also starring Dennis Christopher and Debra Wilson. Nick is currently at work on the web-series BATTERY PARK.  He is a produced and published award-winning playwright and librettist and  has been a finalist for the Kleban Prize for the past two years.

Mary E. Hodges (Banquo/Macduff/Duncan/Porter/Others)

Mary is thrilled to be working with Lisa once again! Mary portrayed (Cassio) and Lisa (Iago), in an All-Female staged reading of Othello for The Harlem Shakespeare Festival(HSF) at City College in 2013.  Mary reprised the role of (Cassio) last Fall in an All-Female production of Othello at The Dorothy Maynor Theatre, directed by Tony award winner Trezana Bevereley. Other shows with HSF/TWAS: Julius Caesar (Metellus Cimber) and Medea (Chorus) both directed by Petronia Paley; King Lear (The Fool) directed by Timothy D. Stickney; Hamlet (Ophelia) directed by Elizabeth Swain.  Mary has also played with Judith Shakespeare portraying mostly male roles: Double Falsehood (Henriquez); Coriolanus (Citizen/Adrian); Richard III (Edward/Richmond);

Henry IV, pt2 (Jack Cade); Much Ado (Beatrice).  At Connecticut Repertory in Hamlet (Queen Gertrude) and Twelfth Night (Maria) both directed by Eric Hill.  Mary has played with Long Wharf Theatre, The Berkshire Theatre Festival, Connecticut Rep, Berkeley Repertory Theatre, Gideon Productions, Target Margin, EST, New Federal Theatre and the National Black Theatre Festival.  Mary has a MFA in Acting from The University of Connecticut and a BFA in Acting from Virginia Commonwealth University.



More about LISA WOLPE and "ALCHEMY..."

(Another portrait of me by Chuck Rounds! With Iago, wrapped around me...)
THE SHOW:

Visionary theatre artist Lisa Wolpe’s new solo show Shakespeare and the Alchemy of Gender offers a unique celebration of the enchanting power of cross-gender Shakespeare. Over the past 20 years of work with the Los Angeles Women’s Shakespeare Company, Ms. Wolpe has played more of the Bard’s male roles than any woman in history, always to superlative reviews. An activist as well as a celebrated actress and director, Wolpe’s work speaks toward liberation from the “gender box” of expectations, and offers a unique and powerful perspective of courage, resilience and hope against her family’s background of war, suicide and despair.

Shakespeare and the Alchemy of Gender played in London last summer for a two-week run at the historic Rose Playhouse. She has played it in various iterations at: Provincetown Women’s Theater Festival, Los Angeles (Whittier College, The Miles Playhouse, Skylight Theater, UCLA), SpringWorks Festival, Stratford Ontario; Vancouver, B.C.; Chicago, Hope College, MI, Richmond Shakespeare Company, Colorado Shakespeare Festival, San Francisco Shakespeare Festival, Shakespeare’s Birthplace, Stratford-Upon-Avon, U.K.; The Rose Playhouse, U.K.; Orlando Shakespeare Theater, FL, and New Orleans Shakespeare Festival at Tulane University.

LONDON

The New Current, U.K.

★★★★★

“Lisa Wolpe is her own woman and joyfully speaks her mind, but her greatest legacy will undoubtedly be her creative vision and determination to create a platform and a voice for women, minorities and now the growing trans community in theatre. Theatre inspires, it gives hope to a generation who will, sooner than they think, be given the keys to these theatres and told ‘now it’s your turn’. When this time comes these new guardians can look back at those pioneers like Wolpe who will make this future possible, a future that’s fair and doesn't see gender, colour, sexuality.

For the UK theatre remains very white and dominated by men on the horizon there are some exceptional female playwrights, producers, and directors making their mark so it's only a matter of time before UK theatre starts to be more inclusive and challenging.” http://www.thenewcurrent.co.uk/#!london-theatre-review-lisa-wolpe/cidv

UK Theatre Network,

“Lisa Wolpe's mesmerising performance celebrates Shakespeare's language and shows the humanity of his writing. Wolpe finds solace in the Bard's work whilst her family struggles to cope with their often tragic history. Bursting with energy but also mastering the gentler notes, Wolpe provides samples of her Shylock, Romeo, Juliet, Hamlet, Hermione, Richard III, and Prospero… The Rose Playhouse is the perfect site for Lisa Wolpe's show – a celebration of Shakespeare's humanism, love and life.”

A Younger Theatre, 

“As a visionary theatre artist, Wolpe is best known as the Producing Artistic Director of the LA Women’s Shakespeare Company. It’s an all-female company that spans across all ages and races. Wolpe’s intention is to bring enlightenment to her audiences… Regardless of how brushed up you are on your Shakespeare, it is impossible not to be touched by her heartfelt performance…”

The Play’s The Thing UK, 

“At 19 years old, Lisa Wolpe fell in love with Shakespeare. She’s now performed more of Shakespeare’s male roles than any woman in history after founding Los Angeles Women’s Shakespeare Company twenty years ago. She is currently touring the world with her solo show, Shakespeare & The Alchemy of Gender. Although it sounds like an academic lecture, it contains some of the best Shakespeare performances I have seen. The play pays homage to her father, telling the man’s story and how he affected her life…”

“Definitely a must-see for anyone interested in the development of Shakespeare productions in recent years and wanting to experience the work of one of the most notable proponents of cross-gender casting.”

http://twohourstrafficofourstage.blogspot.com/2015/07/shakespeare-and-alchemy-of-gender.html

“In her show she certainly not only mapped but inhabited shifting realms of thought and myriad niches of human emotion. Such a joy and nourishment to see and hear Shakespeare played so truthfully and fully…Theatre well done exercises empathy. Wolpe, in this article says: 'If we can build empathy, we can invigorate the purpose of art, which is to create alliances that save lives and offer hope.” 

http://www.petalily.com/clown-dark-clown-theatre-practice-blog/category/gender

NEW YORK

HowlRound

“The political mission of this project is to create a forum for the exploration of brilliant Shakespeare that will be resplendent and variegated in its constituency. And that will lead into different visual representations, different conceptual and design presentations, but it will never change the fact that we all need to do the text beautifully. We use it to source ourselves personally, psychologically, and politically. And, we apply what we learn to this moment. We present the positive, of finally having a role worthy of your humanity.” 

http://howlround.com/transhakespeare-lisa-wolpe-and-the-art-of-empathy

LOS ANGELES

“Ms. Wolpe knows how to tell stories, personal and Shakespearean, and she does so with power and panache. Her Romeo is bold and flirtatious, Hamlet is wracked with uncertainty and Shylock reveals a determined, well-reasoned, revengeful soul.

Through the words of Shakespeare, Ms. Wolpe tackles contemporary political and social issues, offers perspectives on the haunting influences of war, violence and victimization and provides a glimpse of the resilience, hope and humanity that makes a life worth living. She’s equally adept at telling her own story and the many tales told together result in an engaging, heartrending, satisfying time in the theatre.”

http://isechronicle.uvic.ca/index.php/Var/2013/05/01/shakespeare_and_the_alchemy_of_gender

VANCOUVER, B.C.

“It was unexpectedly gut-wrenching, at the same time fascinating, thought-provoking, and in fact transcendent… I just hope Vancouver gets another chance to see this show, and that I do.”

https://beyondyvr.wordpress.com/2014/07/28/review-shakespeare-and-the-alchemy-of-gender-lisa-wolpes-

“Wolpe knows how to tell stories, personal and Shakespearean, and she does so with power and panache. Her Romeo is bold and flirtatious, Hamlet is wracked with uncertainty and Shylock reveals a determined, well-reasoned, revengeful soul…Through the words of Shakespeare, Ms. Wolpe tackles contemporary political and social issues, offers perspectives on the haunting influences of war, violence and victimization and provides a glimpse of the resilience, hope and humanity that makes a life worth living. She’s equally adept at telling her own story and the many tales told together result in an engaging, heartrending, satisfying time in the theatre.”

 solo-show-orpheum-annex-july-16/

OREGON SHAKESPEARE FESTIVAL

"She approaches characters such as Iago and Hamlet in challenging and illuminating ways. It's a pleasure to have this company member returning to share some master work."

http://www.broadwayworld.com/portland/article/OSF-to-Stage-Lisa-Wolpes-SHAKESPEARE-AND-THE-ALCHEMY-OF-GENDER-91-20140825

AMERICAN THEATER MAGAZINE

“Playing Shakespeare’s great roles is an alchemical process about unpacking the vulnerability of a villain or a man in order to understand why men do what they do.”

http://www.americantheatre.org/2014/08/13/lisa-wolpe-uses-shakespeare-to-bend-gender-roles-around-the-country/

A.R. Gurney’s THE OPEN MEETING and productions of Coward’s DESIGN FOR LIVING
(Otto) and Chekhov’s THE SEAGULL (Treplev). Recent film credits include the
Indie mystery PORNOGRAPHY, A THRILLER and the recently released Indie feature
NINE LIVES also starring Dennis Christopher and Debra Wilson. Nick is currently
at work on the web-series BATTERY PARK. 
He is a produced and published award-winning playwright and librettist
and  has been a finalist for the Kleban
Prize for the past two years.

Mary E. Hodges (Banquo/Macduff/Duncan/Porter/Others)

Mary is thrilled to be
working with Lisa once again! Mary portrayed (Cassio) and Lisa (Iago), in an
All-Female staged reading of Othello for The Harlem Shakespeare Festival(HSF)
at City College in 2013.  Mary reprised
the role of (Cassio) last Fall in an All-Female production of Othello at The Dorothy
Maynor Theatre, directed by Tony award winner Trezana Bevereley. Other shows
with HSF/TWAS: Julius Caesar (Metellus Cimber) and Medea (Chorus) both directed
by Petronia Paley; King Lear (The Fool) directed by Timothy D. Stickney; Hamlet
(Ophelia) directed by Elizabeth Swain. 
Mary has also played with Judith Shakespeare portraying mostly male
roles: Double Falsehood (Henriquez); Coriolanus (Citizen/Adrian); Richard III
(Edward/Richmond); 
Henry IV, pt2 (Jack Cade);
Much Ado (Beatrice).  At Connecticut
Repertory in Hamlet (Queen Gertrude) and Twelfth Night (Maria) both directed by
Eric Hill.  Mary has played with Long
Wharf Theatre, The Berkshire Theatre Festival, Connecticut Rep, Berkeley
Repertory Theatre, Gideon Productions, Target Margin, EST, New Federal Theatre
and the National Black Theatre Festival. 
Mary has a MFA in Acting from The University of Connecticut and a BFA in
Acting from Virginia Commonwealth University.

More about LISA WOLPE and "ALCHEMY..."





(Another portrait of me by Chuck Rounds! With Iago, wrapped around me...)

THE SHOW:

Visionary theatre artist Lisa Wolpe’s new solo
show Shakespeare and the Alchemy of Gender offers a unique
celebration of the enchanting power of cross-gender Shakespeare. Over the past
20 years of work with the Los Angeles Women’s Shakespeare Company, Ms. Wolpe
has played more of the Bard’s male roles than any woman in history, always to
superlative reviews. An activist as well as a celebrated actress and director,
Wolpe’s work speaks toward liberation from the “gender box” of expectations,
and offers a unique and powerful perspective of courage, resilience and hope
against her family’s background of war, suicide and despair.
Shakespeare and the Alchemy of Gender played
in London last summer for a two-week run at the historic Rose Playhouse. She has
played it in various iterations at: Provincetown Women’s Theater Festival, Los
Angeles (Whittier College, The Miles Playhouse, Skylight Theater, UCLA),
SpringWorks Festival, Stratford Ontario; Vancouver, B.C.; Chicago, Hope
College, MI, Richmond Shakespeare Company, Colorado Shakespeare Festival,
San Francisco Shakespeare Festival, Shakespeare’s Birthplace,
Stratford-Upon-Avon, U.K.; The Rose Playhouse, U.K.; Orlando
Shakespeare Theater, FL, and New Orleans Shakespeare Festival at Tulane University.
LONDON
The New Current, U.K.
★★★★★
“Lisa Wolpe is her own woman and joyfully speaks her
mind, but her greatest legacy will undoubtedly be her creative vision and
determination to create a platform and a voice for women, minorities and now
the growing trans community in theatre. Theatre inspires, it gives hope to a
generation who will, sooner than they think, be given the keys to these
theatres and told ‘now it’s your turn’. When this time comes these new
guardians can look back at those pioneers like Wolpe who will
make this future possible, a future that’s fair and doesn't see gender, colour,
sexuality.
For the UK theatre remains very white and dominated by men on
the horizon there are some exceptional female playwrights, producers, and
directors making their mark so it's only a matter of time before UK theatre
starts to be more inclusive and challenging.” http://www.thenewcurrent.co.uk/#!london-theatre-review-lisa-wolpe/cidv
UK Theatre Network,
“Lisa Wolpe's mesmerising performance celebrates Shakespeare's
language and shows the humanity of his writing. Wolpe finds solace in the
Bard's work whilst her family struggles to cope with their often tragic
history. Bursting with energy but also mastering the gentler notes, Wolpe
provides samples of her Shylock, Romeo, Juliet, Hamlet, Hermione, Richard III,
and Prospero… The Rose Playhouse is the perfect site for Lisa Wolpe's show – a
celebration of Shakespeare's humanism, love and life.”
A Younger Theatre, 
“As a visionary theatre artist, Wolpe is best known as the
Producing Artistic Director of the LA Women’s Shakespeare Company. It’s an
all-female company that spans across all ages and races. Wolpe’s intention is
to bring enlightenment to her audiences… Regardless of how brushed up you are
on your Shakespeare, it is impossible not to be touched by her heartfelt
performance…”
The Play’s The Thing
UK, 
“At 19 years old, Lisa Wolpe fell in love with Shakespeare.
She’s now performed more of Shakespeare’s male roles than any woman in history
after founding Los Angeles Women’s Shakespeare Company twenty years ago. She is
currently touring the world with her solo show, Shakespeare & The
Alchemy of Gender. Although it sounds like an academic lecture, it
contains some of the best Shakespeare performances I have seen. The play pays
homage to her father, telling the man’s story and how he affected her life…”
“Definitely a must-see for anyone interested in the development
of Shakespeare productions in recent years and wanting to experience the work
of one of the most notable proponents of cross-gender casting.”
http://twohourstrafficofourstage.blogspot.com/2015/07/shakespeare-and-alchemy-of-gender.html
“In her show she certainly not only mapped but inhabited
shifting realms of thought and myriad niches of human emotion. Such a joy and
nourishment to see and hear Shakespeare played so truthfully and fully…Theatre
well done exercises empathy. Wolpe, in this article says: 'If we can build
empathy, we can invigorate the purpose of art, which is to create alliances
that save lives and offer hope.” 
http://www.petalily.com/clown-dark-clown-theatre-practice-blog/category/gender
NEW YORK
HowlRound
“The political mission of this project is to create a forum for
the exploration of brilliant Shakespeare that will be resplendent and
variegated in its constituency. And that will lead into different visual
representations, different conceptual and design presentations, but it will
never change the fact that we all need to do the text beautifully. We use it to
source ourselves personally, psychologically, and politically. And, we apply
what we learn to this moment. We present the positive, of finally having a role
worthy of your humanity.” 
http://howlround.com/transhakespeare-lisa-wolpe-and-the-art-of-empathy
LOS ANGELES
“Ms. Wolpe knows how to tell stories, personal and
Shakespearean, and she does so with power and panache. Her Romeo is bold and
flirtatious, Hamlet is wracked with uncertainty and Shylock reveals a
determined, well-reasoned, revengeful soul.
Through the words of Shakespeare, Ms. Wolpe tackles contemporary
political and social issues, offers perspectives on the haunting influences of
war, violence and victimization and provides a glimpse of the resilience, hope
and humanity that makes a life worth living. She’s equally adept at telling her
own story and the many tales told together result in an engaging, heartrending,
satisfying time in the theatre.”
http://isechronicle.uvic.ca/index.php/Var/2013/05/01/shakespeare_and_the_alchemy_of_gender
VANCOUVER, B.C.
“It was unexpectedly gut-wrenching, at the same time
fascinating, thought-provoking, and in fact transcendent… I just hope Vancouver
gets another chance to see this show, and that I do.”
https://beyondyvr.wordpress.com/2014/07/28/review-shakespeare-and-the-alchemy-of-gender-lisa-wolpes-

“Wolpe knows how to
tell stories, personal and Shakespearean, and she does so with power and
panache. Her Romeo is bold and flirtatious, Hamlet is wracked with uncertainty
and Shylock reveals a determined, well-reasoned, revengeful soul…Through the
words of Shakespeare, Ms. Wolpe tackles contemporary political and social
issues, offers perspectives on the haunting influences of war, violence and
victimization and provides a glimpse of the resilience, hope and humanity that
makes a life worth living. She’s equally adept at telling her own story and the
many tales told together result in an engaging, heartrending, satisfying time
in the theatre.”
 solo-show-orpheum-annex-july-16/
OREGON SHAKESPEARE FESTIVAL
"She approaches characters such as Iago and Hamlet in
challenging and illuminating ways. It's a pleasure to have this company member
returning to share some master work."
http://www.broadwayworld.com/portland/article/OSF-to-Stage-Lisa-Wolpes-SHAKESPEARE-AND-THE-ALCHEMY-OF-GENDER-91-20140825
AMERICAN THEATER MAGAZINE
“Playing Shakespeare’s great roles is an alchemical process
about unpacking the vulnerability of a villain or a man in order to understand
why men do what they do.”
http://www.americantheatre.org/2014/08/13/lisa-wolpe-uses-shakespeare-to-bend-gender-roles-around-the-country/

story:
Basic Information

Dublin Rising is a new musical by Krishna Alexandra and Lórien Patton. It is an original story about the everyday women involved in the 1916 Easter Rising in Dublin, Ireland, which paved the way for Irish independence in 1921.

The musical debuted in Las Vegas on December 10, 2015 in a concert performance at the Paul Harris Theatre, and we are now planning to continue development with two stagings: (1) a small workshop production on April 22 and 23, 2016, to correspond to the 100-year anniversary of the Rising; and (2) a more complete staging to be held on July 1 and 2. (All currently scheduled performances to be held in Las Vegas.)

Synopsis

Dublin Rising tells the stories of three women from vastly different socio-economic backgrounds, whose lives are upended by the one-week Easter Rebellion.

Nellie is the owner of a Dublin brothel, and the head of an underground spy network. She allows her place of business to be used as a meeting place for a small rebel unit, under the leadership of a female commander, Josephine Moore.

Brigid, an educated middle-class woman and the wife of an Irish officer, supports the revolution financially and writes for an Irish Nationalist newspaper.

Meaghann is an unwed teenage mother who has been condemned to a cloistered life under the supervision of nuns. Her brother fights in the revolution, and promises to free her someday. These three women’s lives will be forever changed by the events of Easter Week 1916. 

About the Show

With the upcoming 100th anniversary of the Irish 1916 Easter Rising, a great deal of attention has been fo- cussed on the few men and exceedingly rare women generally thought of as the leaders and heroes of the Rebellion. Little attention has been paid to the contribution of women outside of ‘accepted’ roles: brave nurses, loving wives, and mothers of the next generation of patriots. The truth is that women served not only in leadership, but at all levels of the Rising: from finance and logistics, to intelligence gathering, to physical combat.

With this heavily researched piece of historical fiction, we wanted to show the contributions and experiences of women in Dublin during that pivotal week. In addressing that broad range of experience, they also wanted to celebrate the 20th anniversary of the closing of the last Irish Magdalene Laundry, a harsh Catholic institution for the confinement of ‘wayward’ and rebellious women and girls. 

The production will also include a significant filmic projection component, consisting of original illustrations, animations, and historical footage from the Rising.

Production Artwork

  

  

  

  



About the Creators

Krishna Alexandra (Book, Music & Lyrics, Direction) is a writer, director and performer with a 20-year career in theatre and music. Her first original musical, Running Away to Broadway, was produced at Manoa Valley Theatre in Honolulu, Hawaii in 1990. Additional theatrical writing has included Look Ma, No Hands!, A Night at Ground Zero, and most recently Itzayana: A Dream Circus.

Krishna’s work as a singer and songwriter has been featured on more than 50 albums over the last 25 years. She recently toured California as half of the singing-songwriting duo She Flies, together with Lórien Patton. Prior to that, Krishna wrote and sang lead for the Los Angeles band, The Dervishes, from 2004 to 2007. In that time, The Dervishes released one album, Possessed, and went on a successful 5-state tour of the Western United States. Krishna has also been a featured singer on over 50 albums with artists including Ho’olea, Anela, and Voyage.

Krishna Alexandra is the co-founder and CEO of Athena Solaris, an independent theatrical development com- pany in Las Vegas, Nevada. She has a BFA in Illustration, with a concentration in Experimental Theatre from the Academy of Art University in San Francisco, and is currently an MA candidate in Theatre at the University of Nevada, Las Vegas, where she is also creating new theatrical work and teaching undergraduate courses.

Lórien Patton (Music & Lyrics) is a singer-songwriter with a 25-year career spanning two coasts. She has written songs for NBC, and has appeared as a musical guest on the Tonight Show with Jay Leno, the Today Show with Katie Couric, Geraldo Rivera, and Sally Jesse Raphael. She has performed at hundreds of venues across the U.S., including CBGBs in New York City, Genghis Cohen and Molly Malone’s in Los Angeles, and the Milk Bar in San Francisco. Lórien has released 2 solo albums, and 1 live album with the band She Flies.

Lórien Patton is the co-founder and COO of Athena Solaris, an independent theatrical development company in Las Vegas, Nevada.

Sam Owen (Art Direction, Story Contributor) is a theatrical designer and illustrator. Sam completed a BFA in Illustration at the Academy of Art University and currently works as a freelance illustrator and designer in Las Vegas, Nevada. S/he was the art director for Itzayana: A Dream Circus, and is one of the founders of Athena Solaris, an independent theatrical development company in Las Vegas, Nevada.

Roudi Boroumand (Director of Projections) is a Nevada-based indie filmmaker and stage director. While her career focus is on filmic writing, producing and directing, she has also been an art and entertainment journalist and a freelance film studies translator and writer for two decades. Roudi has published work both in English and Persian on major figures of cinema and film analysis, and has been a collaborator with Cine-Eye and Cinema Scandinavia film magazines.

A graduate of Portland State University and North West Film Center in Portland, and a current film student at University of Las Vegas Nevada, Roudi Boroumand was recently the co-producer of Death to False Hipsters, an independent movie written and directed by Kathrina Bognot. 

Featuring...

Casey Keenan (Brigid O’Connor), a Texas native, began her musical studies at the Berklee College of Music before continuing on at the Texas Tech University Music School. She then continued her studies at the American Musical and Dramatic Academy in New York City, where she lives currently. She was awarded the Lincoln Center Artist of the Year Award in 2015 and then performed in the Radioactive Women’s Play Festival later that year. She currently studies at the BMI Musical Theater Workshop and looks forward to a solo engagement at the 54 Below venue in 2016. 



Krishna Alexandra (Nellie O’Brien) is a writer, director and performer with a 20- year career in theatre and music. Her acting credits include Buttercup in HMS Pinafore and Mama Euralie in Once on This Island at Dillingham Theatre, Yum-Yum in The Mikado at Kennedy Theatre, Irena Synkova in I Never Saw Another Butterfly at the Iolani Theatre, and Anna Areyevna in The Government Inspector with the Ilkhom West, directed by the legendary Mark Weill. She recently made her Las Vegas debut playing Madame Pace in Six Characters Looking for an Author at the Nevada Conservatory Theatre, directed by Jean Randich. 



Juliana Renee Martin (Meaghann McBride) was born in Las Vegas, but raised in Green Bay, Wisconsin and has returned home to complete her studies in the Stage and Screen Acting program at the University of Nevada, Las Vegas. Her acting roles have included Hope Harcourt in Anything Goes, Leonato in Much Ado About Nothing, Marjorie Baverstock in The Musical Comedy Murders of the 1940s, and Gertrude McFuzz in Seussical the Musical. 

Why Our Show Matters

Women have been written out of history, out of literature, out of popular entertainment, and out of theatre. For untold millennia, the cultural contributions of women have been either discounted or appropriated by men of power, and the preservation of the patriarchal social order has been prioritized at the cost of history, culture and truth. In the theatre, we have denied women agency, funding and opportunities at every turn, at great harm to the art form. The cultural suppression of women in the theatre has had a profound impact on the body of litera- ture studied, performed, and produced today.

My mission as an artist is to bring women’s stories to the forefront of the theatre. If I were to write nothing but women’s stories for the rest of my life, I could barely make a dent in the gender imbalance in theatre today, but every story I tell brings another woman out of the shadows, and helps to bring a bit more female representa- tion into the communal, cultural memory we share.

Communal, cultural memory is primarily defined not by the memories of living people, but by the stories and histories that narrate our memories of the past. The idea of cultural memory as a living process, rather than a static artifact, requires that we view the creation of cultural memory as active and mutable. Further, it requires that we, as citizens, artists, and historians, take some responsibility for the cultural memory that we are even now writing.

As theatre professionals, this responsibility is particularly profound, because theatre has always played an important role in this ongoing construction of history. If our communal, cultural memory is defined by the stories that we choose to tell, and the stories we choose to preserve, than we, as a theatre community, have some very difficult questions to face about the imbalance in gender representation in positions of creative power in the pro- fessional theatre. In the theatre world, women’s stories are often relegated to the same place as women’s studies are in academic circles: a dusty corner, not considered relevant to the general population. This shallow charac- terization of the experiences of fully half of humanity as being secondary or periphery to the core of academic study, or dramatic expression, is short-sighted and damaging to our cultural identity and our communal, cultural memory.

Women’s stories must be prioritized in the theatre, at least until a level of equal representation has finally been achieved. It is not merely a matter of fairness or opportunity. It is far more important than that. It is a question of our cultural heritage, and the cultural memory that we are passing on to our descendants. If we continue to write women’s stories out of the primary narrative of history, our culture will continue to fester with inequality and misogyny, and there will be no counter-narrative popular enough to be remembered.

As makers of theatre, we are the recipients of an ancient tradition of storytelling and memory-making. Now, as in every age, it comes to us to decide what kind of culture we are trying to build, and who is invited to participate fully in it.

What We Need

The following expense list includes some items which we hope to borrow or for which we expect to receive discounted rental rates. As such arrangements have not yet been finalized, the current budget is based on com- mercial rates.

  • Location Rental: $3000
  • Scenic Design & Construction: $1010
  • Prop Rental: $540
  • Sound Equipment Rental: $2500
  • Costumes: $800
  • Projection Content: $5000
  • Travel: $700
  • Printing: $500
  • SUBTOTAL: $9050
  • Contingency: $950
TOTAL ADDITIONAL EXPENSES: $15000

Additional Expected Support

The University of Nevada Las Vegas Department of Theatre and the Nevada Conservatory Theatre are generously supporting our production with the loan of materials and equipment. The following items will be provided by them free of charge:

  • Flats
  • Platforms
  • Raised Walkway 
  • Projection Screen
  • Furniture
  • Props
  • Costumes
  • Wigs
  • Shoes
We are requesting additional funds from the UNLV Student Government to cover the costs associated with the projection components. We are also pursuing additional loans of equipment and materials from a variety of sources. 

Other Ways You Can Help

Whether or not you can contribute financially to our campaign, we would love for you to be a part of this show. Like us on Facebook, post and tweet about our campaign using #dublinrising , and tell your friends to come see our show!

We are also in need of advertising and material donations. For more information, contact the Team.

Shoes

We are requesting additional funds from the UNLV Student Government to cover the costs associated with the projection components. We are also pursuing additional loans of equipment and materials from a variety of sources. Other Ways You Can HelpWhether or not you can contribute financially to our campaign, we would love for you to be a part of this show. Like us on Facebook, post and tweet about our campaign using #dublinrising , and tell your friends to come see our show!We are also in need of advertising and material donations. For more information, contact the Team.

story:
Harry and the Thief

Strand Theater Company, dedicated to celebrating women's diverse voices and perspectives, is thrilled to present to Baltimore audiences a regional premiere of Harry and the Thief by Sigrid Gilmer - an audacious play about slavery,  sacrifice, revolution, and one of Maryland's most beloved historical figures - Harriet Tubman. Oh, and it's a comedy. 

Synopsis: "Jeremy has a Ph.D. in physics from Harvard. And a time machine. And a plan. Jeremy's plan is to send his thieving cousin Mimi back in time to 1863 to find Harriet Tubman and give her guns. Lots and lots of guns. "

Directed by Susan Stroupe.

Here's the story

Harry and the Thief is an ambitious project that involves a cast of ten actors and a highly skilled creative team in order to bring Sigrid's vision to life. Every cent we raise through this campaign will be used to compensate our actors and designers. In the world of theatre, where these talented artists are often underpaid, we ask for your help to reward them fairly.

We love our donors! To say thank you, we have some fun perks in store - see the column at right for details. 

The Impact

Did you know that only about 20% of all theatre produced nationally every year is written or directed by a woman or a person of color? We think that number should be higher! That's why the Strand remains steadfast in its commitment to diversity of women's voices, by offering opportunities to women artists in every aspect of a theatre production!

We feel that Sigrid Gilmer's play is a very timely story for our Charm City that grapples with complex issues of race and diversity.

Please join us in fighting the good fight for diversity and inclusion in theatre and beyond, by supporting Harry and Thief! 

Other Ways You Can Help

Whether you support us today with a donation or not, please do join us for a performance of Harry and the Thief. We'll be performing at St. Mark's Lutheran Church, 1900 St. Paul Street in Baltimore's Station North neighborhood. The show dates are March 31-April 10. Visit www.strand-theater.org to purchase tickets online. 

See you at the show—and thanks for your support!

story:
Images is a one-woman play about the life of Eva Schloss.  Eva is Anne Frank's step-sister and childhood friend.  The two girls played together frequently before World War II tore their lives apart.  

Just like Anne and her family, Eva's family was captured by the Nazis, while in hiding, and was sent to Auschwitz.  They survived nine torturous months in Auschwitz under the watchful eye of Dr. Mengele.  By the end of the war only Eva and her mother would survive --- her father and brother perished following the forced march to Mauthausen.

The play tells the story of Eva's life, in retrospect with Eva in her eighties, via her recollections of events and video segments of recreations of important moments and family photos.  But it doesn't stop there.  It follows Eva's life after her release from Auschwitz and the wonderful work she has done up to the present day.  Eva has made it her mission in life to tell her story to the world in the hopes of helping people to understand the dangers of prejudice and discrimination.  She talks to groups of adults and children all over the world with the ultimate hope of educating people so that another Holocaust will never take place.  Her favorite groups to speak to are school children since she feels that they are the future caretakers of the world.

The play uses a professional actress in the role of Eva Schloss and following the premier production in Youngstown, Ohio, in August of 2016, the intent is to take the show on tour to other theater venues as well as many schools.  Eva is now in her late eighties and when the time arrives that she will no longer be able to travel, this play can help to fill that gap so that her story can live on and can continue to educate.

The world premier will take place at the Youngstown Playhouse and they are 100% on board with the project.  Their assistance and support has helped immensely to bring us this far.  We feel that the subsequent tour is very important in that it will help to supplement Holocaust education in many schools.  More and more schools are beginning to incorporate Holocaust education into their curriculums.  This show could be a valuable asset in many schools.

The funds we hope to raise will help to defray production costs for the world premier production, in August of 2016, which include the few  props needed plus video and editing costs.  They will also help with some promotion and advertising, although much of that will be done with the help of the Playhouse as well as online via two websites and social media.  These funds will also give us a boost toward the purchase of equipment to be used on tour; such as a computer and a video projector.  But the funding we are looking at right now is more crucial to getting the show off the ground in August so it can then move forward for a tour beginning in 2017.

Eva is in full support of this project and has authorized the script being used.  Eva, who lives in London, hopes to be present for the world premier in August of 2016.

What We Need & What You Get

This is only initial funding to help get the world premier production off the ground in August, 2016.  The unique thing about this production is that it is not a big budget show.  The impact is in the content of the actress on stage and the accompanying videos.  Set and props are intentionally kept to a minimum.  This initial funding will help to get things going with the production.  The ultimate goal for the show is to take it on tour, beginning in 2017, to schools and other theater venues in Ohio, Pennsylvania and West Virginia.  After that tour we then hope to increase the range of the tour.
What your contributions can achieve for you is described in the Perks section.  But beyond those Perks you will get the satisfaction that you helped to make this project a reality and you also had a hand in the increase in necessary Holocaust education, not only for students, but for people of all ages. 

The Impact

More and more schools are adding Holocaust education into their classrooms.  We are on the verge of losing all of our Holocaust survivors as most of them are now in their 80s and 90s.  Once they are gone, their stories go with them.  It is up to us to continue their stories and keep the education of what happened during the Holocaust alive.  We must pick up the gauntlet and keep this information available for all to see and hear.  That is what this show will help to do.  Eva travels the world telling her story but when the time comes that she can no longer do that, this show will be there to help fill that void.

Risks & Challenges

Any time you do a show about the Holocaust, and I have done several including a previous one about Eva, you run the risk of people thinking that it will be sad and depressing. But hearing Eva's story is anything but that. Sure there are sad moments but Eva's story is very uplifting due to her outlook and determination. She survived the worst Nazi death camp and has used her experiences to educate the world.

We intend to emphasize the positive side of her story, and the play, in all of our promotion and advertising. Hearing her story is a positive experience that everyone remembers after hearing it. We have great hopes for the school tour since the Holocaust has seen such a resurgence in the curriculum of many schools across the country.

We will also supplement all performances, but especially the school ones, with a question and answer session following the show so that students can learn more about what they have just seen. There are also plans to offer a study guide so that teachers can then go back to the classroom following the performance and use it along with their other Holocaust study materials.

Another danger with Holocaust material in a show stems from the fact that some people feel that nothing more needs to be said about the Holocaust --- "we know all about that." But judging from recent history, we apparently don't know enough --- because similar things continue to happen. It is our responsibility to keep stories about the Holocaust out there not only to help deter re-occurances but also as a way to honor all of those people who suffered through it, particularly the millions that were murdered. Holocaust survivors are dying at an alarming rate --- we have to continue to tell their stories.

The Holocaust has been an interest of mine since I directed my first production of "The Diary of Anne Frank" more than 30 years ago. I have gone on to write several successful and powerful plays about the Holocaust.

We look forward to you being a part of this very important project.

Other Ways You Can Help

We realize that no everyone is in  position to make a contribution.  That is understandable.  But there are other ways you can help.  Help us get the word out about the production.  Tell others about our campaign on Indiegogo and encourage them to visit our page so they can see, first hand, what it is all about.  Also, please go to our website at www.evaschlossstory.com and our Facebook page at www.facebook.com/EvaSchlossStory and encourage others to do so as well.

story:
Have you ever wondered what it might be like to be abducted by Aliens?

If an alien race chose you to take around the galaxy, would you go?  What would you hope to see?  Would you be scared or excited?  What and who would you miss?

My play, "That's My Moonbeam!," explores these ideas as well as the all too human themes of escapism, love, lust, sexuality, and commitment.  A marriage is put to the test, as is a friendship, and if this wasn't enough, the universe is at stake!

I love this play.  I love the characters, their dreams and realities, their passions and their insecurities.  Putting this play on at the NYC FRINGE Festival 2016 means finally giving you the chance to love them as well!

The best part is that it's ALREADY BEEN ACCEPTED!

That's right!  The hard part is done.  The writing and editing, the submission and the waiting and the waiting and the waiting...  

We've been accepted.  But that's just the start of a whole new battle.  The NY FRINGE Fest only secures you a space during the festival.  They do not cover any production costs.  

We're not asking for anything otherworldly.

Our budget begins with the $700 participation fee.  We need to have this secured by April 15.  If that doesn't happen, then the play probably won't make it to this festival.

Everything on top of that goes into production expenses:

  • Production fee : $700
  • Costumes : $300
  • Set design / construction / dressing : $3000
  • Publicity : $1000
  • Rehearsal space and meals for cast: $300
  • Sound Design : $300
  • Cast and Crew stipends: $1150
  • Cast Party : $250

I'm no space cadet.

I have been involved in the New York City Theater scene for around nine years.  

For four years I workshopped and produced the plays Parrallax (2008), Swallow (2009), and Impending Sense of Doom (2010) with the Subjective Theatre Company.  My play SPAN was staged by Meat and Bone Theater Company in 2011.  My short play Stall  was staged at Tiny Rhino in 2012.  I am also a screenwriter, novelist, and the Hip Hop Editor for The Deli Magazine.

A SAG actor (under the name Theodore Copeland) and producer, I have an extensive community of talented actors, directors, artists, and tech available and enjoy putting teams together.  I'm lucky enough to call these soulful and amazing folks my friends, and collaborations like this are what keep us all sane.

Eyes on the Skies.

The script is in it’s tenth draft.  It was performed as a staged reading at a Scarlet Fox Salon in 2013, and a scene from it was read in 2015 at an Undiscovered Countries literary salon.  It’s a lighthearted examination of the distances we maintain within and without, estrangement, and love.  Elements of Hip Hop culture, Gender and Sexuality, and Science Fiction cavort as the five characters get to know each other and themselves.

Be a Beacon.

I'm an artist.  It's not all about money.  If you're hard up for funds, it's all good.  But if this project sounds cool, please help spread the word.  If you have friends in NYC, shoot them the link.  We'd love to have you all in the house on opening night!

story:
Dear friends,

We have just begun a wonderful adventure! wandering movers is a dance company that was begun by artistic director/choreographer Kevin Ortega-Rojas earlier this year. Kevin uses his hip-hop background and contemporary dance training to create movement that is captivating and expressive. On April 30th, wandering movers debuted their new work 'lost in the right direction' and received amazing feedback from audience members. We are going to take everything that we heard into consideration while we continue to fine-tune or repertoire for future performances. 

Our company is set to perform at different venues around the country this summer in places like New York, Michigan, Virginia and more. We really believe that audiences everywhere will enjoy and connect to our work and we're excited to get to them. We may need some help. That's where you come in. 

The cost of travel expenses, space rental, dancer stipends and othermiscellaneous artist fees really adds up, especially when you're a brand new company that audiences aren't familiar with. We are using this crowd-funding platform to raise money to help us continue to grow as a company and perform for audiences around the country. Donations of any size will be accepted and greatly appreciated. As an incentive to donate, we will be offering perks to all of our donors to thank them for their support. Descriptions of perks are at the bottom of this page.

If you would like to support our company's goal but can't donate yourself, please share this post and help us spread our message. Thank you for time and consideration. We hope you will attend one of our shows soon. Find us on Facebook , Instagram and on our website for more information on our company, dancers and future performance dates.

Thank You Gifts 

$1- $24 - Public acknowledgement on our social media pages and a personal thank you video made by a company member.

$25 - $49 - The above gifts as well as a copy of our program from our debut performance signed by the dancers.

$50 - $99 - The above gifts as well as the opportunity to come to a company rehearsal and witness what our process is like.

$100 - 199 - The above gifts as well as a DVD copy of our work 'lost in the direction' 

$200 or more - The above gifts as well as a contemporary workshop class for up to 6 people led by our company dancers. Class will include a contemporary ballet warm-up, across the floor combinations and repertoire.
