story:
WHO are you now?

My name is Michelle Lunicke. I'm a genderqueer writer and performer. My mother told me if I had been born male my name would be Ryan. Ryan is me too, regardless of what's in my trousers. I also go by Ren, which is my androgynous name.

"Ze": queer as f*ck! is my second solo autobiographical comedy show about my coming out experiences. It chronicles the discovery and rediscovery of my identity through the years, feeling a foothold on every LGBT float in the metaphorical pride parade. ("Ze" is a gender neutral pronoun alternative for he or she.)

This is my most intensely personal, risky, revealing, controversial work to date about sex, gender, and all of it....and I need the support of my international community. While "coming out" stories are niche, the through-line in them is not. We all seek belonging somewhere. It is deeply important to have stories that express honest and complex experiences we can all relate to. I hope this show will reach out to people who share my struggle for pride in a culture that is reflexively shaming (even within pockets of "tolerant society.")


What's with the title?

It's a reaction to the world (both the LGBT world and the hetero-normative world) about labels and the compulsion to explain oneself when equally craving authentic identity and accepting community. This can be frustrating, hence the need for cursing, quickly followed by laughter.


Best Made Plans:

"Ze" is touring fringe festivals in Australia and New Zealand in 2016, with plans to also tour Canada and the U.S later in the year. This funding request is for the Australia and New Zealand leg of my tour. If successfully funded, I hope to bring it to the U.S. and Canada with better means. With your help the reach will be huge.


The Need: Publicity and Traveling Expenses

My tour is multi-tiered, and I won't see any ticket sales for even one season until months after I am finished with the next. I want to pass this forward to bring the show to you, but I need to send out posters and flyers in advance, eat a few veggies a day, and survive until then. The Australia and New Zealand tours combined cost is about $20,000. I know!!!! Relax, breathe, there are five cities involved.

Publicity (printing and distribution, as well as advertisements) is approximately 24% of my budget.

About 20% is my traveling expenses including food, shelter, transportation to my venue (not including airfare), and other basic needs over a combined nine week period.


Success, Shame, and Pride

Last year (2015) I successfully raised almost $1,700 for my show I'm from Up Over. It helped so much and was a fabulous experience. I got some great feedback, but it wasn't enough to land my pie-in-the-sky expectations for funding the next show. 

So I got a job in a cafe. I wanted to earn all the money for this year's show.  I was  determined to make "Ze" better, smarter, and with a long enough run to have some  incredible artistic growth. I've done that. I'm doing fourteen times more shows than last year. Last year's five performances is this year's 70. I have a wonderful team and a great director, Mr. Peter Larsen, and I am already getting great feedback from the local LGBT communities where my show will play.

But I still need help, and I was embarrassed to ask for it a second time. The last successful campaign lasted over a month. This one lasts just 20 days. Twenty days of rehearsals and previews ending just before my official opening February 7th, 2016. I am late, but trust you to catch me. I am committed to making great theatre, great art, and growing into my place in the arts world. Here's my write-up about it. I've gone full-tilt.


Perks and YOU

If you're not in New Zealand or Australia, you might feel detached from the aims of this campaign. Please understand I am doing everything to bring this show to you. I am already lined up to tour Canada and plans for the US are in the works. This came about by a bit of tremendous good luck and I want to seize the opportunity. The better a success I can make the show here via your help, the more feasible it is for me to take those opportunities.

Those of you who have given a donation in the past, THANK YOU! Without your help I would not have discovered so clearly what I love and need to continue to do. You have made this possible.

Those of you who can give a donation again, or can give for the first time, I offer my love and a few tokens of affection (perks). Most importantly, I offer you this show. It's a show I am humbled by, and can't wait to have you in the audience for.

Those of you who can only help me in other ways, help me by spreading the word about this show and this campaign, which is asking for the same drop of money as least year, in a much much bigger bucket. If you are in New Zealand or Australia, share my events links on facebook! Come to the show! Talk about it! Follow my feeds so you can find out when I might come to you.

Blessings to you all. I make this art out of my trust for your love and acceptance and I thank you for proving that trust is well-laid.

P.S. To see my revived blog and info about the tour as it unfolds, please see "Ze" page. You can also follow me on my facebook artist page and twitter feeds for daily updates as I tour.
story_txt:
WHO are you now? My name is Michelle Lunicke. I'm a genderqueer writer and performer. My mother told me if I had been born 
male my name would be Ryan. Ryan is me too, regardless of what's in my 
trousers. I also go by Ren, which is my androgynous name. "Ze": queer as f*ck! is
 my second solo autobiographical comedy show about my coming out 
experiences. It chronicles the discovery and rediscovery of my identity 
through the years, feeling a foothold on every LGBT float in the 
metaphorical pride parade. ("Ze" is a gender neutral pronoun alternative
 for he or she.) This is my most intensely personal, 
risky, revealing, controversial work to date about sex, gender, and all 
of it....and I need the support of my international community. While
 "coming out" stories are niche, the through-line in them is not. We all
 seek belonging somewhere. It is deeply important to have stories that 
express honest and complex experiences we can all relate to. I hope this
 show will reach out to people who share my struggle for pride in a 
culture that is reflexively shaming (even within pockets of "tolerant 
society.")

What's with the title?
It's
 a reaction to the world (both the LGBT world and the hetero-normative 
world) about labels and the compulsion to explain oneself when equally 
craving authentic identity and accepting community. This can be 
frustrating, hence the need for cursing, quickly followed by laughter.
Best Made Plans:"Ze"
 is touring fringe festivals in Australia and New Zealand in 2016, with 
plans to also tour Canada and the U.S later in the year. This funding 
request is for the Australia and New Zealand leg of my tour. If 
successfully funded, I hope to bring it to the U.S. and Canada with 
better means. With your help the reach will be huge.  The Need: Publicity and Traveling ExpensesMy
 tour is multi-tiered, and I won't see any ticket sales for even one 
season until months after I am finished with the next. I want to pass 
this forward to bring the show to you, but I need to send out posters 
and flyers in advance, eat a few veggies a day, and survive until then. 
The Australia and New Zealand tours combined cost is about $20,000. I 
know!!!! Relax, breathe, there are five cities involved.Publicity (printing and distribution, as well as advertisements) is approximately 24% of my budget. About
 20% is my traveling expenses including food, shelter, transportation to
 my venue (not including airfare), and other basic needs over a combined
 nine week period.   Success, Shame, and PrideLast year (2015) I successfully raised almost $1,700 for my show I'm from Up Over.
 It helped so much and was a fabulous experience. I got some great 
feedback, but it wasn't enough to land my pie-in-the-sky expectations 
for funding the next show. So I got a job in a cafe. I wanted to earn all the money for this year's show.  I
 was  determined to make "Ze" better, smarter, and with a long enough 
run to have some  incredible artistic growth. I've done that. I'm 
doing fourteen times more shows than last year. Last year's five 
performances is this year's 70. I have a wonderful team and a great 
director, Mr. Peter Larsen, and I am already getting great feedback from
 the local LGBT communities where my show will play.But I 
still need help, and I was embarrassed to ask for it a second time. The last 
successful campaign lasted over a month. This one lasts just 20 days.
 Twenty days of rehearsals and previews ending just before my official 
opening February 7th, 2016. I am late, but trust you to catch me. I am committed to making great theatre, great art, 
and growing into my place in the arts world. Here's my write-up about it. I've gone full-tilt.  
Perks and YOUIf
 you're not in New Zealand or Australia, you might feel detached from the aims of this campaign. Please understand I am doing everything to bring this 
show to you. I am already lined up to tour Canada and plans for the US 
are in the works. This came about by a bit of tremendous good luck and I
 want to seize the opportunity. The better a success I can make the show here via your help, the more feasible it is for me to take those opportunities.Those
 of you who have given a donation in the past, THANK YOU! Without your help I would
 not have discovered so clearly what I love and need to continue to do. 
You have made this possible. Those of you who can give a 
donation again, or can give for the first time, I offer my love and a 
few tokens of affection (perks). Most importantly, I offer you this show. It's a show I am humbled by, and can't wait to have you in the audience for. Those of you who can only help me in other ways, help
 me by spreading the word about this show and this campaign, which is 
asking for the same drop of money as least year, in a much much bigger 
bucket. If you are in New Zealand or Australia, share my events 
links on facebook! Come to the show! Talk about it! Follow my feeds so 
you can find out when I might come to you.Blessings to you all. I
 make this art out of my trust for your love and acceptance and I thank 
you for proving that trust is well-laid.P.S. To see my revived 
blog and info about the tour as it unfolds, please see "Ze" page. You 
can also follow me on my facebook artist page and twitter feeds for 
daily updates as I tour.

story:
Lighthouse Theatre

was launched in 2010. Since then we have developed a track record in delivering imaginative, stimulating and entertaining theatre throughout Wales and beyond (we have chalked up three tours of South America and Patagonia to date). We have produced adaptations of work by Shakespeare, Dylan Thomas, Noel Coward, Goldsmith and many others, as well as our own original and site specific pieces. We have pioneered performance walking tours of several towns and cities, even including one on bikes.... - Life Cycle Of The Bay.

Some years ago we came across a series of novels which totally enthralled us - the Aberystwyth series by Malcolm Pryce. Written in a delicious prose style, the critics hailed the first book as 'sweeping you away into a funfair mirror world of grotesque characters and absurd situations' and the series has coined the phrase 'Welsh Noir'. The first book in the series, 'Aberystwyth Mon Amour' became a global hit and has a huge following.  It is an affectionate homage to the 1950s Raymond Chandler detective series - our hero Louie Knight a down-at-heel gumshoe detective. Only our detective isn't in LA, but Aberystwyth. And the criminal element isn't the Mafia but a secretive druid cartel seeking to destroy the town.

Witty, sharp and highly comic the books seemed to us to be intensely theatrical. But how come no one had ever tried to put them on stage? We asked Malcolm this question and he said that he would like to have a go. Buoyed by this vote of confidence we undertook a Research and Development process to deliver a really sharp play script of Aberystwyth Mon Amour, supported by Arts Council Wales. The project was a huge success and the word on the street was that the play should tour in a major production.

Once again the Arts Council have backed the project despite stringent cuts and other fiscal pressures, but with a large cast and ambitious production values our grant so far does not meet our basic budget requirements. We are £5000 short of being able to make this show the very best it can be, pay our actors a basic wage, and take the show to the maximum number of audience members possible. The funds will be spread across a range of areas; Wages, Costume And Design spend, Travel and Accommodation, Marketing and Publicity. Undoubtedly the 'show will go on', but the extra funding will be vital to its success. We know - all to well - how many demands there are on your generosity but a donation of just £5.00 will be a huge help towards our hitting our target.

If a donation is not possible then all you need to do is forward the link to your friends and contacts who may like to come along and see the show, or better still, come along and see the work for yourself.

We are very grateful to you for taking the time to visit this page and read this far.  Looking forward to seeing you out there!

story:
What is it? 

People of the Eye is an autobiographical piece of theatre based on writer/performer Erin Siobhan Hutching's family experiences growing up with a deaf family member. The Deaf & Hearing Ensemble are looking for help to take the show to the Edinburgh Fringe, to share it with an international fringe-going audience including influential programmers, reviewers and importantly, the Deaf community who may not be able to access many of the shows at the Fringe Festival. In line with our commitment to outreach and developing young artists, we will be running workshops alongside the performances which are open to all, Deaf and hearing, for free. 

“Of course, you shouldn’t use ‘sign language’.”

Inspired by real events, this personal story follows a family finding their way through unfamiliar territory to discover their own voice. A story about parents, about sisters, and about the complex love that binds families together.

Using a mix of video projections, sound, live performance, and creative accessibility, this unique performance is about memories, feelings of isolation, and finding the joy in difference.

People of the Eye has been developed with The Deaf & Hearing Ensemble, in particular with director Jennifer K Bates and deaf actresses Sophie Stone and Emily Howlett, across the last 2 years, with each artist contributing personal experiences and developing a deep connection to the project. 

The piece has just finished an Arts Council England supported run at London's Yard Theatre, selected from over 200 applications to be part of their NOW'16 festival, with mentorship and in a double bill with Forest Fringe Co-Artistic Director Ira Brand. It has now been chosen to be part of the acclaimed Northern Stage progam at Summerhall at the Edinburgh Fringe. This is a clear indication of the potential of this project, and the excitement generated in the Arts and Deaf communities about it. 

"An arresting, immersive and startlingly original piece of theatre. A beautiful, tightly choreographed spectacle...something very special indeed." A Younger Theatre

"The love between the two characters is palpable and you leave the piece warmed by it while questioning why society is so fussed about difference." Huffington Post

The Deaf & Hearing Ensemble has just received a Research & Development grant for a new show from The Samuel Beckett Theatre Trust and the Barbican, indicating the quality of our work, and the need for it. 

Who are we?

Erin Siobhan Hutching (writer/performer), Emily Howlett (deviser/performer), Jennifer K. Bates (director), Sophie Stone (deviser), Samuel Dore (videographer), Emma Houston (sound designer), Myriddin Wannell (designer), Oliver Savidge (lighting designer), Rachel Sampley (technical manager), David Monteith-Hodge (photography and promotional videos), Nadia Nadarajah (movement/outside eye) Emily Salter (intern), Rachael Merry (intern), 

We won't all be going to Edinburgh but we have all put our love and talent into this project!

Why does it matter?

The Ensemble is so passionate about this project and about telling this story, which will resonate with anyone who has experienced being different, the "odd one out" for any reason, and for the people who care for and about them. You could be forgiven for thinking the world is becoming a less tolerant place. Please help us take this honest, joyful, poignant show to the largest theatre festival in the world, and change some perspectives!

Being programmed in such a respected theatre venue will begin to pave the way for other accessible work being part of mainstream theatre programming, to allow D/deaf audiences the access they deserve. We are not a community or outreach theatre group (although we applaud these groups) we are professional artists making high quality, innovative theatre we believe in. 

We are also passionate about providing opportunities for training for D/deaf young people, who often experience barriers to access when they audition for Drama Schools and other forms of training. We will be running workshops in London (at Southwark Playhouse) for young people and in Edinburgh (with Fringe Central) for all ages to allow D/deaf and hearing people the opportunity to work together in a creative environment. These will be free to attend. 

What We Need & What You Get

  • Facilitator fees to run our workshops - £500
  • Communication Support Workers to assist at our workshops - £500
  • Fees for our professional artists for rehearsals - £1300
  • Transporting our set - £250
  • Travel and accommodation costs - £700
  • Ensuring our video captions make our performance accessible- £350

We are fortunate enough to have received support from Northern Stage, Boshier Hinton Foundation and Birkdale Trust for the Hearing Impaired to cover the majority of the costs of running the workshops and performing at the festival. We need this bit extra to ensure our artists can be properly paid and everything is accessible. If we do not reach our entire goal, we will prioritise our workshops, production and accessibility costs to ensure that the show can go on! Rest assured that we have set a flexible goal because we are determined to ensure this project goes ahead, so your money will go to very good use.

The Perks

  • £5 - Love it or hate it, social media is here to stay! A £5 contribution will get you a shoutout on Facebook AND Twitter
  • £10 - A shoutout on social media plus a thank you email from the team containing exclusive rehearsal pictures.
  • £20 - A shoutout on social media and a beautiful postcard from the artists in Edinburgh during the run of the show.
  • £30 - A shoutout on social media, and a ticket to our preview performance at Southwark Playhouse in London with a thank you card from the cast given to you in person after the show! If you cannot make the preview performance, we will send the thank you card to you in the mail with a signed production shot from the show.
  • £40 - A shoutout on social media, and a personalised video message from our company mascot, Emily's hearing dog George! 
  • £50 - A shoutout on social media and a ticket to a performance of your choice at the Edinburgh Fringe Festival!
  • £100 - A shoutout on social media and a 25 minute 1:1 BSL class on skype with the members of the cast! 
  • £250 - VIP - Two tickets to the show of your choice in Edinburgh, plus cocktails with the cast after the show!
  • £500 - VVIP - Two tickets to the show of your choice in Edinburgh, plus dinner and cocktails with the cast after the show! OR for companies within easily commutable distance of London or Edinburgh, this can cover a Deaf Awareness session with your employees. 

Risks & Challenges

Taking a show to the Edinburgh Fringe is a risky prospect. We have raised enough support, financial and in kind, to make this less risky than most shows going up. We are at one of the best venues, with a company (Northern Stage) which has a strong reputation who have chosen us to be part of their press day, ensuring we will have reviews before other shows. They will be providing volunteers to help promote our show as well as a fantastic PR company, both essential tools for getting audiences in at the Fringe.

With the current movement towards recognising the importance of diversity and accessibility, with #ActForChange, Sick of the Fringe, Unlimited and other initiatives, we are well placed for people to be interested in seeing our work. 

With the faith placed in us by organisations like Northern Stage, The Yard, The Barbican, The RSC, The Roundhouse and more, we have a strong track record. 

We are in a strong position to do well at the Fringe, with a little luck! With your investment, we can ensure the product that we present is as good as it can be. 

Other Ways You Can Help

We completely understand that not everyone can afford to donate to every crowdfunding campaign. But you can still help!

  • Please help us get the word out there - share across social media, using the Indiegogo share tools
  • If you have contacts in industries other than the arts who may be interested in supporting a theatre piece, or who are interested in accessibility, please do share this with them
  • Please come and see our show if you can! Check our website www.thedeafandhearingensemble.com for other opportunities to see it if you are not in Edinburgh in August
  • Follow us on twitter @DH_Ensemble and @People_OfTheEye, and Facebook www.facebook.com/thedeafandhearingensemble to help build our social media presence

Thank you so much! Feel free to get in touch for a chat, using any of the avenues above.

story:
The ChoreoJoey Project is in the process of creating a delightful evening of works based on revered Tall Tales and needs your help to complete it! 

The ChoreoJoey project started back in June 2014 as a challenge to create and present innovative, site specific dance with artists on any level. It often invokes the creative efforts of a rotating team of artists, musicians, and dance educators to display a high vector of integrated mixed media dance performance. The work developed through the ChoreoJoey Project explores various themes decided by its collaborators and contributors, directed by founder and choreographer Stephen Hill.

Our theme for the production this year is called Tall Tales. It will be an evening of ballets showing the relativity of life proceeding folklore and its many experiences that follow. It was a theme created through the process of rediscovering what Tall Tales are to us as children and how the morals within these tales affect cultural learning experiences through the perspective of adults.

Your contributions will assist in the production, turning our black box theater into a tropical rainforest set. Funding will aid in the creation and development of the choreography that will bring to life the fables of Aesop, The story of Anansi the Spider, two stories of Johnny Appleseed and Johnny the hammer with a twist, Verna Aardema’s tale of Why the Sky is So Far Away, and an original choreopoem written by Antonevia Ocho-Coultes. All the funding of the campaign goes directly to the production to assist with the cost of technical rehearsals, set and costume design, and the cost of the theater rental.  

The major inspiration behind the theme of this year’s production was the playful/larger-than-life aspects of stories and how those aspects can be used to teach morals through illustrations. Our main aim is to allow the illustrations to come alive through movement by letting the dance retell the tale, transporting the audience to a place and time where anything is possible.

story:
Hello Friend!

Thanks for joining this community with Syndee Winters (me!) and the "LENA" project. We've spent the last two years on this wonderful project, and great things have happened. We acquired a director,Logan Vaughn, and we are proud and relieved to announce our initiative of the next phase.
 

WE ARE TAKING LENA OFF-BROADWAY!!!
 

But, in order to accomplish this, we must produce a presentation ( It's more like a fancy audition) for theatrical investors and theatrical houses. If these folks like what they see, the next steps involve them producing our little skit (fingers crossed) in their theater.The presentation will be held in NYC at the decadent Duane Park, NYC. We have invited renowned theaters in New York City, to potentially become our new home. 

How Much?


The total cost of the presentation is $11,410.43
 

HOW IS THE MONEY SPENT?
With a big of magic and miracles, we are going to WOW these folks. But, putting on a show can be costly. Why? Because unfortunately, we can't ask world class musicians, management, dramaturg, director, wardrobe, stage managers, sound, cast and stage crew to be paid in hugs and high-fives. Your contributions go to them!

Cast Rehearsals 

The Team will work A LOT in a little amount of time. 

We will have production meetings from now until Showtime. 

I will cry, at least twice, until we reach our goal, put the show up, and when it's over...okay that's three times...

WHY Do This Now?
Who Runs The World? GIRLS! - Our world is finally beginning to recognize women as the most influential beings on the earth. In a world not too long ago, it wasn't thought of this way. Lena Horne was there. She was there as a woman, and a woman of color. She broke down barriers for, kicked down doors, and forged a path for many Black female artists to follow. Think about this, the music you love from the artists you love would not be here if it wasn't for Lena Horne. Eartha Kitt, Diana Ross, or BEYONCE would not exist.  It's time to tell her story of how she persevered through adversity. 

We at #TeamLena are excited to share this journey with you. We are grateful for your love and support in making this presentation a reality. I'm a believer in the strength of community, and together we can do it! And when we go to Broadway, YOU can say, you helped us get there!

ABOUT

LENA: A Moment With A Lady

As we approach the centennial of her birth, Lena Horne’s legacy lives on as we are transported back in time to remember, relate and relish with the one and only. Lena: A Moment With A Lady, set in 1981, Lena, played by Syndee Winters (Lion King, Pippin, Motown) constructs a narrative through words and music of some of her most pivotal personal and professional moments, which made her the multifarious women we all come to love. On a mission to share the truth and overcome adversity, she unexpectedly opens crevices that she has eluded for many years

She’s recognized as of the most influential African-American pioneers in entertainment. Ms. Horne collaborated with some of greatest musical artists of the 20th century, shattered the color barrier in Hollywood, and she was heavily involved with the civil rights movement. Lena Horne is not only recognized as a timeless beauty, inside and out, but she is cherished as an American Icon. 

Did you see the trailer? See it NOW!
Check out our on-air debut on FOX Good Day New York.
story_txt: Hello Friend!Thanks for joining this community with Syndee Winters (me!) and the "LENA" project. We've spent the last two years on this wonderful project, and great things have happened. We acquired a director,Logan Vaughn, and we are proud and relieved to announce our initiative of the next phase. WE ARE TAKING LENA OFF-BROADWAY!!! But, in order to accomplish this, we must produce a presentation ( It's more like a fancy audition) for theatrical investors and theatrical houses. If these folks like what they see, the next steps involve them producing our little skit (fingers crossed) in their theater.The presentation will be held in NYC at the decadent Duane Park, NYC. We have invited renowned theaters in New York City, to potentially become our new home. How Much?The total cost of the presentation is $11,410.43 HOW IS THE MONEY SPENT?With a big of magic and miracles, we are going to WOW these folks. But, putting on a show can be costly. Why? story:
“Superhuman effort isn’t worth a damn unless it achieves results.” - Sir Ernest Shackleton

Who better to receive endurance advice from than a man whose ship became wedged in an Antarctic ice floe, leaving him and his crew stranded for months on end?

With the intrepid spirit of Ernest Shackleton as our guide, Ernest Shackleton Loves Me is focused on results: We are about to open the show in the heart of Times Square in New York City, the center of the theatre world!

And that goal is within sight. Ernest Shackleton Loves Me is scheduled to officially open on May 7th and run through June 11th at the Tony Kiser Theater at Second Stage. The cast is rehearsing; the ad agency is strategizing; the marketing machine is moving; the tickets are selling! Previews begin April 14th. We'd love for you to join our team!

We feel fortunate that we hopped on-board The Tony Kiser Theater, as this venue has launched many successful projects onto Broadway, such as Dear Evan Hansen, Next to Normal, and the 25th Annual Putnam County Spelling Bee. Who knows where our ship will sail after this…

 

“I believe it is in our nature to explore, to reach out into the unknown. The only true failure would be not to explore at all.” - Sir Ernest Shackleton

Exploring the world of theater has been in my nature since I was young and opening a show in New York City has been a dream of mine for as long as I can remember. From 2001-2008, I was founder and Producing Artistic Director of Capitol Hill Arts Center in Seattle. And for the past eight years, I have produced the legendary Black Rock City pop-up restaurant Sacred Cow. And although I have produced over 15 world premiere plays in the past, Ernest Shackleton Loves Me will be my New York City theater debut. When that curtain opens on opening night, a dream of mine will be realized. You can be part of that excitement!

OK, so here’s what the show is all about: Ernest Shackleton Loves Me tells the story of a sleep-deprived single mom who struggles to balance her family and career as a video game music composer. Late one night, while posting a dating video, she receives an unexpected response from Sir Ernest Shackleton (1874-1922), who is stranded on an iceberg near the South Pole. Inspired by her music, he shares his heroic Antarctic journey with her in video and song (including actual video footage and photos from Shackleton’s 1917 Antarctic expedition). Against all odds, they discover that their greatest inspiration lies within each other.

Help us reach our destination! If you contribute, you’ll be a part of the journey! You may be able to visit the set, join the opening night party or host your own party out of town featuring a video recording of the show!

One of our crew has custom designed a special brass expedition pendant for this NYC journey. The pendent is water-jet cut and features a sextant on a field of mountains. One arm of the sextant has the tuning pegs of a violin. See "perks" to get yours shipped in time for Opening Night.

 

“By endurance we conquer” - Sir Ernest Shackleton

Ernest Shackleton Loves Me has endured. We’ve had full productions at the Seattle Repertory Theatre in April and May of 2014. And at George Street Playhouse in New Jersey in April and May of 2015. And at the Paramount at Arts Emerson in Boston in September and October of 2015.

We now are entering the rehearsal room:

 

And THE CRITICS LOVE US:

“An intrepid new musical. Exhilarating.” --New York Times (from our New Jersey show)
“Antartica has never seemed so warm. A deliriously light hearted love story!”  --Boston Globe
“Visually impressive, sonically inventive and whimsically diverting.” --Seattle Times
“A must see multi-media extravaganza”- The Examiner

Awards We Have Won:
Best Musical - Critic’s Choice, Broadway World, Seattle
Outstanding Musical Performance by an Actor - Boston Theater Critics Association, Elliot Norton Awards
Best Visiting Play - The Independent Reviewers of New England

And love us they should! We have a world- class crew aboard our production:

Starring the fierce and funny electro-violinist and rocker Valerie Vigoda as "Kat" a single mom video game composer.

Val also wrote the lyrics to Shackleton. Electric violinist, singer, writer, former Army lieutenant, and founding member of the band GrooveLily. She has toured the world with Cyndi Lauper, Joe Jackson and the Trans-Siberian Orchestra, and is now spreading her wings as a soloist, with her live-looping multimedia release Just Getting Good (inspired by the technology used in Ernest Shackleton Loves Me). She is the co-writer of many songs for Disney, as well as the scores for ten stage musicals.

And the courageous and charismatic Wade McCollum:

Wade originated the role of Ernest Shackleton at the Seattle Rep and went on to play Shackleton at George Street Playhouse and most recently in Boston at the Paramount/Arts Emerson where he won the Norton award for best actor in a musical. Wade has also been seen on Broadway in Wicked, in S.F. in Jersey Boys and also starred in the first national tour of Broadway's Priscilla Queen of the Desert as Tick/Mitzi.

Directed by Obie award-winning director Lisa Peterson.

New York: The Model Apartment (Primary Stages); Slavs!, Traps and Light Shining in Buckinghamshire (Obie Award), The Waves (two Drama Desk nominations), all at New York Theatre Workshop; The Scarlet Letter (CSC, world premiere). New Play Development: Sundance, The Playwrights' Center, New Dramatists, Young Playwrights' Festival, Taper New Works Festival, Audrey SkirballKenis, NY Stage and Film, Royal Court London. Lisa is the Associate Artistic Director at Berkeley Repertory Theatre.

Written by Tony award-winner Joe DiPietro:

Joe has won two Tony Awards, a Drama Desk Award and two Outer Critics Circle Awards.  One out-of-town scribe referred to Ernest Shackleton Loves Me as the weirdest thing the author has ever written.  He happily agrees.  Less weird work includes Broadway: Nice Work If You Can Get It (Tony nom – Best Musical), Memphis (Tony winner – Best Musical, Best Book, Best Score),  All Shook Up, Living on Love. Off-Broadway: Clever Little Lies, The Toxic Avenger, The Thing About Men, Over the River and Through the Woods, I Love You, You’re Perfect, Now Change.

 

Composed by Brendan Milburn:

Selections from Brendan's musicals include: Striking 12 (Off-Broadway & regional), Sleeping Beauty Wakes (CTG, McCarter, La Jolla), Wheelhouse (TheatreWorks), Toy Story: The Musical (Disney), Long Story Short (regional & Off-Off Broadway), Watt?!? (Village Theatre), The Behavior of Broadus (CTG, Sacred Fools). Film: four movies about Tinker Bell (Disney).  Awards: Jonathan Larson (2006, 2008), ASCAP/Richard Rodgers (2009), LA Ovation for music direction and best musical (2007), LA Drama Critics Circle for best musical score (2015), LA Stage Raw for best musical, best score (2015), LA Ovation Award for best musical, best music and lyrics (2015).

Production design by Alexander V. Nichols:

Alex's Broadway credits include: Wishful Drinking, Hugh Jackman - Back On Broadway, Nice Work If You Can Get It. His designs are in the permanent repertory of San Francisco Ballet, Boston Ballet, Alvin Ailey American Dance Theater, Hubbard Street Dance, Hong Kong Ballet, Singapore Dance Theatre, ODC/SF and the Royal Winnipeg Ballet.

Music Direction, Orchestrations and Additional Music by Ryan O'Connell:

Sound design by Rob Kaplowitz:

Rob is reuniting with past collaborators Lisa Peterson, Joe DiPietro and Alexander Nichols. He was honored in 2007 with a "Sustained Excellence in Sound Design" OBIE award and a 2010 Tony Award for Fela!, which subsequently toured the States as well as visiting London, Amsterdam and Lagos. He's pretty sure he's designed more than 300 productions, installations and development projects by now.

Music Supervision by Curtis Moore.

And inspired by: Sir Ernest Shackleton.

One of the most inspirational leaders of the twentieth century. While he never achieved his personal dream of being the first to reach the South Pole, his reputation as a leader of men is based on a still greater success: the survival and safe return of all of his team members, whilst overcoming almost unimaginable odds. Shackleton’s name lives on as a synonym for courage, bravery and most of all, leadership.

 

“Optimism is true moral courage” - Sir Ernest Shackleton

This is a watershed moment in the history of the world and no one knows what the future may bring. The world needs optimism now! And Ernest Shackleton Loves Me is here to bring it -through girl power, hope, adventure, miracles, technology, and innovation. Our heroine struggles against everything the world can throw at her and ultimately triumphs when she finds that hope (and an epic adventure) can truly create miracles. And Ernest Shackleton Loves Me is high-tech! We use live green screen technology and we create the score live onstage. How’s that’s for courage?

Operating Budget:

Off-Broadway shows in NYC today can range in budget from $450k to $1.5M, depending on the scale of the production, size of the theatre and size of the advertising budget.

Ernest Shackleton Loves Me has a total budget of $1M. In order to continue to expand the production (see below) we need a little bit extra help from our friends (you). Budget so far is:

  • Physical Production (Set, Costumes, Video, Props): $150,000
  • Creative and Company Salaries: $175,000
  • Advertising & Marketing: $125,000
  • Labor for Load-In & Technical Production: $75,000
  • Corporate (Legal, Accounting, General & Administrative): $100,000
  • Theatre Rent and Personnel: $125,000
  • Aggregate Running Costs: $250,000

So what do we need your money for? Well, in NYC we have some exciting new changes we would like to add:

  • Two brand new songs including a new opening number and an epic "man versus nature" number for Shackleton. These songs need to be written, orchestrated and rehearsed.
  • We need more blizzard! More snow machines to create the reality of Antarctica. And, lots and lots of actual prop snow.
  • New songs and new ideas require new video...more shooting, editing and implementation.
  • New props: a new rifle, bosun whistle (look it up!), lots more musical instruments for lots more live looping
  • New costumes: there are two new characters!

Get Onboard: What You Get

EARLY BIRD REWARD: Ernest Shackleton trekked without a break for 36 hours over glacier-clad mountains thousands of feet high to arrive at the whaling station. Let’s honor that effort by rewarding those who donate in the first 36 hours. Everyone that donates in the first 36 hours will get a limited edition bonus gift of an Antarctic Expedition Patch in the style of Ernest Shackleton Loves Me (This will be shipped in time for the show!). 

By contributing to Ernest Shackleton Loves Me, you are officially part of the crew!

Note that all contributions on this campaign are donations and not investments. But by donating, you are joining our family, a company of artists, technicians, designers, marketers, friends, family, and the thousands of audience members who have joined us in Seattle, NJ and Boston. Are you one of those already? Sign up and get your SWAG!

Congrats and welcome to an epic adventure! Hope to see you in NYC -- when you come please stop by and say hello.

Company "Meet and Greet" on Friday, April 7th, 2017 at the Tony Kiser Theatre at Second Stage.

story:
Theatre Iridescence presents

TRANSIT

an original musical

Written by Aya Kawakami          Directed by Jessica A. Robison

Music by David Freeman, Aya Kawakami, and David Dycus

 

Mina, a former actress of mixed descent, falls for Eric during his vacation in Hiroshima, where he was once a resident and local celebrity rock star. Despite their best friends’ disapproval, their romance results in a decision to cross oceans and change lives for a chance at happiness. Will it be different this time? Get a glimpse of life in a small English-speaking multicultural community as we accompany Eric and Mina and their friends Susan and Mike through a land where chopsticks are a part of daily life, “fireblossoms” fill the sky, and nothing ever really fits. This exciting new musical, which combines modern Eastern and Western music and stunning dance numbers, is a must see!

Dates and Times: July 1st, 1pm & 6pm and July 2nd, 1pm & 5pm 

Place: Nishi Playhouse (https://goo.gl/maps/AtaLMBwxFW52)

Tickets:  ADV: 2,500 yen, DOOR: 3,500 yen

Ticket Information: Tickets are available at the door, by email reservation nagoyatheatretickets@gmail.com or from Ticketpia.

Ticketpia Code: 457-913

 

Who we are:

Theatre Iridescence aims to create innovative, high quality works that promote intercultural understanding and celebrates diversity through the artists we feature on and off the stage and the range of stories we bring to life. Theatre Iridescence provides educational workshops and programs to aid those with a passion and commitment to theatre, more opportunities for growth and development. We also currently have an intern program for university students with our theatre company. And YOU could be a part of it!

 

With your help we will able to cover the cost of:

  • The programme
  • Promotional material (flyers and posters)
  • Ticket printing
  • Props, set and costumes
  • Basic salaries for our very talented cast and crew

 

Donors can receive:

  • The honour of contributing to arts as one of our donors on the Theatre Iridescence spectrum
  • A mention on show days in lobby
  • A link to a Backstage thank you video
  • A link to watch a recording of Transit
  • A mention on website as donor
  • A single rose for any cast or crew member of your choice
  • A bouquet of flowers sent to the cast or crew member of your choice

 

Why?

Help us encourage a more international and diverse perspective among members of our community, while helping  increase local educational opportunities in the arts.

Other Ways You Can Help:

Please like and share this page! Even if you can't contribute funds, you can join our email list to get updates on future shows and opportunities in theatre. We are actively looking for volunteers and sponsors!

nagoyatheatre@gmail.com

https://theatreiridescence.com

Many Thanks to our Sponsors!

The Cervesa http://japomex-thecerveza.com/

Cockney Hair & Beauty  http://www.cockney-hair.com/

Red Rock http://theredrock.jp/

Midtown BBQ http://midtown-bbq.com/

Yamanaka Dental Clinic http://yamanakashika.org/

Mina, a former actress of mixed descent, falls for Eric during his vacation in Hiroshima, where he was once a resident and local celebrity rock star. Despite their best friends’ disapproval, their romance results in a decision to cross oceans and change lives for a chance at happiness. Will it be different this time? Get a glimpse of life in a small English-speaking multicultural community as we accompany Eric and Mina and their friends Susan and Mike through a land where chopsticks are a part of daily life, “fireblossoms” fill the sky, and nothing ever really fits. This exciting new musical, which combines modern Eastern and Western music and stunning dance numbers, is a must see!
Dates and Times: July 1st, 1pm & 6pm and July 2nd, 1pm & 5pm 
Place: Nishi Playhouse (https://goo.gl/maps/AtaLMBwxFW52)
Tickets:  ADV: 2,500 yen, DOOR: 3,500 yen
Ticket Information: Tickets are available at the door, by email reservation nagoyatheatretickets@gmail.com or from Ticketpia.
Ticketpia Code: 457-913
 
Who we are:
Theatre Iridescence aims to create innovative, high quality works that promote intercultural understanding and celebrates diversity through the artists we feature on and off the stage and the range of stories we bring to life. Theatre Iridescence provides educational workshops and programs to aid those with a passion and commitment to theatre, more opportunities for growth and development. We also currently have an intern program for university students with our theatre company. And YOU could be a part of it!

 
With your help we will able to cover the cost of:

The programme
Promotional material (flyers and posters)
Ticket printing
Props, set and costumes
Basic salaries for our very talented cast and crew

 
Donors can receive:

The honour of contributing to arts as one of our donors on the Theatre Iridescence spectrum
A mention on show days in lobby
A link to a Backstage thank you video
A link to watch a recording of Transit

A mention on website as donor
A single rose for any cast or crew member of your choice
A bouquet of flowers sent to the cast or crew member of your choice


 
Why?
Help us encourage a more international and diverse perspective among members of our community, while helping  increase local educational opportunities in the arts.

Other Ways You Can Help:
Please like and share this page! Even if you can't contribute funds, you can join our email list to get updates on future shows and opportunities in theatre. We are actively looking for volunteers and sponsors!
nagoyatheatre@gmail.com
https://theatreiridescence.com
Many Thanks to our Sponsors!
The Cervesa http://japomex-thecerveza.com/
Cockney Hair & Beauty  http://www.cockney-hair.com/
Red Rock http://theredrock.jp/
Midtown BBQ http://midtown-bbq.com/
Yamanaka Dental Clinic http://yamanakashika.org/

story:
Ephemeral and ritual, sacred and profane - blackSKYwhite take you on a compelling trip through a magic and mysterious reality entirely orthogonal to our own.

 

This Moscow, Russia - based theater has thrilled audiences all over the world - including Burning Man in 2010 - and it is our goal and mission to bring their wonder back to the playa, but we need your help to make it happen.

Bringing international artists to the United States is not easy, and especially at the level of production values which make seeing blackSKYwhite memorable for a lifetime. We believe that their work will offer a revolutionary uniqueness and beautifully complement Burning Man 2017's theme: Radical Ritual.

Burning Man 2017 attendees will be able to witness blackSKYwhite at the Dust Circus camp on the playa - free of charge, liberating of mind, and welcome to all!

 

About blackSKYwhite

The concept of blackSKYwhite is based on creating new forms of interaction between the inner and outer world of the character.  "Radical", "Progressive", "Nontraditional", "Cultist", "Stylish" - these are just some of the epithets received by this unique Russian theatre which has invariably stood out since its inception in 1988, having since performed their inimitable work all over the globe.

 

BlackSKYwhite's performances are magical sights - incorporating computer graphics and the organic actor's bodily movements, music reaching from electronics to cabaret and ethnic style as well as stunning lighting effects which create a surreal world of great illusion, yet at the same time, a world that is very close and true.

blackSKYwhite have created, and continue to create a special technique of placing actors on the edge between reality and illusion - where performances are more of a dream than anything resembling real life. It is difficult to identify the genre of this theatre's stagings (as the word "genre" in itself implies some kind of traditionalism) and perhaps the company's style is closest to modern choreography in its most nonconformist form. The shows tell no story, reveal no plot, have no dimensions, or narrative. Rather, they mirror reality through dreams, bordering on that thin line between the outer and the inner worlds that interacts with the spectator through their own intuition or unconsciousness. As in the 'absolute mirror', every single person should see in each their work, an inner world and their own particular destiny. 

blackSKYwhite has received important awards for innovation in theater at FringeFirst - the international performing arts festival in Edinburgh, Scotland and have headlined performances at Glastronbury Festival.

 

Why Are We Raising Money?

Inviting blackSKYwhite to take part in Burning Man 2017 is the most amazing gift that we can give to the playa, but it is not without difficulty. The theater resides in and performs in Moscow, Russia - a long way to go for three humans and dozens of characters. We are handling their visas, invitations, airfare, tickets to the Burn, lodging, production logistics, and hosting them through their entire trip to the United States to spread amazingness and wonder.

We are raising money to cover the physical costs of their travel (airfare, et al), costume and prop shipping, planning for their playa survival and accommodations, as well as setting up an indoor and outdoor stage on the playa so that their art can be enjoyed by all.

Simply-put, the more we raise, the better we can make the experience - more lights, more effects, and they can bring more costumes and props!

In addition to their appearance at Burning Man 2017, we are looking to arrange three special events in Mountain View in September - stay tuned!

 

 

Of course, sometimes Dmitry and Marcella appear in default forms too....

 

Dust Circus - Burning Man Camp

Dust Circus is honored to bring blackSKYwhite to the playa at Burning Man 2017. Based in San Jose and Sacramento, California -  our camp has been present and growing at Burning Man since 2008 - offering performing arts and circus events. We are a community of carpenters, metal-workers, dancers, singers, fire-dancers, theater directors, actors, and lighting designers. 

In 2016, we could be found at 4:30 & B.

story:
The Production Team:


Alena Alena is a builder and the writer of this particular show, drawing from experience on stages in Milwaukee and all over the United States, creating drag and burlesque performances. Her passion and ability to tell stories within a given framework brought this fanfiction to life. She is driven to tell stories that evoke kindness, empathy, and above all inclusion. With a formal education in philosophy and political science she hopes to provide audiences with a show that’s led by heart and backed with brains. Alena excited to not only be part of building beautiful sets, but to also make cute nerdy rewards!

Tony is a composer and singer/songwriter, a member of Milwaukee's premier drag troupe, The Miltown Kings, and a geek with a dedication to merging fandom with burlesque and drag. As a serious Doctor Who fan, he has been helping with making the plot seamless and make sense within a fandom framework. His background in music along with his loyalty to Doctor Who and all its intricacies give him unique and exciting ideas for the show's choreography and blocking.

Lyndzi started the Dainty Rogues with a group of friends in 2012. She has been doing burlesque since 2010 with Milwaukee's own Brew City Bombshells, owns a geeky craft business, and is very passionate about the performing arts. The Dainty Rogues holds a special place in her geeky heart.

 

The Campaign:

This project aims to produce a 13 act burlesque fanfiction inspired by one of our all time favorite fandoms: Doctor Who. We plan to support the local artists, builders, performers, and creators of Milwaukee, WI - not only are the rewards local, but the entire production is local. If you support this campaign, you'd be taking a part of creating something phenomenal. Don’t just do it for us, do it for you because you genuinely need this kind of magic in your life. In a world where each dollar you spend is like casting a vote, vote to see strippers coming out of Daleks.

 

What we need and what you get:

The estimated cost of this production is much grander than past Dainty Rogue shows. For example, for the set of the first Dainty Rogue show “Clockwork Dolls,” set in a steampunk brothel, the director used her own bed as a set piece, and borrowed or bought at an antique store almost every prop or piece of furniture on that stage. We're hoping we can get past the beg, borrow, and barter stage, and actually build our set to our exact needs.

Tech & Special Effects Rentals - $1,058 - Includes Freezefog Pro rental, projector and screen rental, special effects lighting rental

Sets & Props - $1,144 Includes full sized TARDIS, Temporal engines, Timeglasses, and more!

Costumes - $2,693 Includes Daleks, Cybermen, Doctors, Companions, Missy and more!

Total Estimated Costs = $4,895

Our $5,000 goal has a $100 cushion for things like IndieGogo fees, credit card processing fees, and taxes.

Once building, we would use any found materials we could and put forward the money we save to the next show. Ticket sales go to paying venue, performers, builders, and stage crew.

 

Where will funds go if we don't reach our goal:

All of our flat costs would remain and the show would most definitely go on! Cuts would be made to anything that we are physically building. Designs would be simplified in all areas and we would most likely have to set up in a smaller venue. If we do not reach our goal we plan to have some fundraising events to help boost our budget.

If we earn beyond our goal, surplus would go to extra special effects, like the inclusion of pyrotechnics, or to fund a future Dainty Rogues Productions show.

 

Why is project valuable to the contributor and the WORLD:

There is truly nothing like this (of this kind or quality) that exists in Milwaukee (or even the Midwest for that matter). We will strive to provides artistic jobs to local artists. The current social climate needs as much art of inclusion as possible right now. Now is the time to change minds, but more importantly to make those on the fringes feel allied and less alone.

 

Risks and challenges:

Our greatest risk is that the demand for geeky burlesque isn't there. We don't believe this is the case. Whenever the Dainty Rogues have put on a show in the past, we have come close to selling out, and have had a great response to our style and type of art. A challenge that we will face is making sure enough of Milwaukee knows about the production to make this show more than just a 1 night only event. We want to have multiple showings and we'll need the support of our community to make that happen.

 

Overcoming hurtles:

This very campaign is a way for us to test the waters and see how eager Milwaukee is to have a production like this come to them. We also want to know if our neighboring cities get excited and want to see it happen and are willing to travel to Milwaukee to support us. If our goals are not reached, we know how to meet that audience with just as much love and enthusiasm from a smaller stage and an adjusted script. We just really believe in this show, and it will come to fruition any way we can.

We are in the very best position to make a production like this come to life. We have the necessary combination of talents between producers and their further connections, plus we have access to Milwaukee’s most talented burlesque performers, actors, costumers, and builders as all of the production team has been involved in the performing arts community for over 5 years.

 

Other ways you can help:

Get the word out and make some noise about this campaign! Share on Facebook, tell your D&D buddies, talk to people in and outside of Milwaukee and explain to them how magical this sounds and that they can help us too. Use the Indiegogo share tools to make it easy!

Fill out our participation quiz and let us know if you have something you’d like to contribute, would like to be involved as a performer or on the crew, or would like to volunteer building services.

When the time comes, we'll need help promoting the actual show by hanging up fliers in local business, maybe at your job, local restaurants and bars, and any community board we can find.

story:
Hi my name is Ashley Robicheaux, or Robi, and I am a performer, choreographer, and movement director. Over the past six years I have been choreographing new works and collaborating with artists in other mediums.  As previous performer in several immersive works, including Punchdrunk’s Sleep No More, Third Rail Project’s “The Grand Paradise” (originating cast member), and Emily Terndrup and Derrick Belcham’s “FABLE”, my experience as a performer has been largely immersive over the past 3 years. Aside from performing in immersive pieces, I have also been creating my own work and collaborating with other artists in a variety of environments including live music performances, installations, music videos and short films, as well as the for the proscenium stage. I am thrilled to be creating Mattress, both the largest-scale and most process-oriented work that I have directed thus far.

PREMISE:

The basic premise of Mattress is the abstraction of the human experience within a dreamscape through both physical and visual mediums. Our process will culminate into a week of immersive dance-theater performances as well as a short film following the characters we have developed.  We will be holding monthly work in progress showings at The Hollows Artspace in Williamsburg from February to June of 2017, where we will invite our audience to be part of our process and give feedback. In addition to these monthly showings, we will be creating an installation of this work at The Hollows in April.  Finally, in the fall of 2017, we plan to present a large-scale version of this work.  Because of the multiple forms this work will take on, we believe Mattress will reach a wide range of audiences that extends beyond the dance community. 

COLLABORATORS:

Several members of the Mattress team have been working together for a number of years, developing a language and a world that is universal yet unique in it's character. Additionally, we have brought on several other incomparable collaborators of different mediums. Robi is fueled by the multidisciplinary aspect of this work, and has curated a “dream team” of artists that she trusts from different aspects of her creative community. Alongside this, the written source material of Mattress is derived from one author’s writing, Eric Stiefel.  Through the creative process each artist has taken Eric’s work and personally navigated it through movement and theatricality to portray their own human experience through his poetic framework. In this way we are developing honest personal narratives through this piece by working off of a concentrated body of text.  We think of the poem as a vessel for self discovery, and the entire work as a vessel for our audience to  go on parallel journey of self realizations. 

The Mattress Team includes:

Ashley Robicheaux (Choreographer & Director) https://www.instagram.com/robecho/

Justin Faircloth, Alyssa Forte, Ruth Howard, Blake Krapels, Rebecca Margolick, and Holly Sass. (Performers)

Jake Saner (Filmmaker)  http://www.jakesaner.com/

Eric Stiefel (Writer)

Rosanna Bach (Visual Artist) http://www.rosannabach.com/

John Stanesco (Composer) https://johnstanesco.wordpress.com/

With live performances from:

Psychic Twin: http://www.iampsychictwin.com/ (check out our recent work together here)

Jordan Spolianksy (Night Soil) &

RAHM: https://soundcloud.com/rahm-official

RESIDENCY:

We have been searching for a long time for a space to develop this work and call our “home”, as the logistical aspects of the creation Mattress simply do not pair well with public studio space in New York City. We have just begun our residency at The Hollows Art Space, and we need the funding to make the work come to life. Our plan is to premiere an installation version of Mattress at Hollows in April, and perform it in the fall of 2017 as a large-scale immersive piece. We are committed to a weekly rehearsal process that will culminate into an inclusive experience for our audience members. 

WHAT YOUR CONTRIBUTION MEANS TO US:

Your contribution will help us create a journey that we have been developing for the past 10 months, a journey which involves our audience members and outlasts what could otherwise be a short-lived proscenium presentation. The funds we receive mean more to us than being able to produce a product, but to create a journey for ourselves and our audience to take part, in a time when it is imperative to be making and viewing meaningful work. 

BUDGET OVERVIEW:

We are asking for $29,730.00 to support the remainder of our creative process and produce a 6-8 night run of the immersive dance-theater performance. The components of our budget include:

Dancer payment for rehearsal and performances

Stipends for our collaborators (writer, visual artist, composer and live musicians) 

Costumes and Set 

Mattresses

Residency space at The Hollows Artspace

Film production and post-preduction

Marketing and Promotional Materials

Insurance

In exchange for your support, we are offering perks ranging from a shout-out on social media, to free tickets to our performances and a sit down dinner with the cast and creatives of the Mattress team.  If we do not reach our entire goal, the funds we do receive will be dispersed to the artists who have given their time to create this work thus far, and as a reimbursement for the cost of space out of pocket.  In addition, we will perform Mattress in whatever capacity we are able to afford as a work in progress. It is important to myself and the rest of the creative that have generously given their time over the past 10 months that we follow through with this work in whatever way we can. 

RISKS AND CHALLENGES:

It is impossible to ignore the fact that in building any piece of choreography, that there will be challenges we have to face in our process. The Mattress in particular may prove itself to be logistically challenging. However, my experience as a choreographer and performer having worked in a range of different environments and under different constraints as well as the inspiring versatility of the dancers and other collaborators, we are confident we will be able to overcome any (most) hurdles we may come across. I have an understanding of the workflow, conflicts, and intensity that come with building immersive work and am ready for the challenge- a challenge that my peers support me in. 

We have planned to perform the piece for a number of test-audiences to help us overcome any road blocks we may encounter. We also trust that our showing + feedback sessions at the Hollows will give us valuable insight into how to make the piece the most effective. 

HOW YOU CAN HELP! 

What we hope the most for our campaign is that it will reach far outside of our own personal communities.  Artists and not artists alike, we want to share what we are making with as many people as possible! If you are unable to give at this time, the most valuable thing you can do for the Mattress team is to share, share, share! You can share our campaign using the Indiegogo sharing tools, on Facebook, on Instagram, or whatever you social media platform of choice may be.  If you have any questions regarding our campaign or Ashley Robicheaux & Artists, please feel free to email us at Ashleyrobicheauxandartists@gmail.com. 

Thank you for your time and consideration, 

Ashley Robicheaux & Artists

With live performances from:
Psychic Twin: http://www.iampsychictwin.com/ (check out our recent work together here)
Jordan Spolianksy (Night Soil) &
RAHM: https://soundcloud.com/rahm-official
RESIDENCY:
We have been searching for a long time for a space to develop this work and call our “home”, as the logistical aspects of the creation Mattress simply do not pair well with public studio space in New York City. We have just begun our residency at The Hollows Art Space, and we need the funding to make the work come to life. Our plan is to premiere an installation version of Mattress at Hollows in April, and perform it in the fall of 2017 as a large-scale immersive piece. We are committed to a weekly rehearsal process that will culminate into an inclusive experience for our audience members. 
WHAT YOUR CONTRIBUTION MEANS TO US:
Your contribution will help us create a journey that we have been developing for the past 10 months, a journey which involves our audience members and outlasts what could otherwise be a short-lived proscenium presentation. The funds we receive mean more to us than being able to produce a product, but to create a journey for ourselves and our audience to take part, in a time when it is imperative to be making and viewing meaningful work. 

BUDGET OVERVIEW:
We are asking for $29,730.00 to support the remainder of our creative process and produce a 6-8 night run of the immersive dance-theater performance. The components of our budget include:
Dancer payment for rehearsal and performances
Stipends for our collaborators (writer, visual artist, composer and live musicians) 
Costumes and Set 
Mattresses
Residency space at The Hollows Artspace
Film production and post-preduction
Marketing and Promotional Materials
Insurance
In exchange for your support, we are offering perks ranging from a shout-out on social media, to free tickets to our performances and a sit down dinner with the cast and creatives of the Mattress team.  If we do not reach our entire goal, the funds we do receive will be dispersed to the artists who have given their time to create this work thus far, and as a reimbursement for the cost of space out of pocket.  In addition, we will perform Mattress in whatever capacity we are able to afford as a work in progress. It is important to myself and the rest of the creative that have generously given their time over the past 10 months that we follow through with this work in whatever way we can. 
RISKS AND CHALLENGES:

It is impossible to ignore the fact that in building any piece of choreography, that there will be challenges we have to face in our process. The Mattress in particular may prove itself to be logistically challenging. However, my experience as a choreographer and performer having worked in a range of different environments and under different constraints as well as the inspiring versatility of the dancers and other collaborators, we are confident we will be able to overcome any (most) hurdles we may come across. I have an understanding of the workflow, conflicts, and intensity that come with building immersive work and am ready for the challenge- a challenge that my peers support me in. 
We have planned to perform the piece for a number of test-audiences to help us overcome any road blocks we may encounter. We also trust that our showing + feedback sessions at the Hollows will give us valuable insight into how to make the piece the most effective. 
HOW YOU CAN HELP! 
What we hope the most for our campaign is that it will reach far outside of our own personal communities.  Artists and not artists alike, we want to share what we are making with as many people as possible! If you are unable to give at this time, the most valuable thing you can do for the Mattress team is to share, share, share! You can share our campaign using the Indiegogo sharing tools, on Facebook, on Instagram, or whatever you social media platform of choice may be.  If you have any questions regarding our campaign or Ashley Robicheaux & Artists, please feel free to email us at Ashleyrobicheauxandartists@gmail.com. 
Thank you for your time and consideration, 
Ashley Robicheaux & Artists

story:
Who We Are:

Spaces of Fontana is a movement collective focused on a continuous study of physical, emotional, spiritual and spatial relationships. We derive each moment in our movement from the world around us by using a visceral connection to combine abstract ideas with the concrete.

Support our 2017 Season by donating and coming to see us dance!

NACHMO: February 1st 8:00 pm at Mark Morris Dance Group
HUMAN: March 24 & 26th at Arts on Site (Collaboration with Smashworks Dance Collective)
Our Give Back: We offer yoga classes, mini dance performances and classes to a women's shelter in Manhattan.

What We Need & What You Get:

In his 'Letter to Artists', Saint John Paul II broke down the importance of creating art and bringing beauty into the world. BUT creating art costs $$$. Help contribute to the voice of a female choreographer creating and sharing beauty with the world! See the breakdown of where the funds will go when we reach our goal with your help!

  • $800 – Performance Fees
  • $600 – Rehearsal Space
  • $500 – Dancer Salaries
  • $100 – Costumes

    The Impact

    We are in the process of creating a new work based upon research of marriage and relationships. Our artistic director, Evelyn Joy Hoelscher, recently married and was inspired to create a piece on her reflection of the vulnerability, playfulness and sacrificial love that this committed relationship requires. Society often portrays marriage through a distorted lens, but marriage is not meant to simply be between two persons; it is also a partnership between God AND your community. As artists we dive into a discovery of the lens of vulnerability, playfulness, and sacrificial love in relation to these partnerships within a marriage.

    The Challenges

    Ticket sales from performances generally go directly to cover the cost of the space or to the person producing the show. Without your support, Spaces of Fontana is self-funded entirely by the Artistic Director. Each $1 donated will allow the dancers to be paid more and help fund the cost of rehearsal and performance space.  

    Other Ways You Can Help

    No worries if you are unable to contribute at this time. More than anything we would love for you to come see our performances! 

    • Spread the word and make some noise about our campaign.
    • Check out our upcoming events by visiting spacesoffontana.com.

    And that's all there is to it.

story:
The Next Great Chicago Play

This city is full of some of the most talented playwrights in the country, but it has far too few development opportunities for them. One of the biggest obstacles standing between our playwrights and the next great Chicago play is the lack of time and support they need to write it. Unlike other theatre artists, playwrights do most of their work without any guarantee they'll be paid for it. Playwrights often spend years working on a play, unsure if they'll ever be paid for their work.

Step Up Chicago Playwrights is ready to play a lead role in supporting Chicago playwrights:

  • Our Neighborhood Residency program connects experienced playwrights with one of Chicago's vibrant neighborhoods, supporting an exchange of knowledge and skills between artist and neighbors.
  • Part of that exchange will be a Chi Wrights class or workshop, in which the Resident Playwright shares their knowledge and expertise with then next generation of Chicago playwrights.
  • Finally, playwrights who have completed a residency will be able to apply for a Chicago Works Commission, which gives them the time and support they need to translate what they learned from the residency into the next great Chicago play

We're ready to play our part in supporting Chicago's playwrights. But we can't do it without you playing a part, too!

Play Your Part

Because we're focused entirely on the development of new plays, every dollar you donate goes toward supporting Chicago playwrights. Your donation:

  • Pays the playwright for their time and labor
  • Pays for printing scripts
  • Pays for paper clips, pens, pencils, and other supplies
  • Pays actors and directors so that the playwright can hear their work
  • Pays dramaturgs to give extra feedback and guidance during development
  • Pays ASL interpreters to make sure Deaf artists and participants are included
  • Allows us to offer our Chi Wrights classes free of charge for our neighbors

... and more! Your donations, no matter how large, allow us to support Chicago playwrights as they create new plays and tell new stories about our city. You will be instrumental in helping the next great Chicago play take shape. And when the World Premiere of that great Chicago play appears onstage, you'll know that it was your support that helped get it there.

Good Neighbors

Your donation supports more than a play. Our vision is a community of Chicago theatre artists and audiences that look and sound like all of Chicago. By supporting Step Up's work, you're helping to make that vision a reality.

Every donation helps, and we're offering several perks to show our appreciation for your support.

  1. A donation of $30 (the price of a theatre ticket) helps; we'll be sure to let social media know how much we appreciate it!
  2. For those who can give at the $100 level or above, we'll be recognizing you as a Good Neighbor: your name will be listed on our website and you'll have early and exclusive access to events and news throughout the year.
  3. Those who can fully fund our workshops and residencies will be honored at events and on our website, as well as given behind the scenes access to the play development process.

We'll be rolling out new perks and giving levels as the campaign goes on. Check back for updates and limited offers!

More Impact, Less Revenue

Focusing exclusively on developing plays (and not producing them) means that Step Up Chicago Playwrights can more flexibly and effectively support playwrights and their development processes. It also means we can no longer depend upon ticket revenue. More than ever, Step Up is counting on donations from people like you. Things to note:

  • Our model is scalable and adaptable. For example: we're hoping to offer 2-3 residencies this year, but can increase that number based on fundraising.
  • This is a Flexible Funding campaign, meaning every dollar helps us whether we meet our goal or not.
  • Step Up Chicago Playwrights is a 501(c)3 nonprofit, which means your donation might be tax deductible.

If you have any questions about how Step Up is making the transition from a production model to a development model, please feel free to contact us.

Spread The Word!

Share this campaign with your social networks and let everyone in Chicago know about us and our mission. Word of mouth is our greatest tool in getting all of Chicago on board!
