story:
Written and directed by Tingying Ma, Future Host: A Speech Opera premieres on Jan 20 - 22, 2017 at Knockdown Center, New York.

The Production

First conceived as a stage play in 2014, Future Host has gone through many evolutions before crystallizing in its current form of "Speech Opera" combining digitally spatialized voice performance and original live music. In the summer of 2016, we rehearsed intensively with an ensemble of 19 actors and completed our studio recording at Atomic Sound this fall. Our momentum was fortified by a work-in-progress performance at "Performancy Forum: speculative (de)structures" at Panoply Performance Laboratory on September 29, 2016, where we shared a night of intimate collective envisioning of the future with an audience. On February 13 - 14, 2017, Future Host is traveling to Yokohama, Japan to perform at TPAM Performance Art Meeting in Yokohama. It is with the generosity and dedication of many people that we are able to bring the future closer and closer to you, and to all of us.We need your help to take further steps so that Future Host could finally meet you.

For our January premiere at Knockdown Center, we are hoping to raise $8800 to accomplish the 14-channel speech opera with original music score. Your contribution will go directly to honoring the work of boundary-pushing artists and collaborators ($3800), as well as equipment rental, professional sound recording and processing, technical support and production logistics ($4500) that ensure a high quality theatrical experience for the audience. An additional $500 goes to printing a designed bilingual booklet with original manuscript and translation. 

If we reach our projected goal, the additional $3200 (including $1000 airfare, $1500 equipment rental and sound engineering fee, $500 for accommodation and miscellaneous costs, $330 registration fee and $70 for visa application) you can send us to Yokohama in February. 

Knockdown Center supports Future Host with an extensive backline inventory of audio-visual equipment; pre-production, production, and installation staff support; targeted marketing and promotion via its newsletter, social media, and media relationships; and space for the realization of the project. Some projects require additional funding for supplemental material and/or specific technical needs that extend beyond what Knockdown provides, such as the printing of collateral material, custom equipment, travel costs, or when the scope of the project exceeds its original vision or encounters unforeseen costs.

[Premiere at Knockdown Center, New York, January 20 - 22, 2017] 

[International tour at Kawabata Hall, BankART, Yokohama, February 13 - 14, 2017]

The Concept

Future Host [未来主人] (noun.) is an epithet commonly bestowed to children in officially Socialist states, which posit the youth as the agent, product, and site whereby the future actualizes itself. "Always already be ready", so they're told—a command of absolute urgency and ecstatic optimism. The coming shall overcome. In this repetitive cycle of speculation and deferral, time passes, life is left unlived, the here and now unlivable.

Has Future Host come to the future? Will the future find a host? How do we host a future as hostile as the one fast approaching? No matter. On Inauguration Day, Future Host will be crowned with historical insignificance. Theater will be crowned with historical insignificance. But no matter. Future Host is always already ready: to endure the tyranny of political time, to refuse to be taken hostage of the flattened present, to suspend narrative in favor of an average moment of presence.

We come together through Future Host as a moment of our own. We gain strength from a collective human endeavor in theater-making and protest the singularity of the event. We make a monument of fugitive voices that emerge between the void and utmost intimacy. We create space where the minor and the multiple are hosted, literally, by bodies that choose to gather for a period of time.

The where is nowhere else but here, the here is theater that takes place in the future. Come here and be with us. By now. For the future.

Channeling historical patterns of speaking and speech-making via an original text performed by voice actors in Chinese, Future Host consists of a multitude of voices in the ancient form of chorus. Recorded and mastered through cutting-edge digital technology, fragmented words and unorthodox verbal expressions are composed into a polyphonic soundscape, where the audience move freely in the vast, emptied hall of Knockdown Center. Together with live performance of original music, they form an aleatory, fully sensorial experience beyond the limits of comprehensibility.

The Team

Playwright/Director: Tingying Ma [马汀滢] is a New York-based bilingual theater maker. Her site-specific choreographic piece Studies has been performed at Nostrand LIRR station, Brooklyn in May 2016. In 2015, the first installment of the Shujin Trilogy: S/K was produced at Signature Theatre, NY. A graduate of Central Academy of Drama in Beijing, China, she is a candidate at Columbia University MFA theatre playwriting program, mentored by Charles Mee, David Henry Hwang, and Ong Keng Sen.

Dramaturg/Co-Producer: Kang Kang [康康] is a dramaturg with a background in criticism, writing, translation and curatorial practice. She has contributed to The Brooklyn Rail, LEAP Magazine, Yishu: Journal of Contemporary Chinese Art, among other publications. She formed the ensemble of Future Host with Tingying Ma and collaborate on Studies and Future Host. She holds a B.A. in Comparative Literature & Society from Columbia University.

Producer: Maya Yu Zhang [张宇] is a performer, producer who primarily practices in film. Her self-produced works have been shown at Black Maria Film Festival, Milwaukee Underground Film Festival, Institute of Contemporary Art in Philadelphia and Anthology Film Archive. A regular collaborator with Tingying Ma and Kang Kang, she works closely with the group to facilitate innovative approaches to independent art production. A graduate of Bryn Mawr College, Maya is currently a collaborative studio fellow at UnionDocs.

Spatial Sound Composition and Production: Kamron Saniee is an electronic musician and producer based in New York. He graduated summa cum laude in mathematics from Princeton University in 2013, having previously trained as a classical violinist with master pedagogues Cyrus Forough and Shirley Givens, with additional studies in composition and performance at Mannes Conservatory pre-college. He has presented his electronic compositions and techno live sets in clubs and on the radio, and performed his multichannel spatial sound works in galleries in New York and Berlin. Recent collaborations include those with András Böröcz, providing a spatial soundtrack to the artist’s light-sculpture performance after Lászlo Moholy-Nagy, and with Lybes Dimem and Maxim Wolzyn at the Spatial Sound Institute in Budapest. He joined the organization of the CT::SWaM experimental concert series end of last year, contributing to the concert programming as well as to the collective’s radioshow on Clocktower Radio, “Broadband Echos”. This fall he attended Red Bull Music Academy 2016 in Montréal as one of 40 young producers selected internationally for the yearly academy. 

Composition: C. Spencer Yeh was born in 1975 in Taipei, Taiwan. In 2009, Yeh’s first solo exhibition, Standard Definition, was presented at the Contemporary Arts Center, Cincinnati. Yeh has toured and performed widely, and has recently presented work at the 2014 Liverpool Biennial; the Contemporary Art Museum, Houston; the Pérez Art Museum, Miami; the Kinomuzeum at the Museum of Modern Art, Warsaw; the Kunsthalle Stavanger, Norway; and in New York City at The Stone; The Kitchen; and ISSUE Project Room, among many other performances and presentations. He collaborated with Triple Canopy for the 2014 Whitney Biennial. In Fall 2014 Yeh was featured in a Modern Mondays at the Museum of Modern Art, NY. Recent recorded works include Ambient, with Robert Piotrowicz, 1975 (as C. Spencer Yeh), Transitions (as CS Yeh), and Wake Up Awesome, with Okkyung Lee and Lasse Marhaug. Yeh volunteers as a programmer and trailer editor for Spectacle Theater in Brooklyn, and co-organized Spectacle’s participation in NYC Makers: The MAD Biennial (2014), at the Museum of Arts and Design. He is a contributing editor to BOMB magazine. Yeh is a 2015 Artist-in-Residence at ISSUE Project Room, Brooklyn.

Live Sound Engineering: Daniel Neumann is a Brooklyn-based sound artist, organizer and audio engineer, originally from Germany. He holds a master's degree in media art from the Academy of Visual Art Leipzig and also studied electronic music composition under Emanuele Casale in Catania, Italy. In his artistic practice he is using conceptual and often collaborative strategies to explore sound, sound material and its modulation through space, situation and media. Curatorially he runs an event series in NYC and Berlin (CT::SWaM) that engages in spatial sound works and focussed listening.

Visual Design: Danyang Yang

Chorus: Quan Xiao 全笑, Evangeline Jiayi Zhang 张嘉懿, Yaxuan Hu 胡雅萱, Maya Yu Zhang 张宇, Bao Dai 保岱, Taole Zhu 朱陶乐

Choir: Bo Cai 蔡博, Xiangting Feng 冯襄婷, Tianyi Lu 芦天翊, He Huang 黄河, Lu Lu 卢璐, Elsa Sun, Tianyang Xu 许天阳, Yi Yang 杨易, Zixiaofan Yang 杨子小帆, Lipei Yu 余力培, Kun Yuan 袁琨, Yunkai Zhai 翟运开, Liaoran Zhang 张了然

[Thanks to our dear friend, filmmaker Ruslan Fedotow for this beautiful little documentary of our 15-minute presentation at Panoply Performance Laboratory, Brooklyn in September 2016]

Special shout out to Eddie Lu, whose generous help lays the foundation of our exploration in vocalization techniques over 5 lab sessions.

Our production team also includes Helen Chu, Yaxuan Hu, and Xiangting Feng.

Special thanks to Hsiang-Chun Cho and Chang Liu

Thanks to Naitian Yang, Xuela Zhang, Jessica Lin, Geng Han, Shu Zhu and Xiaoguang Wei, Taole Zhu who first gave their voices to Future Host; to Aggie Tai, Yaoli Mao, Yang Qiao, Chongren Fan, Sipei Fang, Andrew Shiue, Yusuke Narita, Taole Zhu for their invaluable friendship and support.

The Director wishes to thank long-term collaborator Joe Li for his vision and unconditional good vibes.

Thanks to Ziyi Li, Yimeng Chen and Helen Chu for being our family.

The Campaign

Perks

  • $5            Future Host thanks you!
  • $25         Admission x 2 to Future Host performance @ Knockdown Center
  • $50         Admission x 2 + Future Host Tote Bag
  • $100       The Above + Future Host Archive Keeper: you will receive the Future Host Archival Package and help us keep the seed of performance art alive, including a personal note from Future Host creators and official copy of production archive including notes, manuscripts, and other documentation
  • $200      The Above + Contributor Credit + Future Host "See you in Yokohama" Package, including the Future Host Archival Package, personal letter and special documentation from Yokohama
  • $500      Future Host comes to you for personalized conversation and engagement
  • $800      VIP express access to Future Host's library and brain

 

Coming Soon

Talk to us. Counting down to the future with us. To come and for the coming.

Stay tuned for more on Future Host website and Facebook engagement hosted by Kang Kang and Helen Chu

Dramaturg/Co-Producer: Kang Kang [康康] is a dramaturg with a background in criticism, writing, translation and curatorial practice. She has contributed to The Brooklyn Rail, LEAP Magazine, Yishu: Journal of Contemporary Chinese Art, among other publications. She formed the ensemble of Future Host with Tingying Ma and collaborate on Studies and Future Host. She holds a B.A. in Comparative Literature & Society from Columbia University.
Producer: Maya Yu Zhang [张宇] is a performer, producer who primarily practices in film. Her self-produced works have been shown at Black Maria Film Festival, Milwaukee Underground Film Festival, Institute of Contemporary Art in Philadelphia and Anthology Film Archive. A regular collaborator with Tingying Ma and Kang Kang, she works closely with the group to facilitate innovative approaches to independent art production. A graduate of Bryn Mawr College, Maya is currently a collaborative studio fellow at UnionDocs.
Spatial Sound Composition and Production: Kamron Saniee  is an electronic musician and producer based in New York. He graduated summa cum laude in mathematics from Princeton University in 2013, having previously trained as a classical violinist with master pedagogues Cyrus Forough and Shirley Givens, with additional studies in composition and performance at Mannes Conservatory pre-college. He has presented his electronic compositions and techno live sets in clubs and on the radio, and performed his multichannel spatial sound works in galleries in New York and Berlin. Recent collaborations include those with András Böröcz, providing a spatial soundtrack to the artist’s light-sculpture performance after Lászlo Moholy-Nagy, and with Lybes Dimem and Maxim Wolzyn at the Spatial Sound Institute in Budapest. He joined the organization of the CT::SWaM experimental concert series end of last year, contributing to the concert programming as well as to the collective’s radioshow on Clocktower Radio, “Broadband Echos”. This fall he attended Red Bull Music Academy 2016 in Montréal as one of 40 young producers selected internationally for the yearly academy. 
Composition: C. Spencer Yeh was born in 1975 in Taipei, Taiwan. In 2009, Yeh’s first solo exhibition, Standard Definition, was presented at the Contemporary Arts Center, Cincinnati. Yeh has toured and performed widely, and has recently presented work at the 2014 Liverpool Biennial; the Contemporary Art Museum, Houston; the Pérez Art Museum, Miami; the Kinomuzeum at the Museum of Modern Art, Warsaw; the Kunsthalle Stavanger, Norway; and in New York City at The Stone; The Kitchen; and ISSUE Project Room, among many other performances and presentations. He collaborated with Triple Canopy for the 2014 Whitney Biennial. In Fall 2014 Yeh was featured in a Modern Mondays at the Museum of Modern Art, NY. Recent recorded works include Ambient, with Robert Piotrowicz, 1975 (as C. Spencer Yeh), Transitions (as CS Yeh), and Wake Up Awesome, with Okkyung Lee and Lasse Marhaug. Yeh volunteers as a programmer and trailer editor for Spectacle Theater in Brooklyn, and co-organized Spectacle’s participation in NYC Makers: The MAD Biennial (2014), at the Museum of Arts and Design. He is a contributing editor to BOMB magazine. Yeh is a 2015 Artist-in-Residence at ISSUE Project Room, Brooklyn.
Live Sound Engineering: Daniel Neumann is a Brooklyn-based sound artist, organizer and audio engineer, originally from Germany. He holds a master's degree in media art from the Academy of Visual Art Leipzig and also studied electronic music composition under Emanuele Casale in Catania, Italy. In his artistic practice he is using conceptual and often collaborative strategies to explore sound, sound material and its modulation through space, situation and media. Curatorially he runs an event series in NYC and Berlin (CT::SWaM) that engages in spatial sound works and focussed listening.
Visual Design: Danyang Yang
Chorus: Quan Xiao 全笑, Evangeline Jiayi Zhang 张嘉懿, Yaxuan Hu 胡雅萱, Maya Yu Zhang 张宇, Bao Dai 保岱, Taole Zhu 朱陶乐
Choir: Bo Cai 蔡博, Xiangting Feng 冯襄婷, Tianyi Lu 芦天翊, He Huang 黄河, Lu Lu 卢璐, Elsa Sun, Tianyang Xu 许天阳, Yi Yang 杨易, Zixiaofan Yang 杨子小帆, Lipei Yu 余力培, Kun Yuan 袁琨, Yunkai Zhai 翟运开, Liaoran Zhang 张了然


[Thanks to our dear friend, filmmaker Ruslan Fedotow for this beautiful little documentary of our 15-minute presentation at Panoply Performance Laboratory, Brooklyn in September 2016]

Special shout out to Eddie Lu, whose generous help lays the foundation of our exploration in vocalization techniques over 5 lab sessions.
Our production team also includes Helen Chu, Yaxuan Hu, and Xiangting Feng.
Special thanks to Hsiang-Chun Cho and Chang Liu
Thanks to Naitian Yang, Xuela Zhang, Jessica Lin, Geng Han, Shu Zhu and Xiaoguang Wei, Taole Zhu who first gave their voices to Future Host; to Aggie Tai, Yaoli Mao, Yang Qiao, Chongren Fan, Sipei Fang, Andrew Shiue, Yusuke Narita, Taole Zhu for their invaluable friendship and support.
The Director wishes to thank long-term collaborator Joe Li for his vision and unconditional good vibes.
Thanks to Ziyi Li, Yimeng Chen and Helen Chu for being our family.

The Campaign
Perks

$5            Future Host thanks you!
$25         Admission x 2 to Future Host performance @ Knockdown Center
$50         Admission x 2 + Future Host Tote Bag

$100       The Above + Future Host Archive Keeper: you will receive the Future Host Archival Package and help us keep the seed of performance art alive, including a personal note from Future Host creators and official copy of production archive including notes, manuscripts, and other documentation
$200      The Above + Contributor Credit + Future Host "See you in Yokohama" Package, including the Future Host Archival Package, personal letter and special documentation from Yokohama
$500      Future Host comes to you for personalized conversation and engagement
$800      VIP express access to Future Host's library and brain


 
Coming Soon


Talk to us. Counting down to the future with us. To come and for the coming.
Stay tuned for more on Future Host website and Facebook engagement hosted by Kang Kang and Helen Chu

story:
About me

Greetings! My name is Elizabeth Addison and I am a composer, lyricist, playwright and performer from Boston, Massachusetts. I am also a recovering addict who will be 5 years clean this April. I began writing "This is Treatment" after my year long stay at a residential treatment facility. Truthfully, when I started writing "This is Treatment," I had no idea what I was doing. I had never written a song or a play before and the only thing I knew was that if I kept showing up and had a little faith, eventually I would have a musical. 

Self Producing 'Treatment'

In 2014, I decided that it was time to get "This is Treatment" on it's feet. Now, I had never produced a show before (are we sensing a pattern?) but something inside me knew that unless I put it up, nobody else would. So, I rented a 100 seat theater at the Dance Complex for two days, found a cast and got it on its feet. The first two shows were completely sold out and over the next three years, the productions would continue to sell out. 

No budget, No real set, just a few chairs and tables, but it still resonated with people. Imagine what could happen if we had some real money behind the show?

The Impact

In 2015, approximately 20.8 million people age 12 and up had a substance use disorder. In 2015, 1 in 12 people needed treatment, and out of that, only 14% sought Treatment. In 2014, 47,055 people died from from drug overdoses and the numbers are rising rapidly each year... 

After each production of "This is Treatment," audience members would email me or comment on how the show made them feel. I heard such things as: this show has a helped repair my relationship with my sister who is a recovering addict, I finally understand what my mother went through, I'm not an addict but I could relate to the feeling of being alone and overwhelmed, I didn't know I needed to see this piece and this show is necessary. I even heard that some people sought a form of treatment as a result of seeing the show. Again, if this is happening when I produce the show, what could happen if it got some real money behind it?

Challenges

The biggest challenge right now is raising the funds to get to New York. I have never been able to put up more than two shows at a time because of the lack of funds. Producing a show can be very expensive. Also, I am new to the game, unless you are somewhat established, no one is coming from New York to Boston to see your show. You have to bring it to them and in order to do that, I need your help.

Where does my donation go?

The costs of bringing "This is Treatment" to New York are going to add up quickly. Your donation would go to the following: 

  • Venue: $1,000
  • Rehearsal space: $500
  • Salaries for 12 cast members, Director, Musical Director,  Assistant Musical Director,  Production Assistant and Stage Manager: $3,200
  • Travel and Lodging: $2,000
  • Programs, Marketing, Promotion, etc: $300 

For Me?

As a thank you for your generous contribution, we have come up with some 'Treatment' perks located to the right of your screen. We want you to know exactly what you are investing in and, like the cast and crew, that you are a part of the 'Treatment' family as well.

Are There Other Ways I Can Help?

But of course! Now, while any amount, rather it be $1 or $1,000 is greatly appreciated, we know that some folk are just too stretched to contribute financially.  So, what's the next best thing? WORD OF MOUTH! Tell a friend, post about the campaign on facebook, tell your coworkers, blog about it, sing about it, video tape yourself about it, send out a call to action, anything you can think of to just get the word out!

Thank you and we'll see you in New York!

story:
DramaWay is the leading provider of fine arts programming in the Greater Toronto Area for people of all abilities, specializing in modifying programming for individuals with special needs. 

Danielle Strnad founded DramaWay in 1999 the company has grown to offer programs throughout the Greater Toronto Area to more then 300 participants of varying abilities 

This campaign will provide continued pride in the performance space we can offer to our actors and performers. 

Contributors will be giving our clients with special needs an amazing opportunity, one that they will cherish for their whole lives. Giving our performers a sense of accomplishment and self worth is absolutely priceless!

What We Need & What You Get

DramaWay needs $8,000 to rent beautiful and professional theatre spaces as well as cover many additional costs associated with our productions

DramaWay is prepared to release amazing and fun perks straight from our memorable clients

If we do not reach our goal the funds raised through Indiegogo will still go towards the cost of the theatre rental and showcase expenses. Anything helps!

 

The Impact

It goes without saying that the impact these professional theatre spaces have on our production and performers is invaluable. The evolution of our programs has steadily grown but being able to perform and have our participants experience professional pride stands to be incomparable!

 

Risks & Challenges

Although we pride our company in it's growth it seems we cannot maintain the level of what we have begun to offer with rising costs and the need of many expert facilitators to pull off these productions. The reality is so much planning, effort, time and money are allocated to these productions and their sheer size that we cannot continue if we don't have help. 

With the help of this campaigns success DramaWay can fully pay for the rental of our theatre space and cover some of the many production expenses. This will free up nearly a quarter of our budget to other areas in dire need of monetary support.

 

Further to this campaign DramaWay is taking a whole new approach to our production. We will be re-imagining many costume pieces and sets to provide an amazing production without a major unnecessary cost

 

Other Ways You Can Help

DramaWay is always accepting volunteers for our production. This can be for our front of house, or weekly programming behind the scenes

Please visit our website at www.dramaway.com to find more volunteer information, or contact our direct Danielle Strnad through her email at dramawayoffice@gmail.com if you're interested in becoming a volunteer!

 

Please remember to use the sharing tools that Indiegogo offers! Getting the word out about our campaign is nearly as great as donating! We could always use the help and vote of confidence!

We thank you for your attention to this awesome cause. Together we truly can make a difference.

story:
How It All Began

Manar is a play that has been a work in progress with this team for the past year. Melis had written a short version of the play for our class at Columbia University called “Collaboration” overseen by Anne Bogart. The creation of the play was also overseen by Melis’ mentors in the playwriting program including: David Henry Hwang, Lynn Nottage, and Kelly Stuart. After a few months, Melis finished a first draft of the entire script and the team has been working on developing different drafts of the play. Melis is also involved with the Middle East America writers room hosted by the Lark Play Development Center with Mona Mansour, Hadi Tabbal, Leila Buck, and Heather Raffo where she has been developing Manar. We have just started rehearsals for our workshop production going up at LaGuardia Performing Arts Center’s Rough Draft Festival. The Rough Draft Festival is a celebration of artists/organizations and their work under development. The festival features a wide array of artists whose work is at various levels of development. We are so grateful to have the opportunity to showcase our work on Manar and have such a talented group of artists to work with us.

What We Need & What You Get

  • We need a small amount of money to meet our goal in the first step of developing this project
  • We will be forever grateful for your contributions no matter how small or big
  • Your name will be featured in our special thanks
  • We will dedicate a social media post to you, upon your approval
  • We will be giving out two pairs of tickets to our biggest contributors

The Impact

We find that Manar is a piece that should be seen by as many people as possible because it so timely and it speaks to many generations about their own thoughts and fears in this new age we are living in.

Other Ways You Can Help

We understand that some people cannot contribute monetarily but you can help us in many other ways!

  • Make some noise about the play and the campaign!
  • Find us on Facebook and share our page and event with your friends:
    https://www.facebook.com/pg/manaranewplay/

story:
“Where were you August of 2005?”

(Does that date spark a mark in your memory archive?)

 

THE STORY

 

Back O'Town tells the story of a family, torn.

Not by each other but by the storms.

Katrina and Rita, right? 

Or was it FEMA...

We don’t write blame, but are trying to find the light 

Back O'Town is not a story of giving up

A city chucked in the muck on the cusp of destruction

While the government was spewing fiction 

NOLA overcame addiction of affliction through affection. 

A mother, a daughter, and a feisty grandmother

Part of a community tip-tottering around Big Brother

 

THE COSTS

 

While the story is simple, we need people to tell it

Outfitted and lit while our director leads

a space to trace hearts healing for what’s real

so that when you come to the show, you can really feel. 

The drums on the street of a second line

Tap-tip-da-dip-dat-dat in real time. 

 

THE REASON 

 

Now. 

Why donate to help us tell this story? 

Why this story and not another?

 

Eleven years later, the wreckage has last

Higher-up lies undercover in disguises 

We choose to scrutinize.

In order to build a community

To tell a story truthfully

Musically speaking, make beats out of debris. 

Learn from sounds not heard but felt

Because for others to listen. 

We. Need. Your. Help. 

 

If you can’t contribute money then please help spread the word.

All we want is to amplify voices that should’ve been heard.

story:
Summary

21/40 is named after the room where we all studied at Iowa state University.

2140 - a small room in Pearson hall - was the only space allotted to our department.  Crowded with a bunch of mismatched chairs and piano that was falling apart, it served as a classroom, a rehearsal hall, and an intimate and resourceful performance venue. Storytelling in such close quarters demanded attention to detail, a lack of artifice, and above all, sincere performances.

Inspired by our time spent in that room, our mission is simple: We strive to tell honest stories. Stories that highlight the joy, the headache, and the ambiguity of real life. In hopes of bringing a new level of sincerity to our shows, we will commit ourselves to ongoing training, a rigorous work ethic, and constant experimentation.

Our first show will be Dead Silence. Written by Taylor Sklenar, a fellow alumnus of ISU, it follows the experiences of Brian, a failing spoken word poet.

Haunted by a recent loss, Brian strives to be the ‘Voice of a generation.” In the wake of his obsession and neglect, his wife struggles to hold their crumbling marriage together. 

This script is wonderfully simple. With a flexible set and a cast of only three, the budget necessary is relatively small. A list of production costs include:

A few set pieces, props, costumes, printing (postcards, posters, and programs), and artists stipends.

If you crave poignant storytelling that doesn't condescend to audiences, please consider supporting our mission.

Any additional funds raised will be immediately directed towards our second show: Dog Sees God, Confessions of a Teenage Blockhead. For more information and updates on our upcoming season, please visit our Facebook page:

https://www.facebook.com/2140Productions/

or email us directly at twentyonefortyproductions@gmail.com.

Look for our website to go live later this summer!

We are honored to be a part of the Twin Cities theatre community. Thank you for making it a possibility. 

Other Ways You Can Help

Although money is an  important factor, there are other crucial ways you can help our organization grow.  See our shows, spread the word, or if you're curious about other ways you can get involved, email us at twentyonefortyproductions@gmail.com.

story:
Isobel Rogers is a writer, songwriter and performer who is Artist-in-Residence at the Roundhouse in Camden and a writer on the Soho Young Writers programme. As a songwriter she has supported artists 'The Tiger Lillies' and Camille O'Sullivan and has been making her show 'Elsa' for the past two years as part of her residency, wanting to create a show that brings the liveness of a gig audience into a theatre space. 'Elsa' has been developed with and supported by the Roundhouse & Soho Theatre.

I am fascinated by the way women present themselves and what it means to be strong and powerful in todays society and I wanted to articulate these thoughts in a medium that would allow me to blend character-based storytelling with songwriting. During my time at the Roundhouse I started writing songs for female characters in plays whose stories didn't feel like their own and I wanted to reflect how this sense of incompleteness has been passed down through the generations in Elsa. In today’s society there is a strong impulse to attempt to become somebody else when the world is telling you that an artist’s life is not real and I wanted to explore these thoughts through the lens of a singer-songwriter; everyone sees a girl with a guitar as someone who is both vulnerable and powerful, and I wanted to take that image a step further by turning her into a character in a play. I want Elsa to bridge the gap between theatre and cabaret. Use performance to comment on female performativity and sing about and against the parts we are supposed to play. 

The £2,000 raised here will go towards venue costs, equipment hire, marketing (posters and flyers, etc.) and fees for the creative and technical team. I have been self-funding the project for the past three years and doing my own fundraising for the show so this support would really give the project the security it needs to survive at the fringe. 

If you're kind enough to donate to the show, you can expect some fantastic rewards in the form of handwritten letters from Edinburgh, personalised songs, free tickets to the show, and even a writers' workshop led by Isobel. 

Obviously the risks involved in any fringe theatre production are immense: it is rare for shows to break even, and even rarer to turn a profit. There were over 3,000 shows at the fringe last year, so above and beyond the quality of the show, which has been honed through numerous preview shows at professional venues, it is imperative for us to have our marketing and publicity planned and executed down to the last detail; funding will hugely enhance the impact and reach of our efforts, and the team have been performing at or involved in the Edinburgh Fringe festival for the last ten years. 

Even if you can't donate at this time, please do help us spread the word and we would love you to come and check out 'Elsa' if you're in Edinburgh this year, on at Assembly Hall, Baillie Room, at 9.30pm from the 3rd-27th August (not 14th). 

Thanks so much for reading if you've made it this far, and we hope to see you in Edinburgh! 

Love,

Isobel & Team.
story_txt:
Isobel Rogers is a writer, songwriter and performer who is Artist-in-Residence at the Roundhouse in Camden and a writer on the Soho Young Writers programme. As a songwriter she has supported artists 'The Tiger Lillies' and Camille O'Sullivan and has been making her show 'Elsa' for the past two years as part of her residency, wanting to create a show that brings the liveness of a gig audience into a theatre space. 'Elsa' has been developed with and supported by the Roundhouse & Soho Theatre.
I am fascinated by the way women present themselves and what it means to be strong and powerful in todays society and I wanted to articulate these thoughts in a medium that would allow me to blend character-based storytelling with songwriting. During my time at the Roundhouse I started writing songs for female characters in plays whose stories didn't feel like their own and I wanted to reflect how this sense of incompleteness has been passed down through the generations in Elsa. In today’s society there is a strong impulse to attempt to become somebody else when the world is telling you that an artist’s life is not real and I wanted to explore these thoughts through the lens of a singer-songwriter; everyone sees a girl with a guitar as someone who is both vulnerable and powerful, and I wanted to take that image a step further by turning her into a character in a play. I want Elsa to bridge the gap between theatre and cabaret. Use performance to comment on female performativity and sing about and against the parts we are supposed to play. 
The £2,000 raised here will go towards venue costs, equipment hire, marketing (posters and flyers, etc.) and fees for the creative and technical team. I have been self-funding the project for the past three years and doing my own fundraising for the show so this support would really give the project the security it needs to survive at the fringe. 
If you're kind enough to donate to the show, you can expect some fantastic rewards in the form of handwritten letters from Edinburgh, personalised songs, free tickets to the show, and even a writers' workshop led by Isobel. 
Obviously the risks involved in any fringe theatre production are immense: it is rare for shows to break even, and even rarer to turn a profit. There were over 3,000 shows at the fringe last year, so above and beyond the quality of the show, which has been honed through numerous preview shows at professional venues, it is imperative for us to have our marketing and publicity planned and executed down to the last detail; funding will hugely enhance the impact and reach of our efforts, and the team have been performing at or involved in the Edinburgh Fringe festival for the last ten years. 
Even if you can't donate at this time, please do help us spread the word and we would love you to come and check out 'Elsa' if you're in Edinburgh this year, on at Assembly Hall, Baillie Room, at 9.30pm from the 3rd-27th August (not 14th). 
Thanks so much for reading if you've made it this far, and we hope to see you in Edinburgh! 
Love,
Isobel & Team.

story:
HOW did Pomegrenade Happen? 

Part of IRT's 3B Development Series
www.thearcticgroup.org/pomegrenade

Written by Ran Xia; Directed by Ran Xia & Jake Beckhard

Persephone gets snatched to the underworld, but the place isn't really what she expected. Hades has his own problems to deal with as well, especially when the memory archive is at capacity with the refugees pouring into the world of the dead. 

Cast: Zoe Abuyuan, Diane Chen (Dionysus), Maricelis Galanes (Hermes), Sean Hinckle (Ares), Finn Kilgore (Hades), Lizzy Ana Lincoln (Persephone), Andrea Negrete, Jara Skagfjord, Sharlee J. Taylor (Kharon), Sarah Gwynne Walker, and Marie Zoumanigui.

Choreography is by Samantha Sheppard. Set Design is by Julie A. Solomon. Lighting Design is by Katy Atwell. Assistant Director is Julia Levine. 

It started when scientists decided to demote Pluto from solar system, which prompted me to become instantly obsessed with humanity's obsession with Pluto, as well as its moon, Kharon, both coming from Greek mythology, directly associated with Hades, lord of the underworld, and all the stories around that fascinating realm of unknown. Around the same time, news stories from Syria, Turkey, and frankly everywhere in the world, are streaming in, and I felt emotionally overwhelmed by the amount of tragedies around us. This story comes to be a retelling of how Persephone becomes the Queen of the dead, and the function of the underworld as a memory archive, a refuge of the forgotten. 

  • A little bit about me. I am an NYC based interdisciplinary theatre artist and critic with a specific passion of bridging the gap between theatre and journalism. With a background in psychology and media studies, my writings are inspired by current events as well as the classics. I'm the co-founder of The Arctic Group, a (mostly) theatre collective. We take pride in taking risks and breaking the barriers between genres. http://ranxia.info
  • We have a cast of 11 brilliant actors who have brought so much of their intellect and passion to this creative process, and I would like to compensate their hard work. We would also like to ensure the audience with a transformative experience, which means a polished set of production design including  the set, the lighting, and the sound. We have set our eyes on some materials that would enable us to create a "forest" on stage, so your contribution, no matter how little or how large, will add a new leaf to our creation. Literally. 

 

What We Need & What You Get

  • We are rehearsing somewhere between 15 hours a week, collectively, which roughly costs $150 per week to rent the space. I'm paying out of my own pocket to cover the charge so far and it might put a large strain down the line.
  • We will need transportation to carry set pieces to the theatre around 8/29.
  • We will need stipend for the actors and designers to compensate their hard work, which comes up to around 3000 total. 
  • With a contribution of 10+, you'll get a Facebook shoutout. 
  • With a contribution of 25+, you'll get a Facebook shoutout and a thank you note from me. 
  • With a contribution of 50+, you'll get a free ticket to the show and a personal, hand written thank you note delivered to you. 
  • With a contribution of 100+, you'll get a pair of free tickets to the show and a personal, hand written thank you note delivered to you. 
  • With a contribution of 200+, you'll get all of above and be listed in our program as an investor
  • With a contribution of 500+, you'll get all of above and you will be listed as an associate producer in our program
  • Even if we don't reach the entire goal, we will still try our best to achieve all our goals. Everyone might have slightly smaller amount of stipend and we might have to sacrifice some design ideas. 

Other Ways You Can Help

  • We are sourcing ladders and wooden crates, so if you cannot contribute with money, we ask your help on that end. 
  • Also, every share helps. Much gratitude to you if you could spread the word in your circle.

story:
Who We Are & Why We Are Here


Established in 2014, Strive For Change is a lifestyle brand that represents awareness, truth, hard work, community, and love. Our mission is simple: inspire people to try.

Once a year we come together to organize this event for the community. Whether it be conquering a personal fear or gaining knowledge towards future endeavors, our objective is to open doors to greater opportunities for our convention goers all while creating a long-lasting experience.

What separates us from other conventions is the emphasis we put on conquering one's self-doubt. We also stress the importance of moving from a place that's authentic as opposed to egotistic and keeping an open mind to all the styles and methods of teaching that are presented to them. The atmosphere is non-competitive and focuses strictly on learning and exploring. But what makes this event even sweeter is that it costs up to 4 to 5 times less than other established conventions.

Your contribution to this campaign will do wonders for so many people on a very personal level; that includes both staff and convention goers. We have been successful in creating memorable experiences in the past and have no doubts we can do it again this year.

What We Need & What You Get

This year we are asking our community to help us reach our goal of $5000. Your generous contributions will go towards covering:

  • Venue
  • Insurance
  • Dance Instructors
  • Advertising
  • Photographer
  • Videographers
  • DJ
  • Sound System
  • Staff

If we happen to not meet our goal the convention will still take place. However, it will be much more difficult for us to tackle it financially.

PERKS FOR YOU!
We have a lot of exciting, interactive perks. Make sure you take a good look around. We have things such as:

  • private dance/ tumbling lessons
  • private music shows
  • private hangouts
  • discounted dance workshops
  • professional photo shoot
  • professional video shoot
  • musical cover requests
  • art requests
  • creating original songs just for you
  • an original rap, co-created by you
  • your name in our list of sponsors
  • sponsor someone who wouldn't normally be able to attend the convention

Pre-order T-Shirts

We are now taking T-Shirt Pre-Orders! Email: SFCLifestyle@gmail.com your size and quantity.

THE IMPACT

Our analysis
The dance community as a whole is a very bright place. However, as dancers ourselves, we have noticed that as the community becomes more industrialized it's also grown a bit more shallow. As a result, many individuals have lost touch with the core reason why they ever started dance. Over the past few years, while dance has gotten much bigger, it's also become more intimidating for anyone who might have even the slightest interest to try and take a class. On the other hand, even if they do take a class, they are usually met with extremely overwhelming combinations and sometimes may not get any sort of feedback from the instructor. It is then that some decide that dance just isn't for them.

Addressing our notion
We believe dance should always first and foremost be fun. We also believe it can be used as a tool to overcome personal hurdles as well as a way to communicate with others. At this convention, all of the instructors value your growth. We care about delivering the best of what we have to offer at a pace that's reasonable to the level of the class.

More than just dance
We found that the industry panel from last year was very engaging and helpful to everyone there. Professionals who are active members in their communities (as well as the dance industry) shared personal stories and provided tips on what happens in their field of work and how they're trying to make an impact in their circles.
The community conversation from last year also took us by surprise! The level of engagement we received was not what we were expecting. A scheduled 20 minutes easily went over an hour and we still weren't ready to stop talking! For this portion of the convention we invited local non-profits to speak about their cause and provide tips on how we could all improve our individual lives and our communities.

Has all the awesomeness convinced you to help put together this extravagant event yet? If not... look, a video down below.

EAT SLEEP DANCE REPEAT 2015 RECAP



RISKS AND CHALLENGES


The biggest risk we take every year is not knowing whether or not we're going to break even financially. Booking a place and finding instructors, panelists, non-profits, staff, videographers, photographers, a DJ, and an MC are things we're capable of doing. The event itself is great and gets a fair amount of exposure on social media. Our problem stems from non-attendees that questions the convention's value and sometimes becoming intimidated by the variety of styles that are offered. Additionally, it may get overlooked by those who don't go to events like this unless there is a big name attached to it. This is the sad but true reality.

We hope to change those outlooks by creating an even better experience this year and making sure that it is well documented online to raise more attention for next year as well as give this event more exposure earlier in the year.


Other Ways You Can Help

Share this campaign with everyone :)

story:
Kaspar Häuser Meer

Theaterstück von Felicia Zeller

 

Vorwort:

Theater kann sich nicht selbst allein durch Eintrittsgeldeinnahmen finanzieren. Bei jeder Produktion, die wir beginnen, sind erneute Fördergeldanträge nötig, um alle Kosten im Zusammenhang mit der Produktion bezahlen zu können.

Aber die Fördertöpfe sind begrenzt und viele Theater stellen Anträge. Nicht immer ist für den Einzelnen nachvollziehbar, warum andere Geld bekommen und man selber nicht.

Diesmal haben wir nichts abbekommen und sind deshalb gezwungen, diesen unkonventionellen Weg zu beschreiten.

Uns fehlen genau € 5.000, um das Projekt zu realisieren. Es ist uns aber so wichtig, dass wir nicht einfach auf die Realisierung verzichten wollen. Wir gehen davon aus, viele Zuschauer zu erreichen und wir kennen unser Lüneburger Publikum, das unser Theater liebt und unterstützt.

Wir brauchen das Geld, um Requisiten und Kostüme zu kaufen und um das Bühnenbild herstellen zu lassen. Und natürlich wollen alle Beteiligten Geld verdienen, denn wir leben von unserem Beruf. Dann entstehen Kosten für die Aufführungsrechte, Saalmiete und die notwendige Technik. Einen Großteil davon erwirtschaften wir durch den Verkauf von Eintrittskarten. Aber das reicht nicht.

 

 

Das Stück

Die drei Protagonisten des Stückes, Anika, Silvia und Barbara sind Jugendamtsozialarbei­terinnen und stehen ständig unter der Herausforderung, die Lebenssituation ihrer anver­trauten Familien zu bewerten, zu überprüfen und entsprechende Entscheidungen zu tref­fen. Durch den krankheitsbedingten Ausfall des Mitarbeiters Björn („Björn-Out-Syndrom“), spitzt sich der tägliche Kampf gegen Ohnmacht, Überforderung und Kapitulation der Frau­en noch mehr zu, da sie dessen unerledigte und schlecht dokumentierte Fälle überneh­men müssen. Darüber hinaus muss jede der Sozialarbeiterinnen auch das eigene Leben gestalten und bewältigen. Anika ist frisch von der Fachhochschule und alleinerziehende Mutter einer vierjährigen Tochter. Silvia versucht immer mehr zu arbeiten, um das immer größer wer­dende Loch von Müdigkeit und scheinbarer Ergebnislosigkeit ihrer Arbeit zu stopfen. Bar­bara arbeitet schon zwanzig Jahre in der Verwaltung, hat selber 5 Kinder und träumt von Ruhe und Urlaub.

 

Die Autorin

Felicia Zeller hat die Arbeitssituation der Sozialarbeiterinnen genau recherchiert. Es geht ihr nicht um Schuldzuweisung, sondern sie beschreibt nachvollziehbar verschiedene Sze­narien, wie sie tagtäglich in unserer Gesellschaft geschehen. Auf diese Weise kann der Zuschauer eine Empathie für alle Beteiligten entwickeln, ohne gleich in die Versuchung zu geraten, zu werten oder die Geschehnisse mit dem Gedanken: “Mich betrifft das ja nicht!“ von sich abzuwehren.

Tatsächlich ist die genaue Zahl von Kindesmisshandlungen in Deutschland auf Grund der hohen Dunkelziffer schwer zu bestimmen. Die polizeiliche Kriminalstatistik verzeichnete für das Jahr 2015 3441 Fälle von Kindesmisshandlung mit 3965 Opfern. Schätzungen zufolge sind es aber ca. 20.000 Kinder, die jährlich Opfer von Gewalt werden. Die seelischen und körperlichen Schäden aller Formen der Kindesmisshandlung prägen diese Kinder häufig ein Leben lang. Suchtanfälligkeit und Gewaltbereitschaft sind nur zwei mögliche Folgen, die dazu führen können, dass sich der Gewaltkreislauf von Generation zu Generation fort­setzt.

 

Das Ensemble

Suzanne Andres, Janina Baier und Erika Döhmen sind professionelle Schauspielerinnen, die schon seit Jahren in Ihrem Beruf arbeiten und an vielen Theatern gearbeitet haben.

Laura Remmler (Regie) machte ihre Ausbildung zur Regisseurin an der Royal Central School of Speech and Drama und dem StoneCrabs Young Directors Programme, London. Sie hat außerdem einen Master Abschluss in Englischer Literatur, Film und Visual Culture von der University of Aberdeen. Mit dem Thomas Ney.Theater erarbeitete sie bereits die Komödie KUNST von Yasmina Reza.

 

 

Wie Ihr uns helfen könnt

Wir haben für jeden was dabei. Schon ab € 20 könnt Ihr helfen. Dafür bekommt Ihr eine Eintrittskarte für eine beliebige Vorstellung. Wenn Ihr etwas mehr Geld zur Verfügung habt, könnt Ihr auch für eine Freikarte etwas mehr Geld investieren und bekommt dann noch ein kleines Geschenk dazu, ein Glas Sekt oder etwas anderes.

Wer nicht in Lüneburg oder Umgebung lebt und keine Gelegenheit hat, eine Vorstellung zu besuchen, aber uns trotzdem gerne helfen möchte, bekommt von uns handsignierte Autogrammkarten mit Szenen aus dem Stück.

Und natürlich wird jeder Spender auf unseren Veröffentlichungen erwähnt.

Wer nicht auf finanziellem Weg helfen kann oder will, hat trotzdem die Möglichkeit, uns weiter zu bringen: Teile diese Aktion auf Facebook, erzähle Freunden davon und mache so unser Projekt bekannt. Das geht oft ganz einfach per Knopfdruck oder während eines Gespräches auf der nächsten Party.

Hilf uns, dieses wichtige Projekt zu realisieren!

Tatsächlich ist die genaue Zahl von Kindesmisshandlungen in Deutschland auf Grund der hohen Dunkelziffer schwer zu bestimmen. Die polizeiliche Kriminalstatistik verzeichnete für das Jahr 2015 3441 Fälle von Kindesmisshandlung mit 3965 Opfern. Schätzungen zufolge sind es aber ca. 20.000 Kinder, die jährlich Opfer von Gewalt werden. Die seelischen und körperlichen Schäden aller Formen der Kindesmisshandlung prägen diese Kinder häufig ein Leben lang. Suchtanfälligkeit und Gewaltbereitschaft sind nur zwei mögliche Folgen, die dazu führen können, dass sich der Gewaltkreislauf von Generation zu Generation fort­setzt.
 
Das Ensemble
Suzanne Andres, Janina Baier und Erika Döhmen sind professionelle Schauspielerinnen, die schon seit Jahren in Ihrem Beruf arbeiten und an vielen Theatern gearbeitet haben.
Laura Remmler (Regie) machte ihre Ausbildung zur Regisseurin an der Royal Central School of Speech and Drama und dem StoneCrabs Young Directors Programme, London. Sie hat außerdem einen Master Abschluss in Englischer Literatur, Film und Visual Culture von der University of Aberdeen. Mit dem Thomas Ney.Theater erarbeitete sie bereits die Komödie KUNST von Yasmina Reza.
 

 
Wie Ihr uns helfen könnt
Wir haben für jeden was dabei. Schon ab € 20 könnt Ihr helfen. Dafür bekommt Ihr eine Eintrittskarte für eine beliebige Vorstellung. Wenn Ihr etwas mehr Geld zur Verfügung habt, könnt Ihr auch für eine Freikarte etwas mehr Geld investieren und bekommt dann noch ein kleines Geschenk dazu, ein Glas Sekt oder etwas anderes.
Wer nicht in Lüneburg oder Umgebung lebt und keine Gelegenheit hat, eine Vorstellung zu besuchen, aber uns trotzdem gerne helfen möchte, bekommt von uns handsignierte Autogrammkarten mit Szenen aus dem Stück.
Und natürlich wird jeder Spender auf unseren Veröffentlichungen erwähnt.
Wer nicht auf finanziellem Weg helfen kann oder will, hat trotzdem die Möglichkeit, uns weiter zu bringen: Teile diese Aktion auf Facebook, erzähle Freunden davon und mache so unser Projekt bekannt. Das geht oft ganz einfach per Knopfdruck oder während eines Gespräches auf der nächsten Party.
Hilf uns, dieses wichtige Projekt zu realisieren!

story:
Let's Get Down to the Nitty Gritty...

Grit Theatre is a brand new theatre company based in Chicago, IL. We are an ensemble of actors, who want to create and produce plays that shine light on the dark, rough, and not so beautiful aspects of life. Our hope is to raise money to fund our first play, Danny and the Deep Blue Sea by John Patrick Shanley. We believe this play is the epitome of the type of theatre we want to produce.

In our experience, a genuine connection with another person is difficult to come by. Not only are there every day distractions, but we all have personal baggage that can be scary to admit out loud to another person. "Danny"  asks the questions "What would happen if you confessed your truths and freed your skeletons to a complete stranger?" "Would they accept you?" "Could they relate?"

As a ensemble, Grit Theatre strives to become an established company within the Chicago Theatre community. All contributions will go towards the production of Danny and the Deep Blue Sea.

The Budget

Theatre can be pretty expensive which is why we are reaching out.  Here's a break down of our expenses.

Performance Space-  $1,500 (two weekend performances)
Rehearsal Space- $420
Performance Rights- $600
Costumes- $100
Props/Scenic/Lights- $300

Meet the Cast and Crew

Cast

Roberta- Chelsea Turner is a co-founder of Grit Theatre. Originally from the Boston area, Chelsea graduated from Emerson College with a BA in Theatre and a minor in writing. Since moving to Chicago last year, she has worked with Mercy Street Theatre in their Beacon Series readings. Other credits include Julius Caesar (Class 6 Theatre), Br'er Rose (Speculative Drama), Macbeth and Love's Labour's Lost (Portland Actor's Ensemble). She is thrilled to be playing Roberta in Grit Theatre's debut production. 

 

Danny- Eric Salas is a native Floridian and proud co-founder of Grit Theatre who has been participating in Chicago theatre for the past 3 years.  Previous credits include, Jerusalem, Hellcab, Dreamx3, and Tenderness Sucks. 

 

The Crew

Director- Paige Taylor is a co-founder of Grit Theatre. Although, native of the Bluegrass State, Paige has considered Chicago and the theatre community to be her home for the past 5 years. Paige received her B.S. Degree- double major in Theatre and Public Relations from Murray State University. Paige's Chicago credits include: All Mixed Up (Barely Concealed Productions), Hellcab (Profiles), Suburbia (Level 11 Theatre), Reasons to be Happy (Profiles). Although acting is her passion, Paige has always had a curiosity for directing. Grit Theatre's production of Danny and the Deep Blue Sea will be Paige's professional directorial debut. 

Producer-Ricky Quintana is a Chicago native whose credits include work with Raven Theatre, Red Theater Chicago, Steep Theatre Co, No Stakes, Profiles Theatre, Blue Goose, and many more. He holds his BFA from Long Island University and will be an MFA Candidate at Arizona State University this fall.

Costume Designer- Devan Reed is an alumni of Murray State University where he studied aesthetic design for theatre. He has designed shows such as "Legally Blonde the musical" "Hairspray" "The Amish Project" "Sister Act" and many more. He is very excited to join Grit Theatre To design character aesthetics for "Danny and the Deep Blue Sea."

story:
Who are You?

6 Degrees Collaborative has been around since 2013. Since our inception we have provided free movement workshops to the Boys and Girls Club of Fort Collins, after school programs, community centers, and senior centers along the Colorado front range. 6 Degrees is a group of professional dancers, musicians, visual, and performing artists that have come together to bring affordable performing art experiences and productions to audiences along the Colorado Front Range. We craft our evening length shows by using inspired themes from old and original literary sources. 6 Degrees composes and arranges music and visuals around the  movement created by every member of the collaborative. We currently have a small, dedicated, and professional team from all different backgrounds and disciplines.  6 Degrees creates  and connects communities. We help people get out side of their box and bring awareness to the beauties in sutbletes, the extraordinary in the ordinary, we create an interest in art and literature that is often over looked in todays schools, high paced life, and popular culture.

What are you doing? What would me donating mean?

Your contribution means everything for the continuation of 6Degrees and our innovative advancements in the performing arts and our community outreach programs. Our community outreach programs have the potential to reach hundreds of youth, seniors, and special needs in schools, day programs, and centers across Fort Collins, Loveland, Boulder, and Denver areas. Many of the participants in our workshops have never had the opportunity to go to a dance class, never heard of the classical literature that we derive our performance from, have never heard the classic rock that we choreograph to, or have had the opportunity to meet, interact, and see a professional performing arts company. Many of the places that we visit are not able to afford the services that many of their clients benefit from. Putting together these outreach programs and affordable community performance demands time and money.

6Degree’s current workshop and performance is an educational, innovative, and immersive endeavor. We take on themes from Ancient Greek theatre, legends, monsters, and gods by using Homer’s the Odyssey abstractly and psychologically. Our audience is not only exposed modern dance but also classic and modern from the likes of David Bowie, Tori Amos, and original modern rock scores from 6 Degrees. Our free community workshops use our creation methods of creative movement, trust, team work, and confidence to build their own monster and create their own of moving art work, while teaching our participants about Ancient Greek stories that we were inspired from. These workshop are led by 6Degrees director and we plan on doing 5 starting at the end of February and continuing that pace of work shops for the rest of year with proper funding.

 

What do you need and what do I get?

 We are trying to be as frugal as we can with our small budget. 6Degrees set a goal of 2,000 to help cover costs of many things that is quite tasking for a small, growing, non-profit:

 Rehearsal space $9 hr for 4-6 hour minimum a week

Performers rehearsal time and performance fee (yes it sounds like a ton fun but it is very wearing on the body and it is work) 7 performers ideally $13 per hour for  4-6 hrs min per week rehearsal time and $200 performance fee

 All of our dancers have day jobs and must take time off work to help make the performances happen

Marketing materials and inexpensive ads to help us get the word and reach more people. 

This normally averages to be about $300 but be because of kind printers we are able to keep this cost slightly down. We do utilize as many free forms of advertising and public event calendars as possible. 

Instructor’s fee for teaching Free community workshops to schools, daycare centers, senior centers community centers and day programs. These sessions run from 30mins to an hour and the instructor need at least $25 per hour to help compensate for time, travel expenses, and workshop planning.

Theatre Rental fees 

Our most current fee is $350 for a day but this does not include a lighting designer…We will be paying about this for the next performances we have planned in the Spring and Summer of 2017 

Technical and lighting crew 

These are the guys that really make the show look bangin’! With out them you would not get full theatrical feel. We have some very kind volunteers right now but this is also what these guys do for a living for these and we want to pay them what they deserve. This can cost up from anywhere to $300-$1000 for one show run.

costume and equipment maintenance

 We want to look good for ya. Since we have a shoe string budget we have great looking costumes that need a little love after performing for you!

We will also be using these funds to go towards our current production on March 3rd and for upcoming future works based off early 20th century Sci-Fi novels in the summer and fall of 2017

6Degrees is offering many cool perks from posters, photos, original art work to private lessons and rehearsal peeks.

All contributions made will help pay for the things we listed above. A donation of any size is a tremendous help on our show string budget. We are building this wonderful interactive community project from the ground up and no contribution is too small or will go unnoticed!

 

The Impact

After working with many kids and people from all backgrounds. I have learned that that people leave feeling inspired from dance and movement. Many kids I have talked to have never of Homer, the Odyssey, David Bowie, and many classic novels we draw inspiration from. For them it opens the doors to a rich culture experience they never thought possible. Many other participants have told me that never know dance could be accessible to them or presented in such a way like we have done. This strongly encouraging and our love for our audience and supporters continues to grow. 

 

We have just been awarded our 501c3 non-profit status. We started a kickstarter two years ago for the IRS filing fee and even had enough left over to help pay for rehearsal space. Our success in this campaign contributed to many generous friends, donors, and supporters that donated. Asking is not always easy for an artist but it is becoming increasingly necessary for projects such as ours to exist. We chose indiegogo because it is a safe and convenient way for you to donate to our cause. We are not asking for hand outs or for you to fund our hippie vacations. We are asking for help to fund a true asset to the community and our culture. Since we are a non-profit performing arts company we can apply for future grants and donations are tax-deductible.

We have 3 seasons of performing under our belt. 6Degrees has sold out performance and also performance many intimate shows.

Risks & Challenges

We are in the business of the performing arts and any business there are risks and challenges. Our biggest challenge is having financial backing to take our productions to the next level or even maintain where we are at. Meaning nice lighting and sound to make the shows look and sound more professional, paying performers for rehearsal time, having more rehearsal time, providing pay to our instructors for our free workshops, giving more free workshops, and insuring pay for our hard working crew and cast.

6Degrees is in its 5th year of creating and we have survived despite major financial backing, however our team and productions are growing and with out donations and grants the ability for us to enrich the community with innovative dance theatre, music, workshops and affordable performances will be nearly impossible.

Other Ways You Can Help

We understand that not everyone may be able to donate however you can still share this fundraiser with your friends, follow us on social media, and come to our events! If your far away and want to come support us but distance proves too much to travel then you can donate to our cause with lots of awesome perks!

You can share this on Twitter, FaceBook, Instagram, etc with the easy indiegogo link!

 

P.S. We are in no way against hippie vacations they sound like fun. Sometimes.

story:
Greetings and Salutations.

Pullman.vs.Paxton is a 501c3 non-profit group of musicians, actors, and event producers striving to make kickass musical theatre with limited funds. In addition to putting on a quality show, we make sure to donate a large portion of our proceeds from each production to LGBTQ+ and LGBTQ+ ally non-profit agencies such as Peace for the Streets by Kids from the Streets, Gay City Health Project, It Gets Better Project, Freedom to Marry, and Human Rights Campaign.

The running joke about our company is that we only choose the most shocking, loud, lewd, and downright weird rock musicals to produce. And to that end – this production will definitely not disappoint. This time around, we’re hoping to use the magic of lights, sound, cool clothes, and a lot of wheat paste and duct tape to bring Heathers the Musical to life at the Erickson Theatre-Off Broadway from April 6-15, 2018. We have the vision and the know-how, but we don't have the benefit of a big theatre company backing us up. With your help, we hope we can bring a professional-quality production to the stage.

What's your damage? 

Here's the skinny. The biggest challenge of producing Broadway-sized musicals on a non-Broadway budget is being able to pay our actors, musicians, and crew the wages they deserve.

It's 2017 and Seattle's economy is skyrocketing, performing arts venues are either closing or raising their rates, and it's becoming increasingly more difficult to fund a licensed show and meet charitable donation goals, all while compensating our actors, musicians, and crew. 

Licensed musical theater costs big bucks: $3160 for licensing rights, $6394 for venue rental, $1100 for 10 weeks of rehearsal space rental, $1200 for wireless headset and sound equipment rental… not to mention advertising, costumes and set, and things like photographer fees and lighting designer quotes.

We are asking for your help pre-funding some of the basics, so we can make sure ticket sales go toward the important stuff like paying actors, musicians, and behind the scenes folks for their time and talent. We also want to ensure that we can afford give a sizable donation to one of our favorite non-profit organizations, the It Gets Better Project.

Never heard of us? We’re legit! Check out our past achievements:

Prior to PVP from 2011-2015, we worked as the Executive and Artistic Directors of Chandelier Productions along with former co-founder Jack Chandelier. In that time, our shows raised needed funds for many local and national organizations, including Peace for the Streets by Kids from the Streets (2015), Gay City Health Project (2012/2013), and the It Gets Better Project (2011). We have had a lot of success with “one-night only” or short run productions in music venues and non-traditional theater spaces in Seattle including “The Rocky Horror Show” at the Showbox Market (raising over $8,000 for Gay City) and a sell-out performance of “Hedwig & The Angry Inch” at The Crocodile in 2011, where in conjunction with Rudy’s Barbershop, The Stranger, and Cupcake Royale, we raised more than $10,000 for IGB Project.

Here’s a little taste of our past productions:

Green Day's American Idiot @ Eclectic Theater (2016)

Spring Awakening  @ Broadway Performance Hall (2015 - as Chandelier Productions)

 

The Rocky Horror Show @ Showbox Market (2013 - as Chandelier Productions)

 
 

Hedwig & the Angry Inch @ The Crocodile (2011 - as Chandelier Productions)

 
 

The Rocky Horror Show @ Washington Hall (2012 - as Chandelier Productions) 

 

What’s in it for you?

Whether you come as a fan of the movie or the off-Broadway musical, our hope is that you will leave our production with a new appreciation for Heathers. We want to pay homage to this living, breathing piece of history all while putting our own stamp on it.

As a company, we want everyone who sees one of our shows to feel at home with our cast and company. We are like a “choose your own adventure” story. Whether you are in a front row VIP seat or swaying in the back – you choose how you interact with us - rock out with us, learn the tunes, yell sh*t at us, be a part of our show and we will be a part of your memories.

With this campaign we are pulling out all our DIY skills and offering you a number of Heathers themed merch items in exchange for your support:

  • a Heathers the Musical poster signed by the company, cast, and crew
  • a Heathers themed pin set (including 4 buttons with all the best one-liners)
  • a BIG FUN t-shirt (like the one Martha wore in the movie)

We’re also offering other cool things: BQ Corn Nuts, anyone? Tickets to the show? Our eternal thanks and gratitude for helping us make this show a go? Oh, and we’ll totally talk about you on social media. That’s a given.

Can't afford to donate? Other ways you can help: 

  • Come to our show! It's at the Erickson Theatre Off-Broadway in Seattle, Washington from April 6-15, 2018. Tickets will be $25-$30 and it’s going to be beautiful!
  • Get weird with us on social media! Like Pullman.vs.Paxton on Facebook and follow us on Instagram and Twitter.
  • Get out and talk about us! Word of mouth is the best kind of advertisement we can get.

The Rocky Horror Show @ Washington Hall (2012 - as Chandelier Productions)  What’s in it for you? Whether you come as a fan of the movie or the off-Broadway musical, our hope is that you will leave our production with a new appreciation for Heathers. We want to pay homage to this living, breathing piece of history all while putting our own stamp on it.As a company, we want everyone who sees one of our shows to feel at home with our cast and company. We are like a “choose your own adventure” story. Whether you are in a front row VIP seat or swaying in the back – you choose how you interact with us - rock out with us, learn the tunes, yell sh*t at us, be a part of our show and we will be a part of your memories.With this campaign we are pulling out all our DIY skills and offering you a number of Heathers themed merch items in exchange for your support:
a Heathers the Musical poster signed by the company, cast, and crew
a Heathers themed pin set (including 4 buttons with all the best one-liners)
a BIG FUN t-shirt (like the one Martha wore in the movie)
We’re also offering other cool things: BQ Corn Nuts, anyone? Tickets to the show? Our eternal thanks and gratitude for helping us make this show a go? Oh, and we’ll totally talk about you on social media. That’s a given.Can't afford to donate? Other ways you can help: 
Come to our show! It's at the Erickson Theatre Off-Broadway in Seattle, Washington from April 6-15, 2018. Tickets will be $25-$30 and it’s going to be beautiful!
Get weird with us on social media! Like Pullman.vs.Paxton on Facebook and follow us on Instagram and Twitter.
Get out and talk about us! Word of mouth is the best kind of advertisement we can get.
